content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												150 Hour review, okey so i've been playing X-rebirth (on steam) for 150 hours now so thought why not its probably time to write a review for the game so others can see what its like. the first thing to get out of the way is NO this is not X-rebirth 1.0 that sucked and was almost umplayable and missing a lot, i'm playing on X-rebirth 3.51 atm and they have truely turned the game around and its pretty much amazing now.What i love about the gameThe thing about x-rebirth that i love is how massive the world is and the fact it is all rendered in real time with all of your owned ships, you can be just wandering around a station collecting stashes while one of your stations is receiving wares on the other side of the galaxy, or one of your patrolling ships encounters a xenon that wondered into the area. the world never stops and waits for you to finish a mission or to catch up to someone your following to continue like it does on so many other games and thats one of the things i love about it. The other major thing i love is that you control all of whats happening from your one ship, the Albion skunk you can start as just a little ship doing all the work yourself to managing a giant fleet, or a trading empire or whatever you want and its so imersive in that sense because you don't just instantly get these things you have to find ways to get the money to buy a construction vessel to start building a station, be it slowly with missions moving cargo or transporting people, or by accepting missions from the pirate factions and getting several million by causing mass chaos (at the downside of turning factions against you) you can do whatever you want.What i hate about the gameHonestly the only thing that bugs me about the game is how they haven't been able to go as far as they could of with the whole idea of the economy, yeah each faction has its own funds and stations and resources and stuff but theres still instances where it feels like ships spawn in out of nowhere instead of being built, like with some of the pirate factions in the game, they have their own stations yes but they are in now way capable of building ships or making money to supply the pirates? and the pirates don't actually raid trade shipments, they attack it then if they win they just fly off and look for another one. i can't help but feel that they could have done more with that so that pirates actually had to attack people to survive and if you fought them off enough or launched attacks on their outposts it would slow them down or eventually destroy that faction. since you can make giant empires and have fleets of 50 ships easily but you cant seem to stop a group of pirates. Communitythe only problem with the game changing so much is that when you search google for guides and stuff they are all for older versions of x-rebirth, or the wiki's are no longer up-to-date because the people who were working on them have long since given up on the game as have many fans because of how long it has taken them to get a nicely working version of it. it's also majorly effected the game's rating and put off a lot of new gamers coming to play it, but trust me this is not the same game it is a epic trading/empire/war simulation.Modswith the prospect of mods now aswell you can completely destroy people's stations and help some factions build more of their own, the mods have added a tonn of content to the game along with what there already is in it so i do recomend checking them out.Overall, if you like actually thinking about a game then get this xD its whatever you wanna do kinda game and worth the cash, if you wanna get nitty gritty into working out different productions and sabotaging other companies so your's will be able to sell stuff at higher price you can be that kinda player, but if you just like flying around shooting stuff there is that too, whatever kinda playstyle you have you can make your way in x-rebirth

number of helpful: 77 of 103 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												As you can see by my play stats I have played this game inside out and have come to this conclusion; X Rebirth has loads of potential and scope, but sadly falls way short of what it promises to be.I have sunk over 500 hours into X3 and X3TC and can say that I enjoy the X games, but this one is simply not what you would expect and to make matters worse it should have come out on Early Access. The game is nowhere complete with functionality lacking and outsight not working in certain situations. Egosoft are patching, but as I have dealt with them before this is nothing new, but still doesn't excuse the mess this game is.I have had to edit my save file numerous times just to complete the game and was rewarded by a lame end mission which comes and goes without anything happening and you are left wondering 'Ummm did I just finish the game??'. The bottom line is that they sacrificed what the X series was all about in order to attract new customers, which is a viable business strategy but is a very dangerous thing to do with a game such as X.Because of this decision you get the feeling as if the game was intended for controller use and I think was to be for next gen consoles, but at the last minute I think they pulled the game and Egosoft were left with a game made for consoles which now had to go PC. Now this is speculation, but from the UI layout and functionality it would seem as if this is what the game was geared up for and then had to be quickly ported to PC..... maybe.My final thoughts;Space looks lovely at times and flying between floating cities close to a planet looks breathtaking, but on foot in stations and other areas the lo-fi textures are all too evident. Shoddy menu management and design choices (I had to make a whole new set of UI elements as the default set is woeful), buggy/non-working game play elements, annoying travelling mini game, poor ship and NPC AI, clipping and texture issues, sound issues...... in fact let’s just wrap this up into one sentence;This game in not complete and will not be for at least another 6 months, maybe try back then.

												I have always loved the X series of games.  I have to say while this game seems to have alot of potential and I am really excited about the future of it, it is sadly in the beta stage.  It is wrought with bugs such as ships not responding, graphics disappearing, missions that are unachieveable with editing the save game file.  The rest of the universe seems to ignore you when you try to build stations and are buying materials.  I left the game running over nite to see if some npc trading would occur over time and nothing happened.  The npc characters on the stations are terriable, everywhere you go they are the same with extremely bad and constantly repeated dialog.  I have tried to overcome all these pitfalls and have spent more time researching how to change the save game file and be able to move to the next mission than I have played the game.  I think the game will be an excellant game when it is completed,  I can not believe it was sold in this state.  Anyone who had tried to play through the story line would have very quickly that the game was seriously broken.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Whenever friends asked why I played the X series I always told them that buried under all the sh*t was a diamond and it was only a matter of time before enough patches and community content wiped all the crap away and exposed the games for the gems I really believed they were. They didn't believe me - they knew Egosoft's reputation for DOA game delivery (as did I) - but I kept the hope alive. And while far, FAR from perfect X3:R and X3:TC with substantial modding proved to be decent experiences in the end. We have to take what we can get in this genre - It feels like there will never be another Freespace 2.I guess hope died when X was reborn. All the problems I had hoped resolved in this game - horrible AI, ships colliding constantly, UI that can only be explained as having been designed to annoy and torment - were still present and accounted for. And then some. A lot of some. Yes, it's pretty to be sure but not pretty enough to justify the sheer terror it will run your CPU and GPU through. The campaign is nothing more than a broken tutorial. Combat with other ships is akin to a special-needs jousting contest. I could go on and on but others have done my job for me. Lamentably, Egosoft doesn't appear to be listening.I don't know why this keeps happening with Egosoft's releases. A more naive soul might blame the developers but as a developer myself I have to believe that the product management and sales of Ego's games are driving them straight into the ground. Much like what you'll be doing with the Albion Skunk should you deign to pilot her.Pass on this one. Check back again in 3 years. And don't make the mistake of buying Egosoft before the community has had a chance to find something redeeming and shiny under all this sh*t.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												You can't really write a one-liner about this one, or make a 'pros vs. cons' review.If you want a quick summary: This game is what you make of it. Even at its current state (4.0 with existing DLCs), I simply don't see myself going back to vanilla after all the awesomeness and great fun that mods brought me.The PastYou can't really recommend the game without stating that:X Rebirth had a terrible launch, and the vanilla experience will most likely disappoint you..unless you strictly want to play the plot.Egosoft probably tried to make the best space game they could imagine, but lack of time made they cut huge chunks of the game out for the release. Even though the crazy amount of updates make up for a lot of it, certain issues are at the core of the game, like the UI, the static NPCs inside stations, and all the insane interruptions that can get to the point of preventing you to control your ship as you fly in range of enemy JET/LR [aka Instakill] Turrets.All the other issues with the game are probably down to the fact that Ego aimed at a more "casual-ized" experience and approach to the X series (noticeable by surprisingly including release for console platforms). Therefore, they managed to miss both X series fans (usually hardcore gamers) and more-casual players completely, making the game sit in a X-tremely awkward spot.What I mean by that is that a "casual" audience will probably not like the huge amount of time it takes to build a station or to obtain the items to build the Jump Drive, and the hardcore audience would probably be much more interested in investing time in their empire, waging wars or stealing cargo than scanning huge, empty areas of space and reloading the game 100 times until you manage to open a lockbox with 1 out of 10 pieces of components to craft something.With all that said, you do have to give props for the devs for such an interesting, rich and, sometimes, very immersive universe. By simply flying around or walking around stations, you can see what they were going for.I've finished the game back in version 2.0 (or 2.5). I played vanilla for a long time, and started adding mods slowly. After finishing the plot, I couldn't stand all the issues and quirks of the game and quit. It was, overall, an annoying and hurtful experience.The PresentI played a lot more with version 3.5, and in this playthrough I added more mods as the plot progressed. This made the game become extremely fun, since the game and mods were now much more stable and developed. Slowly adding more mods felt like I was buying/adding/unlocking upgrades.I had lots of fun and ignored the plot halfway through it, but there were still quirks and rough edges that made a lot of things take days - if not weeks - to achieve or obtain. So I took a long break.After 4.0 and HoL hit, I added even more mods and finished the game again, and now I'm having a blast and actually finishing constructing stations and growing a trade and a military fleet.All this thanks to SETA and a mod that makes CapShips jump around faster without refueling. Those two things alone make the game playable on a less insane level. I mean, if you wait for buses for 60 minutes in real life, you don't really want to wait more than half an hour for your fleet to refuel, traverse Jump Gates, and jump to you..only to wait all that again once you're done doing things on the System you were at.Of course, this is my personal opinion. I played for over 70 hours without changing the game's 'pacing', and the original pacing does make everything much more satisfying once achieved. But it gets old - especially if you don't want to spend weeks to achieve certain things.ConclusionThis game was a crazy attempt by Egosoft at developing something totally new for them, and an amazing display of how modders can completely change, fix and turn quirks and horrible issues completely around.The living universe is, as always, beautiful. The NPCs messaging you about issues with their budget, or checking with your Architect the state of your new station's construction, or even the silly detail of mass traffic around stations and highways will truly make your mind wander like very few other games can. Even with all the quirks (mostly fixed), you can't help but feel the love and dedication of developers and artists when flying around stations and looking at their tiny details. It's really insane how such a small team have produced so many inspiring stuff over so many years. I can only hope that Ego hears the community and make even better stuff from now on.A quick overview of the game's characteristics before I run out of space:Graphics looks beautiful, the game Sounds great (except for some sounds that are way too loud or slightly annoying, and certain music loops gets old fast), the VOs are much better than previous games (and I still freaking love Betty) - you WILL eventually need mods to make a lot of interactions silent, though. I appreciate a lot the effort for making the game more alive and real, but making certain dialogs/comms unskippable makes it unbearable after the 100th time. The Plot and Plot Missions are WAY better than before (but could do with many improvements). As with any and all X games - forever - could do with optimizations. But since 4.0 I had ZERO crashes, and many performance issues are probably caused by one or more of the +85 mods I use.The Gameplay and flying around feels much more personal and fun than previous titles, even though you'll probably have to remap controls to suit your tastes/needs.There's a decent variety of Ships and Missions to choose from, and enough freedom to let you focus on certain activities and completely ignore other ones - just like previous titles. You can, however, only pilot one ship (the Skunk), which is a weird design choice.The Trading is probably the most disappointing aspect for previous players, as it's completely manual. Utter madness! Mods will save you here, though.The character limit won't enable me to state all of the remaining games positive and negative features.So, as stated initially, "this game is what you make of it". If you love space games, or the X Universe, I trust you are one of those that are willing to take the time to tailor the game to suit your tastes.It's not great to recommend a game based on it's mods - but the X series is unique enough to make it worth it.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												It's honestly with a heavy heart that I do not recommend X: Rebirth.First some backstory.I first got into the X series with X3: Terran Conflict.  It was intimidating and daunting, but I got it during a sale, and I figured that I should at least invest some time into it.  While it was a rocky start at first, I managed to learn the ropes and have myself a good time with space combat and trading.  Excited, I bought Albion Prelude, and got even more enjoyment due to the improvements upon the systems.  The addition of the stock market, for example, was very much appreciated.Soon after playing Albion Prelude, I heard about the development of X: Rebirth.  Promising to be more accessible but just as deep, I became incredibly excited.  Bohemia Interactive had promised something similar with ARMA3 and they delivered on their promise.  I expected just the same from Egosoft- and why not?  They had been working on the X series for more than 10 years- they knew what their fans wanted and expected.At least... They should've known.But X: Rebirth put my faith into Egosoft into doubt.X: Rebirth is nothing short of a mess.First off, the game is poorly optimized, with framerate drops quite abundant in the earlier areas and very apparent across the campaign.  Some areas are not quite as bad, but it's very clear that there was minimal QA done.  The computer I use is very powerful but even then it chugs with Rebirth.  Secondly, things are buggy.  Ships under your command behave strangely, trading sometimes does not carry out, and orders can be backed up with no way to cancel them.  Saying that it is a test of patience would give too much credit to the game- it is downright broken.  Patches have fixed some of the problems, but many still hang around.Thirdly, the elements Egosoft touted for immersion are of poor quality.  From the number of character models to the interiors to the voice acting...  The detail is not even up to 2008 standard, much less a game being released in 2013.  This could be forgiven somewhat if it wasn't for the fact of how repetitious many of these elements were.  There's probably only about five or so voice actors across the entire game, all with equally wooden delivery.  Ren Otani's VA is the best, but that's best in the sense of "Of all the moldy sandwiches in the fridge, this one has the least amount of mold."Minigames have been put in place, but they feel incredibly out of place in a game meant to be a space trading simulator.  Tapping buttons to time "convince" meters for small-talk or zipping behind ships to speed through the highways are elements intended for action-focused games, not simulators.But perhaps most heartbreaking of all, the game is missing so many features that made the past X games great.  The radar system is now gone, as well as readouts for speed and distance.  Combat has been given more of a focus but it has lost its complexity and tactical thought.  The elements that should help with establishing a gian trade empire are gone, such as trade automation.This is not the X game that we were promised.There ARE some things in X: Rebirth that are worthwhile.  The detail put into the universe is nothing short of incredible.  The low texture resolution can be forgiven as there is now a true sense of scale to the world- the highways, one of the most impressive elements in X: Rebirth, zip you from sector to sector, which can range from stations located in the center of a broken planet to derelict but surviving facilities only tens of thousands of miles away from a star.  It's awe-inspiring, flying around in space.The base of X: Rebirth is not terrible.  It has given us a more moddable engine capable of a very detailed universe.  But sadly, it should've been more.  Knowing Egosoft, they will work tirelessly to patch and fix the game, but the damage has been done- I've lost a lot of my trust in them.  After being so enthusiastic about a game, I honestly feel betrayed.Perhaps in a few months, the game may become what I expected.  When that time comes, I'll revisit this review.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												*Listens quietly for the sound of nails being hammered into wood* I so wanted to love this game even after having come to the X-universe late but X-Rebirth isn't so much a Rebirth as it is a nail in the coffin. Yes, the Teladi outpost DLC fixed a few things but it doesn't change the fact that Egosoft threw out almost everything good about the X3's and gave us... This.ProsThe graphics are simply stunning. I cannot deny the vista's are utterly jaw droppingThe music is sweeping and epicNew sector system-In the previous game each 'map' was one sector which had so many stations, ships and jump gates leading to other sectors. The downside to this is that they had a rather definitive edge to them and expanding beyond the default size of a given sector was difficult. In Rebirth they have highways linking regions withing sectors so that they are now exponentially biggerConsThe highway system to enable FTL travel between regions means they decided to do away with the SETA drives. Singularity Engine Time Accelerator. In a nutshell, it would speed the game up to a maximum factor of %1000 to allow you to cross even massive sectors rapidly however here your only options to move swiftly are to take the highways, which are fixed and only link between regions one way or to boost your way across at speeds not all that much greater than your normal. However that introduces annother problem:Boosting drains your shield. Fair enough, in the last game boosting would eat away at your shield but only if you didn't have enough energy cells to power it. In Rebirth your only options are to arrive at a fight late, or with your shield depleated.Steering is either by joystick (and it doesn't have pre-built profiles so you have to bind everything manualy) or by cursor flight. Either pointing at a spot on the screen and clicking the mouse until you're poiting where you want to go or by moving the mouse around on the screen and it will keep turning that way. Now, for those of us without a joystick this can act as a virtual stick, meaning we don't have to move our mice up and reset them mid-manouver however it also feels difficult and can serve to dull reaction times. This was an option in the previous games but that's where the problem lies. It was an OPTION. Here you have no choice in it.The Ship. Now, as I recal in the first X games you only had on ship you could be in, fair enough it was a while ago in computing terms and resources were limited however they soon corrected this to the point where you could fly around in just your space suit, a small one man scout ship, bombers, corvettes, frigates, destroyers, carriers or even, if you had balls that clanked as you walked, The Valhalla. A ship so large it can't actually fit through a gate. In Rebirth, you're stuck in one ship. This wouldn't be an issue if the ship were any good but it isn't. From the top:It's name is the Albion Skunk. I don't know who thought of this but in the previous games it was named the Albion Pride. And no, you can't even change it's text. I might be able to live with it if your co-pilot (more on her in a sec) didn't say it every time you came into dockThe ship computer from previous games makes a comback, I'd gotten used to her and quite liked the announcements she made but here, the only thing more irritating than 'Betty' the computer is Yisha the co-pilot telling Betty to shut upThe speed is not great, made all the worse by the lack of aformentioned SETA drive and the only boost feature eating up your shieldDrones, missiles and weapons are all limited. And you only get one gun... One. You can have a few on your ship at a time but you can only shoot one. Even the samallest, least combat capable scout ships in X3 Albion Prelude have two. And of course, you are stuck in this one ship. Sure, you can get out and walk on stations but you have to come back to it sooner or later. Or spend the rest of your life running the vents like a rat, trying to make a living out of oddly placed credits and random junk you can sell. Either or. Frankly, I'd choose vent rat

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Lastest update 1.30 patch makes this game very playable. The X-Series games are sandbox after the storyline campaign. The campaign is huge and everything works, of course there are tips on the forums for some parts. I stopped using all the mods and really enjoy the vanilla game now. Once you have your first station running you will see how much depth in trading you have to manage. Assign some ships to your station and they will take over some of it for you.Space is beautiful and the universe is much larger than even X3 Albion Prelude. It is divided differently, but not smaller. I have a fleet of ships patrolling sectors and many transports running wares all over trying to keep my business profits up. Every transport destroyed has an impact on the market due to the products it would have carried.There are many ways to edit your 'save files' but I've learned that it spoils the game. The fun of winning, for me, is gained by figuring out how to earn the credits and build your empire and not just giving yourself millions of credits. When you play this game just be prepared to spend many hours/days/weeks learning about the markets and the universe. Egosoft does make it easy to start playing, but the depth of their previous games is still here in X-Rebirth. Bookmark this website:  http://roguey.co.uk/xrebirth/waresI expect to be playing this game for a long time. If you got this game months ago and had problems, try it again now. It's a beautiful game now.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												2.20 ReviewWhen I was first set loose in X: Rebirth's vast universe, right after it's release, I was convinced it was going to be amazing.  But I quickly realised that this was, in fact, a colossal supernova of bugs and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game design that refuses to let you have any fun – and I really tried. I forgot about the game for a while, and came back to play the 2.20 update, hoping that the game would be fixed by now. I was disappointed, again.First problem: you only get to pilot one ship, the horribly named Albion Skunk. You're able to explore it using a first-person mode, which could have been fun if there were more than two rooms to it, and if anything was even slightly interactive. The cockpit is cluttered and restrict your vision horribly, and it took me a good while to find some of the most important HUD elements, such as the speedometer. Which isn't that well done either. Eventually I found a guy that sells different cockpits, ehich there are four of. And so, I was saved from the horrors of the stock cockpit by bying the very open, combat-oriented one.If I remember correctly EgoSoft said that there's only one ship to incease immersion and that they couldn't have made the capitalship gameplay fun while keeping the mobility realistic. Well, changeing ships has worked just fine in the other games. I would've paid extra for the ability to change into something with more than one gun. Even if it was just a frikin' shuttle.Then there's your co-pilot, Yisha. For a character you spend the entire game with, and who's almost constantly talking, you'd think they would have hired someone with some basic acting ability to speak her lines. But while you'll eventually grow used to her awkward delivery, you'll never stop cursing how useless she is. Case in point: if you're piloting a drone, and enemies start attacking the Skunk, she'll just sit there dumbly. Couldn't you, like, move, or fight back, or something? Not to mention her, and everyone else's, bad animations and ridiculous outfits. Oh, and a boob-window on a spacesuit. Because logic.Second problem: The voice acting. Oh god, the voice acting is absolutely horrible. It has to be mentioned multiple times. I could rate this game negative just because of it, but there's so much more. The game has a big problem with humans in genereal. On stations – which all look identical – you'll talk to NPCs, who are terrifying, slot-mouthed, dead-eyed mannequins. While space itself feels nicely alive, teeming with traffic and huge ships lumbering back and forth, the interiors feel lifeless and boring. In a nightclub I hear the ambient sound of people drinking and laughing, but it's empty except for two people standing motionless by the bar. Thankfully you don't really have to enter stations anymore, you now can do all interaction straight from your ship. But since it's done as a video conversation with the character you're speaking to, there's no escape from the animations and voice acting.How about something positive for a change? Stations aside, Rebirth fares much better when you're in space. Ignoring some messy shadows, it's a good-looking game, with colourful nebulas, asteroids, planets and star. The combat is like jousting in space. Ships make passes at each other, firing a volley of shots when they get close and hoping some connect. Or you can use heatseeking missiles. Hit the spacebar and you can strafe, FPS-style. Hit it again to steer with the mouse. The movement feels nicely weighty.Except that the Skunk can only mount one weapon at a time, which are all extremely underpowered compared to the fact that enemies can mount multiple ones, and have near-perfect aim. Missiles are nice, and one of the only ways to make combat work for me. The other is to fly to a station and hope the turrets kill the hostiles before you die.Third problem: you have separate ships for trading that follow you around and have to be given orders. You couldn't, and still can't, buy any trade-goods with your own ship, everything has to be done with slow and dumb freighters that can't even fight pirates reliably, despite the 20 turrets that are mounted on them. You can't cancel an order without editing your save file, and sometimes the freighter just refuses to move, breaking the entire save and preventing the plot from progressing. It's like I'm dragging a badly-behaved toddler around a shopping centre. Thank god they've fixed most of those bugs by now, but the trading UI is still slightly confusing at times and the ships are still ridiculously dumb.The UI... It's confusing and mostly useless.It's designed to work around a controller, on a PC-exclusive title.There's so much done wrong with this game, even this full A4 page of text is just the beginning. No matter what happens with stability and bug-fixing patches, its poor controls, awful interface, and dull pacing ensure that X Rebirth will remain unpleasant for all but the most forgiving, die-hard space jockeys. And oh god, the voice-acting...

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Promising sequel of the great X series, it's resulted flawed by many bugs and, most important, terrible, terrible, design decisions. First, the good part: - Improved space graphic: the ships, the effects, the stations and the sky is/are simply amazing;- Most of the core mechanics of the previous X games are imported here (like owning many ships/stations, complex economic system, boarding system, etc..);- Fast travel system: they made the sectors both wide and easy to travel in a very nice way- Living space: the stations feels (and are) alive, with many ships that docks and leave anytime while security patrols keeps things safe- Subsystems: the fact that you can target specific subsystems was a very requested improvement, glad they added itNow the bad part:- The interface is almost unusable. Such complexity was handled in all the previous games with many (but simply) buttons and tables on the hud, now all you have is a small (and dark) multi-level radial menu. That means that most of the options are hidden on sub-levels, and even if you know where to look, it will takes 4-5 inputs before your action will be performed. The radial menu is great for chatting alternatives (and such) on rpgs, but it's awful if you want to submit orders and visualize the status of your ship;- You can directly control just one, single, ship. You can still submit orders to other ships, but instead a single table, you have to "speak" with the person you hired to work on that ship (see radial menu concerns above). Actually this can be a minor issue, since the ship is highly moddable and the drone system somewhat mitigate the problem, but forget to jump into your newly conquered ship. Those times are gone, egosoft declared;- The indoor experience: It's not about the 10-years old models/textures of the interior; It's not about the awful "thief-like" minigame inside it; It's not about the time lost in the search of a specific guy to hire in order to use the extra ship you got (a thing that was simple&free in the previous X games). It's about all of that, and much more. At this state, it's just an ugly and useless feature that should be re-designed, if not removed alltogether.- Awful dogfighting system. The lack of basilar stuff like the gravidar and the targeting controls (both presents on the previous X) makes the fighting somewhat problematic;- Doubleclicks everywhere: from the start menu to the last ship that comes your way, if you want to perform a mouse action on an item, you need to double click it. Forget the "mouseOver" events, do you want to make a new game? one click to select "new game" button, and one click to confirm. Do you want to modify a setting? double click there. and so on..Not a real trouble, but very, very, annoying on the long run.. - Console port of a game never released on console: The FoV cap. The GUI size (and usability). The low-res textures. The small (aka ultra-compressed) data size. The "xbox" references all over the code. All of these details (and even more) points out to just one direction -> console port. How a game never release on console can be so consol-ish?  some people got a reasonable answer to this question[forum.egosoft.com]. - Terrible FPS and many bugs: Many people got a very low framerate even on high end machines. Others suffers of crashes and many other bugs. This might not be a big issue if they will fix them, but at this state of the game, the point stands.My opinion is to stick with X3:AP which is the best out of the series, and enjoy the X world until the Egosoft will address to all these issues or, more likely, will give us the real X4A man can dream, can't he?

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Despite having been released over a year ago and receiving many patches, the game still severely underperforms on high-end hardware and does not have compelling gameplay. Expect to spend 80% of your play time flying back and forth through transparent space tubes, 10% flying around space stations within 10 meters of the hull to scan information points and giving trade orders to your ships, and the last 10% pew-pewing spaceships with one weapon at a time.Here are some of the game's shortcomings:Boring gameplay consisting mostly of flying through space tubes, as if you're playing some sort of public transit passenger simulator rather than a space game.Vastly fewer weapon options with no ability to fire multiple weapons simulatenously.You can only pilot one ship unlike previous games, where you had hundreds of choices in many ship categories, from scouts to carriers to freighters.All objects in space are inexplicably surrounded by protective bubbles that absorb all damage from collisions, making the few precious moments spent outside space tubes even less exciting.A lot of tasks needlessly require the player's presence, such as chauffeuring ship officers from stations to the ships where they are to work.When talking to NPCs, you must wait for them to finish talking before your commands take effect, given the fact that a particular zone may have dozens of NPCs of the same type offering their services, this makes finding specific goods very annoying.You are forced to use a cockpit, wasting 30% of your screen on what is essentially a static model with some flashing lights here and there. A discreet HUD overlaid on an unobstructed view of space would be vastly superior for many players.The draw distance is depressing, with objects conspicuously popping in as you travel inside space tubes.The 4 different sectors are basically palette swaps of each other with a few cosmetic differences (a cracked planet here, some space debris there, etc).The script and voiceovers quite obviously weren't done by native speakers, resulting in strange and immersion-breaking dialogue and pronunciation.Character models and station interiors are very low-quality.The Teladi look like E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial. This would be funny if it weren't so tragic.Your co-pilot's jumpsuit has an embarrassing boob window that betrays a lack of respect for the playerbase.The game does feature a few improvements, however they hardly justify all its shortcomings:Capital ship components can be damaged individually, adding depth to capital ship combat.More piracy options, now you can not only extort and salvage enemy ships, but also hack them to release cargo.Station complexes now exist as superstructures rather than individual stations connected by spaghetti strands.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												After replaying this after the 3.0 patch, and with a fresher mindset, i feel I can give this game a fairer review.In a word, X rebirth, is alright. I really wish steam reviews had a better system than a thumbs up or down, because I do not believe this game to be praiseworthy, but neither should it be within the mostly negative on the steam page.It is not by any means a bad game, but it is not a great one either. I still feel if you are wanting to get into the X series, to start you should play X2: the threat or X3: Terran conflict (or Albion prelude, AP is essentially an expansion for TC anyway) however on its own, X Rebirth stands a good space 4X first person space simulator. It has some nice looking paint, a tutorial that is excellent for teaching new players to the X series (whereas before, the game plonked you into a grand universe, without even controls to do anything, with the exclusion of X3, where there is a flight school, that simply tells you how to move your ship. To start this mission, you must open communications with it, which the game neglets to give you the command to do so) Many people were also afraid of the bugs when it first came out. Most of the serious bugs have now been squashed, and the game playable, there are still errors that can be easily seen, but thankfully none that impact the gameplay massivly (the worst ive seen is a group of NPC ships getting stuck together). Although I feel that Ego was going for a major shift in gameplay, alienating many fans of the X series. I do not think that this was made to be a Space management game. Trading takes too long, and profits made during runs are often not worth the time. However, I feel that Ego was going for a more, action RPG type game, and tried to blend the X formula into it. For example, combat is a lot more profitable now, than in previous games. Repairs for your vessel could cost upwards to a few million credits in any previous X game. Here, it should cost less than 100 grand, no matter your hull. This isnt even accounting for the seemingly Hyperinflation that occured during the time of Rebirth, money is no longer measured in the hundreds of thousands, but in up to 4 digits. For example, say I had 5,264,194 credits in my account. Any previous game would show that as 5,264,194, here it is shown as 5.264M. It does not go into detail about exactly how much money you have, which would be necessary in a detailed management game. The speed of combat, and the changes in the combat system have also been changed to be a lot more faced paced. Another change to make it into a more robust Action game. There have only been a few instances in which the player was actually given a character, however those were really only referenced in the main plot missions, and then it was simply by name most of the time. Here Ren Otani (thats you) is not only given a name, but a voice and a very slight personality. He can walk around on ships, engage in talks with other people, and the player now actually thinks about who it is driving their ship, rather than the mystical being who manifestes as a space suit.I shall be continuing this review as i get further into the game, but for now, a TLDR section.X Rebirth, is not worth $40, it is an okay Space sim, with some light space managerial options and a heavy emphases on combat. It is a good game for new players into the X series to try out to get used to the ideas of how a X game operates, before moving onto a previous title if they are intrested in the management and stratergy of those games. But for now, pick up the game on sale (for $15-20 bucks or less), itll be worth your time if you havent tried out the X series and wanted to learn about it, although this game is not an accurate representation of how a X game operates. Although, space exploration is an absolute pain in this game, and areas quickly become generic.

												I preordered this game and it crushed my hopes completely then.  However the game has come a long way from when it was first launched.  Egosoft has done a lot of work in bringing the game to functionality.  They had rushed it to market way before it was ready.  If the game would have come out in the state it is in now it most likely would have been a hit.  I currently have over 800hrs playing this game in all of its states and can say I can get enjoyment out of it.  Is it a $50 game? No.  But if you can get it on sale it is definitely a game you can waste some of your time in.  The modding community has helped this game out greatly and thus are recommended for a better experience.   The only thing this game truly lacks is a comprehensive modding suite.  The ability to truly add new ships and stations to this game would expand it's possibilies.   The game is now stable and recommended.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Paying over $10 for this game will leave you with severe buyer's remorse. If you just want facts, skip the next 2 paragraphs.To begin, I'll state that if you've played X3: Reunion/Terran Conflict/Albion Prelude and loved them, this is not a sequel, spiritual successor or anything along those lines. X Rebirth falls under the "inbread abomination" category. It borrows heavily from the lore, but not from any of the concepts that made the previous titles fun to play.Don't be fooled by the positive reviews, half of them aren't even consistently deluded. With comments like "10/10" then individually listing the areas of the game as followed "Sound: 6/10, Graphics: 8/10, Gameplay: 4/10. Totally loved it" it's as if the positive reviews came from people either associated with the company or from people so dissapointed that they decided a drunken review to sucker more people out of their money was the best alternative to admitting this game was a flop. Graphics: Nothing special here and if it runs on your computer properly it can be very pretty at times, about 50% of the uses are consistantly reporting massive framerate issues even after 6+ months of release. It uses directx 9, which is several generations old at this point and most believe this was due to it's, all but confirmed by the devs, origins as a console port. Sound: The voice acting is mediocre to bad, it's repetitive too so there is really no way around listening to it.  Controls: Severly limiting, more complicated than previous "X" titles due to a complete failure to streamline them into a simpler form. No initial support for flightsticks on a space sim, the menus you use to navigate and control your *cough* "empire" *cough* are obviously designed around the limitations of a primarily controler driven interface, they took the menus from previous titles, removed them, then added in even more awkward and convoluted replacements that are twice as hard to navigate and produce half (if even that) the intended results.  Gameplay: If you like ultra repetitive minigames where you ping the map then blow up space debris for money, you'll love this game. If you like reflex minigames where you get to hear horrible voice acting, repeated over, and over, and over etc. you'll love this game. Your ship, The Albion Skunk, is essentially invincible and overtuned to the point that it's almost not fun. The ships in your fleet can't be directly controlled, they can only be given very, very basic orders and they often decide the best thing to do is follow you instead of completing those orders. These ships die or just dissapear because they're probably as sick of this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t game as you are at this point. Don't waste your money on this game, the only thing they did right was hyping the hell out of it to sell copies and even then it's arguable if that truly was the right thing. After this stinker, I'd be hard pressed to see how Egosoft expects to sell another game in this franchise to anyone.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												I'm very sorry not to be able to recommend this game, because Egosoft clearly put a tremendous amount of effort into improving what was an unmitigated disaster of a game at launch two and a half years ago.  To their credit, they've come a long way and made some good progress on this one.  I can at least say that any product you get from Egosoft, they will absolutely stand by both it and you 100%.Unfortunately there are still some big problems.  There is currently no good way to control and issue orders to large fleets of player controlled ships.  Even when issuing orders to a single vessel, you actually have to engage in a conversation with the captain of that ship to tell them to do something.  20 seconds to issue a single command?  Not good.  Especially not good in combat situations.The campaign was an attempt to train the player in all the things they can do in the X Rebirth universe, but it doesn't do a great job.  For example, you are shown how to board a ship.  What it doesn't tell you is that the team of 8 marines you do this with would NEVER be able to take a similar ship during the real game, most especially not one at full health.  Thus when you attempt your first real capital ship capture, you are met with spectacular failure no matter how many times you reload until you finally hit the forums to discover that you've been misled.  Also, now that you've captured your story scripted ship, how does one go about fueling and repairing it?  No explanation given in game.  To the forums, once again!  Not acceptable given the campaign itself is supposed to be answering these sorts of questions.X-Rebirth has come a long way since launch, and I would definitely do business in the future with a company like Egosoft, who so clearly stand by their products.  But can I recommend this one for a full $30 price tag?  No.  Sadly, I still cannot.  Perhaps some day.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												I enjoyed X3 Terran Conflict a lot and was very happy when I saw this game. But after playing it a few hours now (waiting for patches to make it run ok on my machine) I have to accept that this is nothing like the X3 I enjoyed so much.This is a console game. It's extreamly beautiful in space when you fly around but it feels like you're in a FPS game and not in a space trade sim. I hate the huge space stations with tine little dots you have to fly around and find to interact with. The space station you can (or should i say forced to) walk into.... terrible. Horror. It was cool the first time. The 2nd time it was annoying. The 3rd time I had to dock, watch the animated transitions as I exit my ship and walk into the space station to find some NPC I could only think about if there was ANY way to completely skip this... The animated transitions for everything. I hate it. I want to click somewhere and get a instant window with possible choices and issue my commands. I do NOT want to watch animated screens in the ship cockpit move up and down.  I just wish I could radio all NPCs from my ship and never ever have to set my foot in the space stations. And the voice acting... holy crap. I don't want to trade in this game because of the repetitive NPC speeches when you trade with them.X3:TC was hard to get into at first but once you understood it... it's a awesome game. This game only has one improvement over X3 and that is the graphics in space. Every single other feature is a HUGE step backwards.I'm not sure patches will fix this game. The gameplay itself and the overall gameplay design is just so bad. Performance and bugs can be fixed but this game needs a huge gameplay change to get fixed, I'm not sure it is possible. They have to remove so much to fix it it would be like starting from scratch with a new game.If you are interested in space game where you fight, trade, explore and build X Rebirth is NOT the game you are looking for.

number of helpful: 96 of 142 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The Good: (Yes there is some.) The space graphics while not Crysis are not bad in my opinion for something of this scale. I liked the new transit system as the gate system from X3 was feeling really dated. In general I liked the interface for this X game better than X3. X3 felt like a where's waldo game when you were trying to find the right command or menu for what you were looking for.  Some would chock up some of this as cut features (and it is to a large degree a simplier game than previous installtions), but I still think they did a better job with the interface this time around. It was easier to tell what a specific weapon was going to do or what effect it was going to have on my ability to fight. Hooray for not having an ai that suicide bombs into asteroids like in X3 too.The Bad: The graphics when in a space station are♥♥♥♥♥♥poor by any standard today. The textures and models for NPCs are worse. There isn't a lot of variety in this game. You only get to actually pilot one ship. The dialog lines repeat...a lot! I've heard the same string of dialog from the same person 3 times in the course of 2 minutes and I didn't try to make them talk either.The Ugly: The bugs, oh god, the bugs.  I can't say I wasn't expecting this one though. I challenge anyone to name a game of this scale that hasn't had a lot of bugs. It's just inevitable with this size of a game where it's not a linear game like Call of Duty. That isn't an excuse for them releasing it this way, but take it for what it is. The game made me rather nauesous, but I can't put my finger on why. I suspect it was somethign to do with the FOV, but I haven't had issues like this with any other game so I don't know. Trading is done now by docking and actually walking to the trader. This is nice at first, but tedious after a while when a vendor only sells a few of each ware. It makes it hard to trade. On the other hand there are little "trade hubs" for lack of a better term that allow you to dock on them and buy or sell a resource en-mass. Though it took me a while to find them. It was still really restrictive and I only ever seemed to find basic wares with this method. Summary: This game isn't ready for purchase unless you're willing to deal with the "The Ugly" section mentioned above. I hope they can make another X game and that this doesn't kill the company because I liked where they were going with some of the stuff they added.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												I play and review games a bit different. I review games as what they are and not as what they should be. So, I'll take this game as it is today and ask: Is it a good game? Preface Note that I didn't play the campaign, so I can't say anything about that. Not because I didn't like it, but because I never played any campaign in the X series. I like the sandbox playstyle.Also note I got all the DLC's so I am talking about the game with all DLCs. This is not a review of the base game.What you get when you enter this game is your ship and a huge universe. The structure of the universe and travellingWith the DLCs you get new sectors in that universe where you have no highways at all -- while in the original universe you got highways that make travelling faster. Having highways or not... for me a universe in a space sim game has to be believably big. The keyword here is believably. And from my point of view X Rebirth has that. The universe is huge. In X Rebirth the universe is divided into galaxies, each galaxy ( there are 8 ) has sectors and within those sectors you've got zones. Galaxies are connected through huge jumpgates, like the gates that connected setors in X3. The sectors in X Rebirth are connected through superhighways, where you fly through, but faster. And the zones are connected... Well in some sectors, some zones are connected by highways. You can enter and leave those highways at any point of the way, but you can also fly all the way with your ship and explore. There are entire sectors without a single highway. Your ship has a boost, but the energy for your boost is taken from your shield energy. So it will not last forever.Another way to travel faster than boosting through the universe (besides highways if they exist) is the new jumpdrive for your playership. There were some mods in the past that provided a jumpdrive, but now it was implemented by the developer. Random Missions This game started with a pretty small variaty of missions. That definetly changed. You got a huge variaty of missions, from assassination over smuggling, patrol, building (stations) requests, trading requests (deliver wares to a station), escort missions ( escort VIP ships to their target location and defend them), crafting and some more I don't remember right now. All are available at different difficulty levels. And then you got complex missions which I like most. Those are missions that combine a lot of different types of missions to a small storyline. It's not like a campaign, but it is a mission where you have to fulfill a varitaly of quests that are connected through a small story, which adds to immersion a lot. I didn't find many of those missions, but I really enjoyed the ones I played. Fighting In X Rebirth you can fight with your player ship and in a fleet with other ships you bought. Many people complain that the fleet control is not good. Well, that is true. It's pretty cumbersome to give other ships in your fleet commands. All ships in your fleet will attac what ever attacs you, but other than that, there is no simple way to command ships. But my problem about fleets is not the controls. My problem is how the game calculates the simulation when you are in the same area as the fight. In short: If you are in the same zone, your ships fight pretty bad while when you are not there watching it, they fight much better. There are some mods to optimize that, but it will probably never be perfect. I found something that works for me... though, I like to fight alone much more in this game.Your playership can only load one weapon at the time. That means, you have a variaty of weapons that you can load, but you have to choose one. So you can fire your plasma cannon, and then switch over to the heavy mining laser ( which can be a deadly weapon too) but you can't fire both at the same time. I didn't really like that when I started the game. But I realized that it adds a small layer of strategy into the fight. Your weapons are all usefull for different purposes: Some are strong against shields... others do better hull damage. They also have different ranges. Because you can not fire all your weapons at once, you got to know which weapon is strong in which situation. When I found out that I can optimize my damage by a rotation through my weapons during a fight, I really started to enjoy this kind of fight.You have missles available, but you also have to load one kind of missle and use it and then switch over to another one to use another type of missle. Boarding Boarding ships is a huge part of X Rebirth. It is probably the best way to earn money, but it's also a more complicated way. I'll try to explain the most important parts:The first thing you want to do, is hire a marine officer. That officer will command your marines when you board a ship. Now you need troopers which you can hire from a Recruiting Officer. As soon as you have both, you can try to board another ship. To get your troopers on a ship they will fly in tiny kind of shuttles, so you got to make sure they are not shot on thher way. All ships in the X universe have their own staff on board, which will fight your troopers when you try to board a ship. To weaken the enemy you have to destroy surface elements on that ship and bring the hull down to a low percentage. You should do that before you send your troopers, otherwhise you will fail. It's very important to destroy the ship's jumpdrive first, when you attac. Ships can be repaired by their engineer during a fight. It is slow, of cause, but you should be aware of it, as the jumpdive or the engines could start working again after you destroyed them. Trading There is not much to say about trading. You can buy ships that can transport huge amounts of wares. You can add those ships to your fleet, but you don't have to. You got two menus to manage your trading actions. The standard trading menu will show you all the offers and demands and you can figure out what would be a good deal. That can be profitable, but it takes time to find good deals. But you got a second menu where you get the best deals in a list and you can see what the profit will be. So you simply click on one of the deals and it will add the buy and sell operation to the ship's trading queue. Ships can only queue up 3 operations ( buy or sell ) at once when you start the game. But you can buy software upgrades for your computer to make more operations available.Another layer of trading is the item trade system. Items are things you have in your player's inventory. Those can be looted when you enter a station, or you can find boxes of loot with you scanners all over the universe. You can sell them or craft with them. Crafting There are a variaty of items you can craft in your inventory from items you looted. Some of them are items that can be gifted to NPC's during a smalltalk to get special offers from them. But you can also craft a unique engine and spectial items that are needed to hack into stations. Hacking You can hack into the computers of any station in X Rebirth in order to sabotage the station. I will not describe all the things you can achieve by hacking, but let me tell you that it can be very profitable. You will need to practice it a bit though, it's not simple. Review I tried to cover as much as I could, probably in too much detail. I reached max characters in this review and I didn't even cover station building, which should be in this list.Is it a good game after all? Yes it is. It is a universe full of enemies, missions, and opportunities. It has flaws, of cause. Every game has flaws. But none of them break the game for me.

number of helpful: 57 of 78 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Simply put, this game is incredibly badly designed. The trailer and description of what the game is, are as accurate as Aliens: Colonial Marines was to it's demo, or possibly even far worse. Reading through the description of what the game is supposed to do is actually more fun than playing the game. You get more fun counting the lies and laughing about how absolutly untrue the description of the game is. It's like if someone runs up to you and starts telling blatently obvious lies, you smile and probably get a chuckle or two. That is at least enjoyable. This game is an anomaly in itself. It is broken to the core. It is actually designed wrong, and to work against itself. I have never in my life experienced anything as fustrating as this game, never. I don't think the developers even know what a video game is, seriously. The absolute basic "unwritten" standards of gaming do not exsist in this game. Simple things like telling the player what things are. Letting you know what to do. Things like pressing I for inventory, or, even the option to map it to a key (Inventory is not mapable to any keys!!!)No instructions or idea as to how to do things, it just tells you to do them. Many items in game have a description saying "no description". There is a limited 6 button radial in-game menu, where one option is next page..  and sometimes has 4 or so pages worth of options, on a 60+ button controller (The KEYBOARD!!!)Seven year development time.. What were they doing? Why aren't the most basic standards of gaming in here.Why did the game have game breaking bugs on mission 1 and 2. How did it get released? Did anyone even try to play the game first? Was there even 1 single game tester? In seven years of development, you never figured out that the first couple missions have game breaking bugs!?!?!?!?Horrible frame rate unless you own a low end - mid spec PC. That's right, the more powerful your computer / graphics cards are, the worse the game runs.. Wow. Like I said, this game is an anomaly.Stations are copied and pasted hundreds of times each, with a total variety of maybe 3 or 4 at most. Why not release an editor, and ask people to submit station designs, then you load them into the game for free. Name it after the creator. Why not? People will do it for free for you.Why are the developers so terrible at what they do? How is it possible. I know I will never ever buy another game before reading a review ever again. I will never buy a pre-order ever again, and I will never ever buy enything from Egosoft again.What an accurate name too, I bet their ego's are very soft after this absolute worthless unfinished joke of a "game" was released.Want a score? Out of ten? Ok,  give it 2 / 101 point for being at least somewhat nice looking1 point for future potential... (From the modding community, not the devs)

number of helpful: 68 of 97 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I own all of the X games. Rebirth was the most "attractive one" for me. New interface (let's face it, the old one was terrible -> keeping it complex doesn't mean that it should also be inaccessible), station interiors, a story line that will suck us in and so.Well, first of all, the cockpit design was good, at least as an idea. Being able to wander around in your ship is also good. As an idea.What Rebirth did wrong is that, all the ideas that would elevate the gameplay were implemented so bad that, they actually hurt the title.The interface causes more issues than fun. Yeah, every space sim fan loves to wander around in their ship, experiencing the roleplay of a space farer. However, when that cockpit causes you to loose your tradeships, fail your missions, limit you from using other angles to see your ship, etc. it becomes a burden. Come on, Privateer had multiple angles and camera views AND a cockpit view. A game that came out two decades ago!The story, it could've been interesting, even if being a total cliché. However, the voice acting KILLS the atmosphere. God, the voice acting is SO bad that, you will IMMEDIATELY want to turn the audio speech off. The dialogue scripts are also terrible. It is as if a kid wrote the whole script. You meet with the remnants of a long time enemy, in two sentences, you decide to help them fix their base. They are not surprised to see you, you are not surprised to see them etc.The interiors are all the same, with little to zero difference. The station dialogue stuff is basically trading menus while staring at an NPC, a very badly modeled one to be exact. The "dialogue like" menu is also completely useless. It looks like a pre-alpha stage Mass Effect dialogue tree used for a menu system.The co-pilot you get in game as a part of the story is also completely useless. Whenever you are occupied with something else, she just... well, she just "exists" that is all. No autopilot, no anything.The dialogues with other NPCs are also terrible.The only thing I liked about the game was the graphics. They weren't on today's high end standards and the game crashes or stalls more than a player can bear, but they were still good.However, gameplay elements of the game were poor at best in every sense and in every department that, it would be disrespectful to recommend this game as a part of a genre where you can find titles like Privateer, Freelancer (in all its flaws), IWar, DarkStar One (even that one is better) and worse, other X games. Heck, even playing back the very old classics like Elite would be much more fun, while you await for the upcoming Star Citizen and Elite 4 as a fan of the genre.I was really hopeful about this game, even pre-ordering it.Such a shame... So much potential down the drain.

number of helpful: 44 of 57 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
												X: Rebirth is a mixed bag, there were some major issues with the game at launch which is part of the reason I waited until later to purchase, that and all the negative reviews.  As it turns out the vast majority of the negative reviews are actually longtime franchise fans that didn't like the new game formula, X: Rebirth on it's own(now that most of the big bugs have been ironed out) is a pretty solid game.  I bought the game on sale, but if not for all the bad reviews I would have paid full price, the game is worth the $30 tag for sure.Good:  I'll be brief at first and go into details further down-Interiors for ships and stations add to the experience-Harpoints to target on ships/stations to take out weapons, engines, etc.-Nice variety of stations-Plenty of side missions to do-Complex enough design to allow more options, simple enough that you only need a couple "how to" videos to learn everything-Crew: nice to be able to feel like you're working with people-Ability to "command" your fleetBad:-Interiors aren't that flushed out-AI pathing and behavior-System to increase Crew members' skills is extremely repetitive-Complex enough that the game doesn't necessarily show you how to do everything-Unable to pilot other ships besides SKUNK-Fleet commands are extremely limitedMORE DETAILS:Interiors - This feature makes it into both the good and bad category, and for good reason.  The addition of interiors to an X Universe game is huge and can be quite enjoyable to those looking for a bit more out of their game.  Being able to look around the inside of your ship(s) along with the inside of stations you visit can allow a player to immerse themselves into the game more easily.  This feature could have been one of the shining examples of the new direction for X: Rebirth, but the development fell short.  While it was a great step in the right direction, it seems the developers wanted to force you to visit these interiors whether you liked it or not.  Patches since launch have allowed much of the "on-station" tasks to be performed while in the sector instead but at launch you were forced to go onto stations just to recruit new crew members, which is a pretty huge part of the game in X: Rebirth.Ways to Improve:- Take away requirements to visit stations that are repetitive- Add actual vendor stores instead of random people standing around the station- Addition of "Recruiters" which will track down the crew you needI will add more to this later when I have more time, all in all there are definitely some glaring issues with X: Rebirth but I feel it was a risk worth taking for Egosoft and I hope to see them continue with the concepts explored in this game, even it not for the "main" iterations to the series.  The game has a ton to do and will be able to keep you busy for hours if you like building a trade empire.  The story has a decent build up but then just falls apart at the end and feels like it was rushed.  I wouldn't put the main story into either bad or good because it functions great as a tutorial and is fairly rewarding, but the ending could have been much bettter.

number of helpful: 265 of 429 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Updated to include 3.0 changes.Most reported bugs from the good old days are now corrected.  Game is 100% playable.  With 3.0 new content was added to include a new race, new ships, new sectors, new missions and new features.  After a very bumpy start Rebirth has pushed beyond what people were promised and have entered into something new and improved.  While some people still complain about lag and there are cases where lag does in fact take things down a notch for the most part people are getting beyond playable rates.  You will never get 120 fps but most of the people I talk to as well as myself are getting in the 40s.I'll not give away any story details because I hate when people do that but it's an interesting addition.  If you own the game there is no reason not to try it again.  If you don't own the game you can get an enjoyable experience as a good price so give it a try.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------Updates up to and including Version 2.0 corrected the majority of the launch bugs and added a lot of requested features.  The game is fully playable and depending on what you are looking for can give you hours and hours of fun.Also with 2.10 (In Beta) there is a native 64bit executable which should address some of the resource issues.One thing to remember is that X games tend to take a while before they get to a state where people love them.X3 had a bad start and really didn't shine until version 2.5 yet now it's one of the greatest space sims out there.There is a lot of bad threads in the forums and Egosoft did earn a lot of hate from the poor release. however they have spent the last 6 months fixing things as fast as they can and adding requested items as fast as they can.  There is still work to be done and we hope that within a few months they will move from a bug fix mode to a new content mode.That being said, remember when reading reviews, a person's opinion really only matters if you are that person.  I like the game, I have since launch.  There are a lot of people that do not like that game.  A lot of that is related in the core gameplay.  It's different then X3 and a lot of people do not like that.If you are looking for a X3 clone with some new flashy graphics this isn't your game.You'll also note that alot of the reviews were done 6 months ago and do not reflect any patches or the 2.0 update.Updated on 5/29 to reflect 2.10 changes.  2.10(still in RC stage) introduces a native 64bit executable.

												I can finally recommend this game. The Devs have done a lot of hard work to fix many things, and it shows. Many people I have spoken with believe the game has gone from a 1/10 to a 7/10 and counting. The great thing about egosoft is they don't release a game and then forget about it. I feel like X-R at release was simply the release of a foundation/framework that was meant to be built upon over time, both by the devs and the modding community. This turned many people off because they expected a completed game with every single bell and whistle they desired. Those bells and whistles were not in at release, but they are here now. They have added very nice UI improvements and quality of life features.The mod authors have filled in the gaps with afew nice things, but I wouldn't be surprised if the devs added them to vanilla.All in all I am excited for the future of the game! I am actually having fun this time around.

number of helpful: 49 of 67 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												I have clocked in thousands of hours in the X series, all the way from X2 to X3AP. So believe me when I say I could not be more disappointed with how X-R came to be. 7 years in development, when in reality it was 7 years of Console development, a failed pitch to Microsoft, and a quick cash grab to recoup the costs of their monumentally dumbed down game.From design decisions based on programmer's personal beliefs (no automation, jump drives, SETA, mind numbingly boring minigames), to decisions that simply boggle the mind (no cancelling of trade orders, your ship carries no cargo, you personally have to drive around and order your ships to trade, literally nothing in the game is 2 button presses to issue an order)Sure, the space cities look damn pretty. From the outside. Because they had to be, because to even interract with one of these gorgeous space cities, you have to scour the entire external surface with a fine-toothed comb to even dock. And when you do, you'll wish you hadn't. X-R features the most hideous, badly rigged and designed character models I have literally ever seen. The models in X2, a game over 10 years old, looked better. Between that and the mandatory hunting of arbitrary pilots to pilot your ships *for* you (because you will never leave the Skunk for something better), the disgusting 'find the crates' minigame, and the heavily Consolized conversation wheels, you'd wished you stayed outside, and wonder how this ever because a feature.Next we have the Universe. Something that the X series is pretty well known for; it's huge, sprawling universe that you are but one speck of. Well good look seeing the universe, because the new map system is taken out of a preschoolers scribble book. Not that you would even need a map, because there are only 4 regions to explore. Admittedly, they are divided up into 5 sectors, dozens of zones and plenty more inbetween, but cmon. X3AP had 213 individual sectors, and there was more life in the empty sector of Maelstrom in X3 than there is in 90% of the zones in X-R. There simply is no life. Lots of show and distractions, but peek behind the curtain and you realize that all the NPC ships around you only exist when you're there. Ships in space highways literally do not exist outside of those highways. The flowing traffick that weaves through space cities? Completely arbitrary ships with 1hp that have no repercussions for you shooting 10,000 of them. I literally cannot recommend this game to anyone on the reasoning that Egosoft has patently *lied* about the kind of game Rebirth was going to be. "Less complicated, but the same complexity. Complexity is good, complicated is bad" keeps being one of the biggest phrases attributed to this game, but it simply is not true. The 'new and better, more intuitive' UI is literally light years behind the UI in X3, and that is seriously saying something.Please, do not buy this game. Give the money to a charity. It'll serve more good there.

number of helpful: 74 of 110 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												--This recommendation had to be trimmed to meet Steam's character limit.--http://steamcommunity.com/app/2870/discussions/0/648811852568427989/X Rebirth is a strange game.  In an effort to try to be more friendly to newer players and stem the complexity of commanding your fleets, they’ve pushed the menus towards an even more difficult mess.Instead of having a point-and-click interface, time was spent in generating a main menu that uses a radial design[...] The downside is that while the design works alright for the controller, it caused keyboard inputs to suffer. [...]Trading seems to be tuned for some interesting changes.  For “bulk orders” you don’t order a ship to a station, [...] you enter into buying and selling agreements with a station that you assign to a capital ship on your behalf. [...]The downside is that with this method, trading is slow and prone to failure, with what appears to be a fairly critical bug if the ship can’t complete the trade. In this case [...]your ship is stuck with these goods permanently. Hopefully we will see this resolved soon.[...]While on a station, you’re given the opportunity to take everything that isn’t nailed down. While the game seems to acknowledge the strange behavior in the form of the main character Ren Otani asking his companion “What’s wrong with you?” as a direct response to her suggestion that you steal everything, nobody else will seem to mind. [...]One interesting thing that I’d like to see explored further later on is the use of officers for capital ships. While you are limited to one ship, the Albion Skunk (complete with anthropomorphic suggestive hull paint and all), you can gather a fleet of capital ships and smaller ships. In order to have them operate correctly, you must hire a captain (for capital ships) along with support crew like a defense officer or engineer, or a pilot (for smaller ships) and assign them to their craft. This is a little tedious[...].  With that said, this gives a little bit of an RPG mechanic as the characters you are hiring have different skill levels that will ultimately affect the effectiveness of your fleets and also gives a little more personal approach to fleet management.Visually the game is stunning. Space tends to be extremely busy around stations and it doesn’t have a problem showing you that. Egosoft mentioned that each ship was supposed to be important, representing a functioning piece of the economy, but it seems that a smaller vessels around stations (that may represent civilian traffic) don’t really have a purpose as they just circle the stations endlessly. [...]The voice acting is pretty disappointing. While I’m not one to expect anything stellar from Egosoft seeing as how the studio is based in Germany, the stark difference between previous games and X Rebirth is there. It doesn’t help that they managed to get someone that sounds more variable in tone and a native English speaker to play Ren Otani, while your companion falls in line with what sounds like a script reading. Previous X-games were consistent in voice talent quality, X Rebirth isn’t which makes it worse. Repeating lines are a common problem too. While on station you will hear anyone and everyone mention at least five times that they are amazed that the inter-station highway, used for fast travel between sectors of space, wasn’t present 40 years ago. It doesn’t help that in some cases you’ll have a chance to talk up people you want to do business with that will also have Ren Otani spout off how it’s amazing the highways weren’t present 40 years ago as well.For all it’s faults and all it’s problems, X Rebirth has a decent game to play once it’s chiseled free from what is marring it. [...]While I am writing this recommendation, I only do so as a service to friends and readers. Buy the game if you’re wanting to get a look at it, just expect it to be a little rough until Egosoft has made it’s sweep on trying to clean it up. Otherwise hold off for a little until after.
