content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												X:Rebirth is a fascinating mess.  I did not play the game at release or anything near to it, so my review is in regards to the game circa early 2015.  X:Rebirth is a many-headed hydra, where each head does not fit well with the others.  Presumably to reduce the reliance on menu's seen in previous X games, X:Rebirth features a 'walking in stations' system.  At no point does anything you do while walking in stations add anything other than a terribly looking character to your game experience.  As soon as you figure out how to do the same thing via menus, you will.  It is faster and more aesthetically pleasing.The core of the game is an economic empire simulator with the player as a trader CEO who for some reason also engages in combat and exploration.  All of this is accomplished from one ship that has a paltry number of upgrades that only require vast wealth to acquire.  The control of underlings is accomplished through a terribly poorly designed ui that requires repetition of multiple clickthroughs to achieve even the most simple of tasks.  Reassign a fighter from one wing to another? Requires comms to the pilot, choose how to assign them, pick their new superior, and then you are actually forced to wait while their confirmation dialogue plays.  All this could be accomplished through a single drag-drop, but not in X:Rebirth.The space part of the game looks great even without mods, but most of your time is necessarily spent flying around stations.  Although the stations have a wonderful diversity compared to say Elite:Dangerous, no one really wants to spend hours and hours flying around them.  Yet you must in order to discover trade opportunities, missions, and the discounts that make trade profitable.  Even with a fair amount of modding to reduce the tedium of things like scouting stations, I still found myself bored and frustrated by ~70% of the campaign.  I also ran into a game breaking bug that apparently others have not experienced involving a full stop in campaign progress due to a missing NPC.  I had kept hoping that at some point the tedious exploration, lackluster combat (I think 90% of my missiles missed no matter the type I used) and poorly voice acted story would evolve into a fun trade empire simulation, but, for me, it never happened.Even at a reduced sale price, it is hard to justify the purchase of X:Rebirth unless you give Egosoft a lot of credit for aspirations rather than accomplishments.

number of helpful: 25 of 36 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												I've had a long relationship with this game.  I played it when it launched, and hated it.  I played it around v2.5, and was frustrated with it.  But finally, at v4.0, the game is...  Competent.So, how can I put this?  X Rebirth in its 4.0 state is like a roughly-cut imperfect diamond; it's got a lot of facets but none of them shine as brightly as they could.  All of the aspects of the game do come together to create a compelling experience, but its not without some slight frustration and disappointment.The game prides itself upon the facets of TRADE, FIGHT, BUILD, THINK, so let's break it down that way.TRADE is much more involved versus prior X games, keeping the player engaged with their trade ships, a change I rather like.  You have to find trade offers and send orders to your ships to execute the trades through a manual process.  This is made easier through the acquisition of Trade Agents, who will keep you up to date on current prices on individual stations.  The game provides a handy interface for quickly finding and executing those exceptional deals, once your catalog of stations is large enough.Despite all the updates, the interface is still your greatest enemy when trading.  The game is asking you to get your hands-dirty with micro-management while providing you an interface that just barely makes it possible.  Wares are given top-billing with stations being sorted by wares, and while this is what you want 90% of the time, there is that 10% where you might want to see wares sorted by station.  This is not a possible way to search, however.Other small aggrevations, like the routes traders may decide to take, like through unexplored sectors with angry cap-ships blowing up anything that moves, means that you'll encounter frustration from time-to-time as a trader.FIGHT has also been improved.  Rare is the time I see ships attacking space stations by rubbing their nose cone against its hull!  (It still happens though...  Shameful...)  Dog-fighting is an identical experience no matter what faction or ship you're engaged in.  All AI ships fly out a ways, come screaming in guns a-blazing (almost always out-of-formation), usually collide with you, and then go flying off to repeat it, cork-screwing if you happen to be shooting at them.  Even the tankier ships with terrible maneuverability, like the Xenon P, will do this despite being ill-suited to it.Almost all capital ships are completely defenseless versus a meticulously-controlled Skunk.  Your little ship, once upgraded, can execute surgical attacks, hanging out in blind spots and picking off systems, breaking the legs of even the largest, most fearsome ships.  Many cap-ships provide perfect little hiding spots for you to even recharge your shields hidden away from enemy fighters (looking at you Xenon I, the most "fearsome" ship in the game).  It just seems kind of weird that capital ships have no defense against this.  At least make it so the Skunk's shields can't recharge while in an enemy cap-ship's area of influence!  Come on!Finally, fleet-actions are left entirely to the AI, which we've already seen, is pretty dumb.  You can hang out on the deck of one of your cap-ships while it blows things up.  You can tell it what to focus attention on but cannot take direct control or even provide strategic guidance, RTS-style.  Just kick back and hope your ship's AI doesn't do anything completely asinine.Suffice it to say, combat feels like one of the shallower aspects that X Rebirth offers.  Smarter, ship-class-based combat AI would go a long ways toward bringing this up to par.BUILD, on the other hand, is one of the game's stronger offerings.  Station construction and management is straight-forward, the offerings of stations are diverse, and a lot of leeway is given to the order that construction will occur.  You can prioritize getting one ware producing before another.  Stations are being handled better than they ever have been in previous X games.There is very little to complain about when it comes to building stations and your influence on the economy.  The campaign tutorialization left out some important information (that the list of stations that can be built is based on the faction that built the constructor ship; screw you DeVries!) and I wish station traders could leave the system to obtain resources, but these are pretty small complaints.  X Rebirth did pretty allright here!THINK is a little vague, in concept, but I'll assume it's about integration: pulling all the other facets together to advance in the game.  This is where the compelling experience I talked about comes through.  The games gives so many tools to exploit in so many ways, one play-through can be entirely unlike another.In building your trade empire, you may want to obtain a small military to protect your ships in contested areas.Maybe you want to train the toughest marines and sac cap-ships to resell for massive profits.Be a cut-throat and pirate the cargo of one faction to sell it to another!Literally, you can do ALL these things as the opportunities merit, and many more things I haven't even mentioned yet, like hacking space stations!  This is where the true meat of the game comes from and why you will spend dozens of hours in this game.  It's just that you will often find yourself wishing for small changes to make the overall experience even better.  You'll wish that last fight was a little more challenging, or that the trading was a little more streamlined, or that the small-talk mini-game would just go off and die already.The small-talk minigame is honestly the worst part of this game.  Let's just end on that.

												This is a review of version 4.0.I am not an old vet of the X series. I discovered this franchise with X3.  Immediately after launching X3, I was hooked by his universe, gameplay , possibilities .... everything to be honest. So when X rebirth got released, I bought it immediately and faced ... a huge disappointment. I simply could not stand the game, after trying for 10 hours, I just gave up.Time passed, several updates were released and I launched the game again for The Teladi Outpost update.  I thought at this time '' we are on the right path but we are not there yet '', so I quit the game and waited.4.0 is released, and I said okay now is the time, I am going to give X rebirth , one last chance.So after 22 hours played on 4.0, I can finally say it '' We are there finaly !!!!'' After more than 2 years and the product is finally finished and enjoyable.Egosoft took their time but they fixed all big issues, they listen to the community and adapt their game.It is still very different from X3 but it s an amazing Space Sim, probably one of the best with Elite: Dangerous, in my opinion.My advise :-If you own the game :  install and try it again.- if you don't own the game but like Space Sim :  Try the Free demo, I am sure you will like it.- If you don't like Space Sim : I really don't know why you read this review.See you pilots and enjoy .

One thing I haven't seen in other reviews is that you are limited to using one weapon at a time - at least I coouldn't find a way to fire multiple guns at the same time. The other thing is that the menus are not as 'snappy' as they were in say X3. Once you knew the keyboard shortcuts in previous X games you could get to any function pretty fast. In this game after quickly pressing 'Enter -> 5 -> 5' it only recognizes the first '5' keypress and I have to wait for the game to finish rendering the new radial menu before I can press the second '5'. Makes for a lot more sluggish interface.The rest of the problems (trading, highways, station interiors, etc.) have been already detailed in other reviews so I won't duplicate those.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												This is Mount and Blade in space.  If you're sick of empty "sand box" games like Far Cry, Fallout 4 or Elite Dangerous (so glad I bought this and not Elite Dangerous,) this is your game.  You are one tiny ship in a giant galaxy of space stations, capital ships, freighters and stellar phenomenon.  You can be a pirate, smuggler, trader, police officer, bounty hunter or eventually, shipping magnate and fleet commander.  As is the case in a real sand box game, you're thrown into a well-thought out, functional world and you do whatever you feel like.  Apparently the game sucked when it came out (all that's fixed) and franchise loyalists don't like some of the decisions the developers made.  I didn't play it three years ago and I've never even heard of the franchise before; as someone with no previous bias towards this game I HIGHLY suggest it.  Oh and the dogfighting is a blast.  The world they've created is so awesome, I almost forgot to mention how great the combat is.Conclusion: Forget Elite Dangerous; this is the sand box space sim where stuff actually happens.

The release version is a disaster, filled with many bugs and design issues, that neither satisfies veteran fans nor newcomers. Avoid until these are fixed.

Posted: November 14, 2015
												Initially I preordered this game and when it came out I was hugely disapointed by it. I've not touched it since except for today when I looked at some of the videos posted of the game. Having reinstalled and played it again I can see a massive improvement in many areas. This game is now holding my attention and I want to play it.Just to make it clear this is not an X3 sequel, its only slightly similar in some aspects. I still crave for a proper "X4" type game which this certainly isn't.The game is far from what I hoped it would be but with some mods installed the game is improved beyond its original state at launch. For example there is a simple mod which removes the cockpit so you get a decent view of the space in front of you.I recommend to anyone thinking of trying it to watch videos on Youtube etc. It helps to understand some of the basics as this game is still not right without some configuration but its now perfectly possible to change some of the most irritating parts making the game much more enjoyable.If you are a X series fan then its probably one to avoid because you can't help but make unfavourable comparisons. If however you're able to conceptually separate this game from the X series then its not too bad. I guess in the end I bought it expecting something else but over the years I've come to terms with the fact that this game is never going to be what I thought it should be.I still hope one day for a proper X3 sequel...

Posted: December 18, 2015
												I have owned this game from its initial release which anyone who picked it up back then knows it wasn't as expected and was a very embarrassing release for Egosoft. Having now played this for over 300 hours I feel this is a good time to leave a fair review. As mentioned the game was unplayable on its release and got slammed but credit to the devs as there have been a ton of patches, hot fiixes and updates. Also a DLC in the form of the Teladi Outpost, with a further one planned Feb 16 - Home of light. It's because of this support to the community that I would say this as a good game, it has plenty to do, a beautiful universe to explore, campaign mode and free play modes also structured start modes such as pirate, trader. Etc.. There are a ton of mods available from the very clever people in the community which make it even more playable. If anyone held back based on early reviews of the game I would say give a go it's very playable now, unfortunately the early reviews of this game still give it such a bad name on steam and it would be good to see some of the people who left those reviews at the time perhaps update them (if they still play the game that is, as I know most of them got refunded and don't own it anymore)! Anyways hope this helped anybody on the fence about giving it a shot. Catch you all on the other side!

												The weapon system and overall combat was waaaaaayyyyy better in x3 terran conflict.  If this were reverted to the old system I would probably change my review to positive. The fact that you are essentially wed to one ship (the albion skunk) is perhaps its second biggest downfall as I feel as though there are far fewer ship types and therefore play styles available.  Oh also SETA drive (speeding time up by up to 10x should never have been removed)Terran Conflict was a better game except for the graphics and rebirth has a (minorly) improved fleet control system.   Also perhaps a slightly more engaging storyline. I do enjoy the improved stations a bit (the only real gameplay innovation and improvement.)Overall: Get x3 Terran conflict, its better.Edit:So they have put back in seta, which helps, but I still think x3 is a better game because you are not (effectively) tied to one ship, and I like the weapon system far better.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												While the game was absolutely terrible and broken when it got released a long time ago, Egosoft did a really good job of improving the game in many aspects, improving the interface and adding completely new features to the game. I also enjoy the DLCs quite alot (only one is shown in the shop so far, but another one is coming, which is even more worth purchasing).To be frank, the campaign story is kind of meh, especially the last mission, but the story was (except for the very first X-title X-Beyond the frontier) never a focus point of the games.As a fan since the beginning of the series, i hated the new highway system in the beginning because i thought making the warp gates more rare and instead focussing on highways was a betrayal to the series, especially since i did not care about the Albion sectors in the X3-series. But after a while i must say that i love the new highway system, its a great way to enjoy the scenery and to take a short break while flying from sector to sector.It also has great mod support, a really nice mod community and a really great community overall.And i must emphasize, unlike many developers who have a bad/broken launch and just abandon the game, Egosoft is known for supporting and improving the game even years after it's initizal release, and while almost every title in the X-series was incredibly broken at launch (hence the many bad reviews) Egosoft always did their best to improve the game to make their games great, even if it takes many years of (usually) free updates and patches.The only huge gripe i have with this game is it's over-complicated and over-complex menu/sub-menu system to do simple things. But after a while you get used to it.Unpatched on release it was garbage, over time it became acceptable, now i think it's a nice addition to the X-series and i'm always eagerly waiting for Egosoft to put in new updates.Is it perfect? By all means no. Is it enjoyable? In my opinion yes (why else would i play it over 500 hours?), as long as you don't have problems with fiddling around with menus.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												X: Rebirth, a game at launch that suffered terribly and seemed in many peoples eye the deathknell of the X Series. When it first released, Rebirth copped a lot of deserved flak, it was buggy, it was confusing and many of us were questionable about particular game elements. But that was a different time for Rebirth, and it has improved significantly since that time with its 2.0, 3.0 and soon to be released 4.0 and Home of Light DLC. Kudos to Egosoft to sticking to their guns where most developers would sink the franchise and move on.What stands out in Rebirth compared to other space sims of the day? It has incredibly deep gameplay in an incredibly beautiful and dynamic universe. There is a satisfying early, mid and late game as you gradually build up an empire of ships and stations and dominate interstellar markets with your own assembly lines and your fleet of trade-ships. You will always be up to something in Rebirth, whether thats scouting out potential bargains for your tradeships to supervising the construction of your first station or commanding your personal battlefleet into a war against one of the major factions. You can even be a pirate and steal wares and ships from any of the factions in the game. Every Star system in Rebirth is very unique, offering its own visual style, ship and station types (mostly), story and culture. Where other space-sim games like to go the procedural generation route, Rebirth offers a beautifully handcrafted galaxy that on the most part seems authentic.Rebirth still has its fair share of issues, the command system when dealing with NPCs can be frustrating at times and fleet commands still aren't that great, though it has improved substantially with adding basic commands that are necessary. NPCs are still stiff and bland and don't match the visual style of the outer galaxy, this was an issue with previous X games as well but its more jarring here as you are forced to interact with these NPCs more.Overall, if you like base-building, economic games, space-sim games, i'd definitely recommend X:Rebirth. With the Home of Light DLC coming out in the next few days which adds 3 new star systems (There are currently 6 systems pre-HoL ) it may be a good time to pick it up and give it a go.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												Not everyone's cup of tea, not for the faint-hearted or impatient, not for those who can't move on from X3!This game has come a long way since release with a ton of bug fixes, feature improvements and slowly but surely a growing mod community.  Some of the fundamental design changes since the X3 games still haunt it - smalltalk is dull and irritating, customisation options are dumbed down, single ship, badly voiced and poorly scripted lifeless NPCs, slow slow slow progress.....But - it's addictive and what does work generally works well - it looks beautiful on a decent rig, flight paths are very realistic, scale is huge.Overall, I'd give it 7 out of 10 as of v3.50 but you can see the potential here and hopefully things will get better and better as more content and features are added.

I will update my review later with any new thoughts (9/24/15).What I like about Rebirth:* Space flight and combat* Potential to build stations/personal empireWhat I hate about Rebirth:* Highways* Boring fps style stations* hiring/recruiting/managing crew

number of helpful: 15 of 19 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												X: Rebirth is definitely a unique entry in the space-sim genre and the game's universe is very sophisticated if you take the time to notice it. For newcomers to the X series the amount of depth may overwhelm you at first, but this game is probably the most user friendly out of all the X games.At first, I was somewhat of a newcomer to this game since I'd only played X3: Terran Conflict / Albion Prelude for couple of hours. After learning the basics, I came to love that there's so much to do in this game compared to most open world games. You can trade, explore, dogfight, and eventually manage an empire if you invest the time. You may start with just one ship, but a few hours later you could be managing dozens, then a few hours more you could be building stations, and then those stations could start managing even more ships.One of the most interesting aspects of the game is that almost everything happens in real time. When you order one of your ships to trade with a station, it will actually fly there and line up with the trading port. Then dozens of cargo drones will fly back and forth carrying the wares between the station and that ship. When you buy a capital ship from a shipyard, you can see it being built in real time by the shipyard's team of construction drones. If you're a veteran of the series you might be a little disappointed since this is not simply a new iteration of X3: Terran Conflict / Albion Prelude. However, if you give the game a chance you may appreciate its new direction for the X series while channeling the roots of X: Beyond the Frontier. There are some limitations such as only piloting one ship, but overall the game offers many new features and maintains the depth of gameplay from previous games without a needlessly complex interface.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												I don't really get all the bad press on X Rebirth. There are definitely some serious flaws in the game but there is still alot to like about it and I wouls still recommend it, although with only about 18 hours in the pilots seat, I still have allot to investigate and try. Here's my opinion about what is good and bad about X Rebirth, not that my opinion matters...Good:-Awesome graphics. The game looks amazing and runs perfectly smooth on my system (i7 4970 @ 3.6ghz, GTX770, 16gb DDR3).-Lots of huge and wildly varied space stations and other vehicles to see.-Really cool Bladerunner/Fifth Element kind of atmosphere.-You can actually dock at the stations and get up and walk around the ship and into the station.-The "highways" and "super highways" IMHO are kind of a cool way to get around systems.-I have found ship to ship combat to be great fun in XR.-The "flight" controls, for me, are about as close to perfect as they can be. I use a G940 stick/pedals/throttle in a fighter jet sort of arangement except for the addition of strafing controls assigned to a little mini x/y axis hat. IMHO thia is an ideal setup for the way I like to "fly".-No fuel issues!!! In other space sims it seems like I am always about to run outta gas. Not an issue in XR.-The navigator argues with the ships computer.Bad:-Extremely limited systems and sectors. The XR universe, although quite varied and beautiful, feels very small compared to other space sims. I have an XR "galaxy" map and there aren't but maybe half a dozen systems on it. News flash! The 'verse is a whole lot bigger than that!-The system and sector maps just plane suck in XR. That's all I need to say about that.-I rarely ever have time to play multiplayer anything so it isn't that big of a deal to me, but no multiplayer at all? Really?-Only one ship with a really stupid name that cannot be changed. Although you can own other ships, you cannot pilot them although I have heard there are "bridge" mods so you can sort of "be there" on the bigger ships.-My trackIR 5 won't work in XR.-You can get off your ship and walk around the stations but all the stations and people are very generic and look alike. -No standard FTL/jumpdrive.-An FTL/Jumpdrive can be found now, thanks to the version 4.0/HoL update, but it isn't something you can just buy and install. Apparently there is some sort of quest for this experimental drive that has you trekking all over the galaxy, such as it is, looking for parts and pieces.-Did I mention that the system/sector maps really suck?-The navigator is always arguing with the ships computer. There may seem like more bad than good, but other than two or three of those issues, they are mostly just personal preference. There is still allot to like about XR and I definitely enjoy playing it.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												Don't listen to the non-fanboys.  This is a true spacegame.  It has a few flaws, but what game doesn't?  Tetris; that's it.If you want to play a scripted, repetitive game, play Elite Dangerous.  That game even lets you put on your boosters to your next waypoint, so that you can go do the laundry, dishes, and prepare dinner before you arrive at the destination.  Truly Immersive.This game provides freedom, environments with different asthetics, and Workshop mods.  It is obvious that the developers tried to make this an AI social experiment with you thrown in the middle of it.You don't compete with anyone but your own ambition--so, wait for a sale.

												I'm new to the  X series and I have no expectations related to the previous games, that being said I like the game, it has an actual campaign and shows you how to actually play the game instead of just thrustng you into space with no context of who you are, why you are there and what you need to do. I understand the game was released with a lot of bugs, but apparently they have cleaned up a lot of them and the mod community has made the game even better. Definately worth a look especially for the ten dollar holiday sale. I prefer this game over the much harder learning curve of games like Elite Dangerous also it's nice to get in a space sim that has aliens.

number of helpful: 25 of 38 people (66%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												I waited actual years to buy this. I liked the first games, but was wary because of all the really horrible complaints made about it when it first debuted. So, I waited until it was on an unbeatable sale and picked it up. I still got robbed. Don't spend anything on this at all.I have now played more than enough hours to satisfy that stupid fanboy insistence that, "You must play lots and lots of hours before you are authorized to comment on this game." After many many hours, the word still is: to say that Egosoft is phoning it would be an insult to everyone that ever put forth sufficient effort to phone it in.Take all the good things about every other X game and throw it out. Sew the remnants together with used fishing line and bolster it with old carpet tacks. That is X Rebirth.Controls: 1 out of 5. Imagine Wing Commander 1 with half of the keys randomly not working. That would be a better control system than X Rebirth.AI: 1 out of 5. Nothing that it does makes any sense. The enemies are simply out to kill you for no apparent reason. Why do they hate you? Because(TM). Are they pirates? No, because pirates are trying to steal stuff to salvage it. These guys just kill you. Even if they have other enemies in zone that are more dangerous and/or more lucrative, they will always beeline to you to kill you. Because. Your ships... wow, don't even get me started. Whatever is the stupidest thing to do, they will probably do that. Otherwise, they'll do something else just so to keep their stupidity from becoming predictable.Graphics: 3 out of 5. The load times and pauses are not worth it. There is one female model and one male model, but with different (and progressively worse) hairstyles and clothing. It's like watching Frozen for the ten thousandth time, only without any of the fun. Or decent acting.Vocie actors: 1 out of 5. The main actor is "eh". Almost everyone else is so bad that it would be a crime against humanity if someone didn't parody it. They're not quite screwed up enough to reach Zero Wing status. It's clear that they just found random people that don't speak English to just give a go at whatever words were on the page. They didn't even bother to do a second take to clear up usage of the wrong word. The inflections are erratic... not in a cool way like G Man from Half Life, but more in a, "My sister said she'd beat me up if I didn't do this, but she's not checking up on me so I'm just going to get through it as fast as possible" way.Storyline: eh out of 5. Who can even tell if the story line is any good? I'd rather watch Star Wars Episode I.Bugs: Every so often, Egosoft releases another bug pack under the guise of some big patch. For every thing that they fix, five more things are broken. I don't believe that they want X Rebirth to be playable.Protect your sanity! Save yourself! STOP at Terran Conflict!

number of helpful: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Do not be drawn away by then 'mostly negitive'. This game had a bad release...very bad in fact. But guess what, Egosoft dosen't abandon it's children. No, they stay and rebuild, and what they have made out of it is worthy of the price tag.Honestly there are a few things to note.1: It's X:Rebirth, and removes a lot of ship controling and other features since X-3. It's more liken to the older X-Beyond the Frontier, in which you only owned one ship to fly, and upgraded it to suit your needs. X:Rebirth has attempted to bring back that feeling.2: They tried something new and it didn't turn out right. Honestly I hate when these games come out and everyone bashes them for being 'off target' from it's origenal. Do you seriously expect a game to sell if it's just a copy each time and no risks are taken? It dosen't work that way. Even Nintendo, the big daddy of video games, has experimented and gotten smashed. Paper Mario Sticker Star for example... The fact is, you can't judge a game completely on it's predisesor, as everyone is diffrent, the new game that comes will also change.So the game it's self visualy is breath taking. Giant super structure stations, wonderful space backgrounds, massive fire fights. The AI is also nice (But it's definatly not AGI) they can do some weird things, but are there to bring the automatic ecodemy and atmosphere of thousands to life. Gameplay can be rather dull at times, scaning stations, trading long distence with radios, running around on stations for offers and hidden godies. However, once you get an empire going you have meny things to do. The X series is a trading simulator in space with combat. Not a go shootem all up (that is until rather angry AGI and aliens attack.) My personal experience with the game is good. I've experienced very little problems other then a few scan points being inside the super structures (which you can glitch in and out of if you bounce around enough on it.) I recomend it for X series fans or someone who likes this type of game, but don't take this as the X series greatest impression. Play X-3 and it's expantions to get the full idea of how it works in good practice.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
BEST X-Game EVERX: Rebirth is, for me, the VERY BEST GAME Egosoft have ever released, by a HUGE margin!To put that in context, I'm a LONG time X-phile, having played every game since the very first release: X: Beyond The Frontier (1999). While I've enjoyed each iteration in the series, there have been many things I found frustrating and, ultimately, after Albion Prelude (2011) I decided I'd had more than enough of being punished for my dreams: I vowed never to buy another Egosoft game.Earlier games were massive time sinks, Pretty and often fun, but requiring weeks if not months of REAL TIME graft to get to the big ticket rewards like capital ships and fleet battles. There was also an inordinate amount of tedious repetition involved in trading between sectors and stations. Worse, items always cost so damned much. New guns for your ship? That'll be hours of monotonous trading, please. New ship? Come back in a week!At their worst, earlier X games felt exactly like that real life job we are supposed to be gaming to escape from.  Dull, monotonous and frequently punishing. Some like that: for me, it was torture having the dream of a space game so close but unable to achieve it thanks to some obstinate design decisions. Because I love space games, and because Egosoft were producing the ONLY A-grade space games out there for the longest time, I held out like a battered husband, hoping things would eventually improve.X Rebirth is that game. The improvement I'd always hoped would happen.It had a very rough start. Egosoft should not, under any circumstances, have released the game in the state they did. By all accounts it was buggy and broken, on top of being a severe departure from earlier games. Not having bought it I sat back and laughed at my bullet-dodging cleverness.However, a couple of years later, after huge amounts of polish, tweaks and additions by Egosoft, Rebirth is now an absolute gem! A sparkling diamond in place of 1.0's jagged black coal. I've been playing it non-stop since I bought it. I can't stop playing it. This redesigned universe just makes so much more sense than it ever did. Activites make more sense, feel more logical. The graphical improvements are enormous, and a joy to behold (the stations are breathtaking!), but it's the gameplay that now really shines. So much opportunity everywhere! Missions that finally pay out decent rewards! Items priced low enough that a mission or two can afford them! I can repair my ships now without spending a week trading to offset the cost!I love this game!Yes, there are still wonky bits. The narrative is compelling but awkwardly told. NPC modelling and animation rarely looks right. Voice acting is average at best, ear-destroying at worst. The menu-driven UI can still be a bit fiddly. And there's so much to [re]learn. But these are now minor complaints considering the rest of the game design now offers so much fun.I heartily recommed buying X: Rebirth at the earliest opportunity!

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												With the Rebirth 4.0 Update, I went ahead and bought the Home of Light DLC -because you deserve money for not tossing the game out and actually making it better (3.0)-, and then started a whole new game.I didn't actually pay attention to the 4.0 Patchlog, and completely forgot that I'd never seen Trade Deals and Mission lists in X Rebirth before, as well as the awesomely awesome tickboxes in property list. I didn't actually notice that I'd played from morning to morning until I got a surprisingly beneficial CTD (you should stop playing and go to bed now).This is completely and utterly playable and worth the NZ$48, and a must-buy at NZ$12 Sale. Haven't actually bothered leaving Omicron Lyrae yet, let alone newly explored the six or so other systems.Only issues are the mind-numbingly boring small-talk to get trade updates in every station because it is the most important thing ever (fixed by an auto-mod!) and the -graphics related (AMD?)- crashes and visual glitches, which aren't that bad if you keep autosave on. Also having to manually sell (or wait for someone to buy) your station wares; kind of wish managers used tradeships to sell as well as buy instead of just letting them wander around aimlessly until they need to buy something.I'm looking forward to XR:2.

content:
Posted: January 20
												First off I Pre-orderded this game and have been messing with it since the beginning. Let me say that when we first played this game it would crash and crash and you get it. But now Egosoft has worked their asses off and have really fixed this game. This is a different type of X universe game compared to X2 and 3. The biggest difference you will notice is that you run in the same ship from the beginning to the end but you upgrade the weps and shields and engines and computers etc as you go. The controls are now very intuitive and easy to learn. The acting is a bit on the low end but the graphics and views of space are spectacular. There can be some issues regarding AI but for the most part just cancel the orders and reissue them seems to resolve the issues.Please give it a try and dont count the reviews from launch against it. Egosoft was true to their word and really did a good job making this game both playable and enjoyable.

												If you've been following the release of this game, you may remember how disastrous, buggy, and unfinished the initial product was.  Egosoft has done a great job fixing the game up and making it playable.  There are still some missing features, but overall the game itself is great.  If you've never played a game from the X series (and even if you have) there's a good chance you'll probably like this game.  However, I cannot personally recommend it.  Whenever I play this game, it feels like something is missing.  The game lacks... a heart and soul, especially when you compare it to its most recent predecessors, X3:Terran Conflict and the expansion X3:Albion Prelude.  Patches are still being released for this game, so if something changes, I'll reconsider my review, but for now... I'd say buy something else.

												Love the game, sunk hundreds of hours into the game. with the addition of mods and lots of ships, the game fufills the desire to stand aboard your capital ship and pummel the enemy to dust.On the negetive side, once the campain is complete, fleet is assembled, there really is no drive for establishing stations and trade.Late Game BoringThough i love the X series and X Rebirth, i think the game needs a better "End Game:" there begins to be nothing for you to do when you have a massive fleet , stable trade, and tons of money. there is no diplomacy, fleet upkeep, and most of all variety of ships.    -Diplomacy would make you feel like you are a real faction when you are growing yore empire    -Fleet upkeep, whether that would be more pay for crew, or licenses to hold that many ships until you have an empire, would make reaching a stale state much harder    -The ship variety is only a personal point, i make it a point to collect all ships, and when you have a bunch that have a very similar artistic style, it gets a bit boring.    -smaller factions and engagements would add some dimension to the game.     -the game seems a bit small. compared to say X3 ( which you cant escape) you were in a small fighter and a large world, where you are in the equivalent of a well equipped Katina which could be the goal for the next X game.All in all love the games and sunk thousands of hours into them and i respect you as game Devs.

number of helpful: 32 of 52 people (62%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												X Rebirth is a reboot of the previous X Series games. I first got into the X Series back in X2: The Threat. Being able to command big capital ships was something that was a very memorable experience. Trying to get into big fleet battles was interesting. You had the whole universe of hundreds of systems to play in and play with which is the best part of any X Series game. X Rebirth was something of a disaster, especially at launch. Many of the bugs were fixed with upcoming updates for X Rebirth but the gameplay and the Freedom that was once there is no more. You no longer have the freedom to fly other small ships or “Captain” Capital Ships in any way or form. You can “Own” many ships but cannot “Fly” any ship. You are locked to a ship named “Albion Skunk”,♥♥♥♥♥♥poor name in my opinion, and are limited in not only a dozen weapons.There are only, currently I believe 4 or 5 systems vs the Hundreds of systems previously accessible in the other X Series games. Would rather have hundreds of systems to explore rather than 4 or 5 with smaller sub areas you can visit. X Rebirth, has certainly improved somewhat in combat and most certainly graphically from its predecessors. There are many new gameplay mechanics, such as the Space Highway System, Bigger Space Stations with multiple dock locations and areas to explore. However, many interiors are identical to one another, faces on all characters are all nearly the same and various other small things just almost don’t make it worth your time to dock and talk to people. There have been many improvements since Launch, and some great content has been added. But the freedom to do what you want, that made the other X Games so successful, is no longer there. To summarize this all up without going into a 5 page essay as to why this game is a disaster, I would NOT recommend buying the game unless you got money to blow.

number of helpful: 160 of 290 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												This game is currently beta-quality, and it has many, sometimes game-breaking, bugs. If bugs and performance issues turn you off, then you should not consider purchasing this game for at least a few weeks. However, this is NOT an abandoned title. The developers are keen on fixing these bugs, and they release regular weekly updates which do improve the game.If you are coming from older X-titles, then you probably expect more of the same. While many things were carried over from the older games, X Rebirth is very different in many respects (for better or worse):GOOD (non-exhaustive list):• The universe feels more alive than in previous X-titles.• The space-flight visuals are often cinematic, reminiscent of sequences from movies like Blade Runner and The Fifth Element.• Fewer loading screens. Similar to other open world games, such as Skyrim, or GTA, you can travel vast distances without encountering a loading screen. The highways, for instance, will save you hours of travel, but you are also free to travel outside of them if you wish.• Capital ships appear much more massive than in the prior X-titles. Dock with one of these ships and walk around on its platform in the middle of a heated battle, and you will feel very small.• I have not finished the campaign, admittedly due to bugs, but so far I do enjoy it more than the campaigns in prior X-titles.SORTA-GOOD, SORTA-BAD (non-exhaustive):• You may only fly one ship. Some people will enjoy the fact that the game has been balanced around the abilities of a single playable ship. Others, especially veterans of the prior X games, may miss the freedom to choose what to fly.• SETA is gone, replaced by a more immersive system of highways which connect zones together, offering fast (yet still interactive) travel between them. Without SETA, unfortunately, some players will grow impatient as their trade ships lumber toward their destinations.• You may now walk around inside stations. There is a lot of potential for gameplay-depth here, but the feature is currently not very engaging and appears unfinished.BAD (non-exhaustive):• Trades are tedious. Expect to babysit each of your trade ships. Automation made trading tolerable for me in the prior X-titles, but this feature doesn't seem to exist in X Rebirth. Not yet, anyway.• The NPC models are ugly. I don’t know whether it’s the artificial gravity, or the lack of a proper atmosphere, but human skin apparently doesn’t hold up well in space — expect to either laugh or cringe at the organic sights that await you on space stations and capital ships.• Stations, although populated with NPCs, feel mostly lifeless. NPCs sit, stand, or weld metal objects, but rarely do anything else — they do not interact with each other, nor do they walk around with any purpose whatsoever. This aspect of the game needs a lot of improvement.CONCLUSION:X Rebirth is an incredibly ambitious game, and when it works it delivers an experience you won’t find anywhere else. At times the game is frustrating, but the developer is working hard to address the issues. I recommend this game to enthusiasts of the space genre who do not mind paying full-price for a game that is still beta-quality.

number of helpful: 16 of 23 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												I can't recommend this game, even though I'm probably one of the most patient guys, when it comes to bugs and slow grinding, micromanage demanding games. The release version was awful, the campaign completely broken and unplayable and the framerate unacceptable. I have an iCore5 Haswell  CPU with 8GB of gaming RAM and an ATI 7700 Series graphics cards. I could barely muster 15 frame per second, which made me feel like being in the 90s, the only kid stuck with an 5 year old Pentium and can't play any latest games. This is not the case here. I can't actually find a game, that would bring my computer down so much. Not even Crysis 3. And Rebirth isn't even that great looking to begin with.As of this review, the game is patched to 1.21 and the framerate has improved and some bugs have been corrected.  Regardless of patches, there are much much deeper problems with this game. I doubt they ever gonna be fixed, since they are "features". Appearantly, the dev team thought, that everyone wants to navigate a space trading/fighting simulator with an XBOX controller, where there are multiple menus and submenus and sub-sub-sub menus to deal with, instead of giving a simple keyboard shortcut. Appearantly, they forgot, that PC games have 101 keys + at least 3 mouse buttons. I won't even mention people, who got joysticks. Here is an awful example to compare: Battlefield or Call of Duty both are heavily console-aimed (now), and yet I got shortcut keys for everything, even joystick support for flight.  And we are talking about a simple shooter on a comparabily small map to play on, unlike Rebirth, which has numerous sectors, zones, systems and stations. I could go on with the menu system starmap, which I have never even heard of.  Dumb down games like Mass Effect has a starmap for crying out loud, even though the space part of game is just some visual  addition, not really required. Here is the deal.   You may have fun looking at the space stations and flying around for a bit. Heck...you may even have some fun successfully trading or pirating a freighter from the enemy faction.  But I can almost guarantee, that this game will go stale on you, once you realize , that after the first space station built with tremendous amount of work to be done, you'll be doing the same thing for the rest of the time you play. It's not getting easier, it's not getting harder, because you could have billions of credits if the raw materials needed are not there, or you have to travel for 1 hour all around in the sectors to find a cargo freighter carrying the right stuff. By the time you get to that cargo ship, you'll realize, that your traders are stuck somewhere or being destroyed, without your knowledge,  or your trading computer "forgot" where things are bought and sold and the sectors you have already scanned are showing up again as unscanned. You are going to get sick of this game real fast and only the most patient will go ahead to continue for a while, possibly install 10s or 20s of mods just to get by or constantly edit his save file to make it someone bearable. Avoid it...wait for some great space games coming out next  year (Elite: Dangerous, Star Citizen), which are already probably in a better state as alphas, than this "release" version of a giant mess called Rebirth.

number of helpful: 17 of 25 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												The game had potential, but at this point in time I wouldn't waste the money on it there are other games that will work far better as a trading/space sim. Go back to X3 Terran Conflict and Albion Prelude if you want a enjoyable experience.Sadly as many people expected there are to many bugs and design flaws for this game to be truly enjoyable. The one truly good point about this game is the developers did spend a large amount of time making it stunning visually. The depth of a planet you get close to the stars within the game all the lighting and particle effects are top notch, but the good news stops there.Unlike the other games in the x series you are limited to one ship with the ability to use drones. The drones themselves have various uses but in the end seem superficial compared to being able to pilot full fighters. The worst part about this feature is your ship many times will get completely destroyed as you try and use the drones even when there was no threats present.In addition to this the so call "reactive/interactive economy" is anything but either. Most of the ships in game are fluff as bots that have no purpose other than to make the space ports and space station's look busy. The ships you can interact with seem to randomly disappear after leaving/docking with stations or ships on some occasion's. its disappointing that such a huge part of the prior X games is regulated to a unusable mess.Everything within the game from getting your other ships to do as you want to trading bulk items #i.e. energy cells and such# is nothing but a complicated chore that ruins any hope of you having fun or at least feeling like you accomplishing something. In addition to this many of the in game commands and the very ships which made up such a big part of the other X games will not respond, move, or work in any way no matter what you need them to do. The ability to move around stations is a bit fun but ultimately pointless. It seems the real reason you go from station to station is to rob the lockers of items and get illegal items in air ducts to supplement your cash flow as you cant get anything else within the game to work for making money properly. Though there are workarounds for these issues you should not need them as you spent money on a game that should of been ready after 7 years.Lastly we have combat something truly enjoyable within the prior X series. Its sad, boring, dull, uninspired, slow. If you though you would have fun  think again. As stated before you only have one ship. Wanted tons of turrets? Think again. Wanted to be able to use 8 front mounted plasma throwers? Not gonna happen. You can have one of each weapon but that's ONE only. There are no multiple banks of weapons on your ship and no way to add them. The customization you can do to the ship is very shallow when compared to the other games within this series.The final verdict is i would hope and try to believe that this game will be fixed by the developers. If not them than the gaming community at large through many mods that defined other games in this series. Alas i cannot see this happening as most of the issues seem to stem from core portions of this game not something that can be modded or fixed without major changes to the game it self. We will just have to wait for the next true X series game or perhaps the new Star Citizen that seems to have allot of promise.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												The game really needed an additional year in the oven before releasing. What Egosoft was thinking when they released it in 2013 is beyond me. At its launch, the game was terrible. Barely anything worked, game breaking bugs were everywhere, it felt more like an alpha test for the game than anything else and because of that it suffered. I decided back then that I wouldn't give it a review due to the sour taste it left in my mouth and just put it on the backburner for 3 years. Yea ... 3 years. When I saw the 4.0 update I decided that it was time I gave the game another chance, a lot of people were praising it since the Teladi Outpost DLC for beginning to show its colors as an X game.All the bugs that existed since launch have been fixed, I've managed to complete the campaign without hitting any kind of issue. The story has its ups and down, but in my opinion its final act and ending are not what I expected and somewhat unimpressive. The good part about it is that it leaves you wanting more.The gameplay is what you'd expect from an X game. You start with a ship, some credits and your personal skills. What you do from there (if you don't start with the campaign) its up to you. Either go the route of a pirate and harrass the NPCs till the dawn of time, take on missions that are either combat, trading or exploring, go out on an exploration trip to find rare materials that can sell for a high price or maybe even some derelict ships you can capture or just build up an empire and slowly conquer the galaxy. Yep, just like an X game. Now there is one thing I need to mention. What is a very big different between this X game and previous titles is that you cannot fly more than 1 ship. You better get used to the Albion (Pride) Skunk because that's the ship you'll fly till the dawn of time. And yes, you can reconfigure your cockpit so you can have a difference look about your ship, but honestly, its still just one ship. Right now, the game is worth buying. If you can overlook some minor gripes like the 1 ship only thing, then the game is very enjoyable. Especially the empire building aspect of it.

number of helpful: 25 of 40 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												First things to know:-I started playing at version 3.20-I know it had a bad launch-It is not X4That being said, it is a great game!Like I said, I have not experienced the game-breaking bugs that most player experienced at launch.Egosoft really worked hard to make this game better, and are still releasing patches to fix/add/polish content.I remember playing X3: Reunion years ago. It has tons of problems, but they fixed them in later patches. Then Terran Conflict came out: very similar to Reunion but way better. So I knew that a bad launch was not going to be a problem in the long run.I understand the frustration of early buyers and fans, but now it is a great game.You still see on forums the usual "is the game still broken?" posts. To those people I say: it is perfectly playable.I had one crash to desktop, but it was my fault (alt-tabing during screen-resolution changes on a dual-monitor setup, the game did not like it).I run the game at maxed out graphs, on a 1920x1080 resolution: no slow-downs in fps.So here are my pros and cons:Pros:+Beautiful game+Nice micromanaging+Lots of options to choose from+Great gameplay (altho different from other games in the series, again: not X4)+Constant improvements from the dev team (thanks!)+Good music & sound effectsCons:-Repetitive dialogs-Some few-years-ago character models-The interface needs a little getting used toSo for all space-sim fans out there: I recommend the game. If you read reviews of the game, be sure to note that old ones might be from older states of the game, which was indeed bad, so for those who never played the game, at version 3.20 (3.50 soon!): it is a good time to start. And for those who bought the game when it was bad: now is time to give it another try!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												False advertising at its most blatant - "easier than ever to start with, and remains as deep as fans expect". Sure, space looks pretty, but there's a whole lot of ugly under the hood. The interface is stunningly broken (made for controllers, at the expense of the traditional and most effective flight sim control scheme on PC - joystick/mouse/keyboard), the AI is atrociously poorly implemented (won't follow orders, there are many orders you *can't* give, such as meaningful fleet control or automated trading by stations or ships), the setting is far smaller than previous games in the series (and the map is utterly useless), every station is identical or nearly so (down to the "hidden loot items" being in the same place in each).If you believe the marketing, if you expect this to be anything like previous X games, prepare to be sorely disappointed. There's a reason the Metacritic score for this game isn't shown on the Steam store page for it.

number of helpful: 20 of 31 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Edit: The below was written at the time of the initial release, and I gotta hand it to egosoft; they never game up on this game and they've done a massive number of fixes, feature adds/changes and content updates. The game was released with version 1.0 and at the time of this edit it is v2.50 - with a v3.0 on the way for December 2014. A lot has changed, and I personally haven't tested the game since. Added that they offered an upcoming DLC free for those that already have the game, it seems Egosoft is trying hard to make up for the launch mess. So there is yet hope that this review might turn into a thumbs up soon.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------If you're a fan of the serries like I am, there is one word to describe this latest installment: disappointment. The game launched with more bugs than it has features. Added to these bugs are performance issues - but what is really disturbing with this latter is why it's there to begin with: The game is built on directx 9,  and a quick look into the config files, etc shows XBOX 360 commands all around.Yes, the best way to explain why this game turns out to be so disappointing can simply be understood from that: it's a revamped down X game made having consoles in mind. The menus and controls reflect this (seriously, you don't even have keyboard shortcuts for targetting) and it takes out most of what made the X series what they were.But it doesn't end there. You pilot one ship throughout the game (yes, only one) and if you have additional ships in your fleet, they can't even be in a different sector than you. So long for massive space empires. Given the AI is next to nothing, these ships stand and look pretty most of the time instead of firing their turrets or trading.Ah yes, trading. Gone are the days you could dock at a station and trade directly. You have to assign a frigate you can't pilot yourself to do that and wait half and hour for it to dock and do it (you don't have seta). So when the lack of AI and major bugs get in the way, you curse having lost that half an hour and start editing the save file just for the game to keep running on.Well, you would expect dogfights to be good since you have one ship - it would be optimized you'd think. No chance. Dogfights are sitting duck shoots whether you're fighting a cap ship or a small fighter. Again, it's an AI problem.The big thing with this X game that we all were excited about was to walk around stations ... guess, how it turned out? Yes. a disaster. All stations have almost the same interior where all walking around adds to the game is to open crates and get minor items. All these crates look the same and you wouldn't wanna do that all the time, trust me. Except, you have to; you can't disable it. Even if you wanted to talk with someone at the station, you have to dock and open some crates and walk around and open some crates and finally find the person to buy a ship upgrade (if you're lucky and it doesn't bug that is).Granted, the X games were always launched as a mess - and tidied up later on. But this is not the kind of mess that can be tidied up - neither by egosoft nor the modding community. The basic motto is not there: trade, fight, build, think? Can't properly trade, no challenge in fighting can't build wherever I want and all it makes me think about is what good I can write for the game in this review (without any success).I've already written long and haven't yet touched some major problems (NPCs, highways, etc). I won't either. I believe you got my point. This game is released as an unfinished mess, but even if it is patched up in the near future, what we'll have is not an X game that we were expecting. The biggest sandbox in the X universe? No it's not. That's an outright false statement.

number of helpful: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												An unfortunate disappointment.Broken & Buggy:While some elements have been streamlined and are more fun than previous entries in the franchise (combat, maneuvering, traveling), the amount of commonly reproduced game-breaking bugs stop that. Launch bugs are to be expected, but this is equivalent to an early beta/access game - which this is not identified as. Required tutorial story line missions are stuck in a broken state that can't progress. Saving the game sometimes crashes and destroys progress. Basic issues that should have been caught haven't been - walk in front of a scripted robot cleaning the wall? Get pushed through the wall. Stand in front of a vent and open it? The grate lifts you, sticks you to the wall above it, and disables you from closing it. Sometimes, while looking at the ship's in-cockpit UI, the UI becomes non-interactive and can't be left.Awkward:Even for a game in the X franchise, this has the poorest usability of the series. Somehow, the focus on immersion lost out to having a decent, playable game. Having to wait for length animations for basic functionality that a player would do often adds to the tedium for the sake of immersion. Despite being in-space, navigation involves entering an animation where the character pushes back, rotates his seat, and waits for a display to activate. During this, the game world is active, so don't count on quickly breaking from navigation to defend your self. Accept a mission to pick up and transport a passenger? Dock and hoof it through repetitive hallways to that duplicated, shoddy model of the passenger, talk to them (without skipping dialogue), wait through their boarding cutscene, then hoof it or teleport to your ship. Want to ask an NPC for directions to a drone trader? Talk to them, press a dozen keys to navigate through multi-level, multi-paged sets of dialogue options in a Mass Effect style dialogue wheel, 6 at a time (4 + "More" + "Back"), until you find Drone Trader, so that NPCs can randomly decline to inform you *after* you've went through 20 - 30 seconds of this UI to hear a snide rejecting remark. The cut for entering the cockpit of your ship teleports from one side of the ship to the next with no fade - akward and unpolished. While entering the seat, the seat animation seems to be mirrored for your copilot so that she flails and rotates in an inhuman fashion. All of this you must bear each and every time you do so and there is no option to skip.Really wanted to love this - played previous entries in the franchise, played Eve-Online, played Freelancer, played Strike Suit Zero, supporting Star Citizen - but this is a very poor release and very, very poorly designed for any target audience. What would be immersive is just tedious, distracting, and counters any immersion with glaring flaws.

number of helpful: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												You are the pilot of the Albion Skunk, why is it called the Skunk? Quite frankly because it stinks, this game has tons of potential but so far isn't living up to it, if you are a fan of the X3 games for the sandbox style of play, give this game a wide berth for now until the modding community finishes what Egosoft started. As it stands, you can only pilot the Skunk which might be tolerable if it was a capital ship but no, it's a simple fighter. Also the menu systems bring you to a dead stop so issuing commands in battle may do more damage then it's worth. Drones can be controlled by the player, but what point is there in using drones when your ship sits still for the enemies? I mean, you have a co-pilot that won't actually co-pilot, all she will do is pretty much sit there as a conversation piece. To be honest, i miss my auto-pillock from X3, granted it would crash me into stations now and then, but atleast it MOVED MY SHIP instead of having me sit there doing NOTHING.Update: Auto-Pillock is back! and the first thing it did was slam me into the station i was undocking from... Artificial difficulty make this less of an actual space sim and more of an FPS. problems from my original review are still present. will do another update at 3.0 or when patching is dropped due to being unable to plug the dam with a finger.Update: New menu system WOO!!! Game is more tolerable now :D Can also purchase smaller ships so you don't need to keep hunting capital ship crews, Omicron Lyrae has the coolest looking small ships imo ^~^ Short update for now since 3.0 is around the corning, can't wait for the profit oppertunities <3Update: The new DLC didn't add much imo. Still don't recommend this game in it's current state.

												EDIT 28-08-16Below my 1st review. but after having checked SC and ED pages, i had to add these 2 lines. in opposition to what i first said during my first review, i have to say that Star citizen is not a fiction but definitely a reality, and a serious competitor to X-rebirth. same for Elite, i was first saying it was pretty pricey, but after having checked their page, i must admit that their prices have been seriously reduced. so these things taken apart, my review below is still validfirst review:Best sci-fi/space opera around+ amazing graphics+ enterable stations. you can go to the bar and talk with NPC+ ship customization+ trade. you can buy/sell almost anything. from vegetables to illegal waste. you can do it using your personal ship or using large cargos you add to kind. recon drones, electronic warfare drones, defense drones+ boarding. you need to send drones to hijack the target defense systems, then you need to destroy its jump engine, and then you send troops+ cash missions (passenger transport, cargo shipping, infrastructures destruction..)+ (obsolete) a reality not like Star citizen+ (obsolete) a one time purchase not like Elite D+ plenty of stuff number of helpful: 33 of 56 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												If you want a good space sim, where you get to do whatever you want in a vast universe... go buy X3: Albion Prelude, not this piece of junk.Even with all the patches and updates that this game has received, it has hardly improved at all. It is horribly optimized and very buggy, with many features poorly explained, explained incorrectly, or just not explained at all.The storyline is rushed and muddled, forcing the player through mind-numblingly boring missions, for factions  that you don't care about, with several jumps and gaps that made me feel like I was missing information. Even X3 had a better plot, and trust me, that's really saying something.Your companion is incredibly annoying, and frequently yells at your ship AI system for no reason, which is even more annoying than the ship AI itself.Speaking of your ship, it's a piece of garbage, and can for some strange reason only use one gun at any time, a monumental change to combat compared to all other X series games. You can upgrade some parts of your ship to make it slightly less garbage, but in general you'll wish you could take some other ships for a fly-out. But no, you're stuck in the Albion Skunk. To make a bad situation worse, if you want to capture a ship that someone else has bailed from, to add it to your squad, you need to have a spare pilot already on your ship. Apparently all these ships lost all that autonomous AI tech that was around 60 (in-universe) years ago.I can see where Egosoft was trying to go with this game, and I was willing to give them time to work on and improve this game, but now, after 2 expansions, 4 major versions, and 3 years, the game still has horrible UI, optimization, characters, cutscenes, dialogue, and interaction. Trading is a convoluted mess, combat is boring, exploration feels tedious, and in general, this is not a fun game to play.So, I urge you, go look for something else. There are some fantastic space sims out on the market now, or about to be released. If you don't have the budget for something triple-A, X3: Albion Prelude and X3: Terran Conflict are both far superior to this game, and often go on sale for under $10.

number of helpful: 17 of 26 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												Short review: If you really want to try this game, either (A) wait for a great sale (at least 1/2 off) or (B) buy X3 Terran Conflict and Albion Prelude. Long review: Simulation games, especially space simulators run a very tight rope. They must be open enough to allow the player to experience the universe, but structured and formatted well enough to ensure the experience is a fun and pleasant one. Anyone who has seen 2001: a Space Odyssey knows that simulating space exactly would be maddening, boring, and above all, not really a game. In the past, Egosoft has managed (with a great deal of modder and community help) to make an enjoyable space sim. They managed to balance the openness of the universe with (albeit a bit buggy) mechanics. Although the learning curve was steep, the rewards were worth it when you found yourself the ruler of an interstellar empire. For X rebirth, Egosoft decided to sprint full speed ahead, oblivious to that balancing act, and fell off that rope before it even managed a single step.Pros: (1) Graphics update, (2) Capital ships have subsystems you can target strategically, (3) Boarding and training marines are more straightforward, no more chasing marines in space or waiting for them to train. (4) I managed to finish a full length novel and download another on my kindle while waiting for things to happen.Cons: (1) You have 1 ship. Which wouldn't be bad if (A) you could actually customize it beyond 1 upgrade for each option, (B) you could actually customize the ship itself, beyond changing the glass layout in the cockpit, (C) your AI ships weren't braindead or hell, even (D) if you had a copilot that did more than argue with the computer and (2) almost half my total play time was spent wasting time doing NOTHING while I waited for (A) NPC trade runs to complete, (B) trading to complete, so that construction could continue to complete, (C) follow/escort missions to complete, (D) scripted events to start, (E) scripted events to complete, (F) NPCs talking to themselves, especially during D and E, (G) navigating menus while listening to NPCs flirt with me about their "wares". (I even managed to finish an entire novel in the time I was waiting! I kept it close by for these times)(3) The design, and trade menus are awkward to navigate, having been designed for xbox360. There is no depth in the commands, options, or details of the ships. It is nearly impossible to compare ships or their capabilities without using Roguey's site, and even then, there's no real reason to choose a different AI ship because (4) AI is terrible. Normally this would mean that your other ships were on equal footing. However, based on the design and lack of command options, your ships will not attack unless you yourself are attacked, or you navigate three menues to command them to attack a target chosen from the map screen while you are under fire. They also love to run right next to enemy ships (especially the capital ships) instead of using long range weaposn. (5) Repairing capital ships is a giant waste of time, and takes forever; repairing any non-capital ships is impossible without a mod. In other words, anything less than a capital ship is useless. (6) Everything requires an AI NPC, that you must carry around in the back of your ship to transport. Built a station? Needs a manager and a rare speciallist that you must find in a wild goose chase.  Just capped a ship? Better hope you already have a captain, defense officer, and engineer sitting behind you! While I get the idea that capital ships need officers, there is no way to have a "transport" ship keep these NPC's around for you. And god help you if there are no suitable candidates with the skills you need in nearby stations, or you've run out of space for freeloaders in the back. (7) NPC skills have no visible or explained effect. My 5 star all around captain/defense officer combo is equally as useless as my 1 star duo. On the same ship. In the same fight...(8) You must visit every station, constantly, in order to trade. Want to trade somewhere you already visited? TOO BAD! Since the two minutes you last docked there, the trade offer is gone. Note: the trade offer is still there, but you have to revisit to remember it is there!(9) Voice issues and translations: while I understand there are translational issues, a single english speaking person could have cleaned up 90% of the voice over issues. Heck, I might have preferred their native speakers to voice it, with subtitles, as opposed to hearing terribly performed, gramatically incorrect gibberish.(10) If there is a "story" in this game, it is hidden behind hours of waiting, incoherent english, bugs, and useless interface. (11) I'm pretty sure the game is about some guy named Ben who found a laser space skunk and trained it to fight "the man" (and then robots I think?) alongside a pair of breasts in a skintight suit with a strategic breast window. They are named Isha and Terran.

content:

												I don't know what to say. This game is more than just disappointing. It's a shame for the complete X-Series. I had lots of fun with the X-Games. I wanted some of those "new" Features so desperatly, and yet I am ashamed I ever bought the game. There is nothing X on this game. Everything that made the X-Series so great is gone now. You don't have Freedom in the game. I still can't use a Joystick. And even tough there were many "bug fixes", the game still plays ♥♥♥♥♥♥ like hell. The Graphics for Characters are worse than in any other X-Game. Up to now, I always thought that Mass Effect 3 was the worst Sequel I played. Now I gotta admit, that the worst game I played is X Rebirth. But hey, at least they got the title right. This really is a rebirth for the X-Series. A rebirth to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ness I am sad to ever have witnessed. A rebirth of a great PC-Title to a cheap console port. This game ain't worth the Money they want for it. It's definetly a "Don't Buy" game.
