number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												I initially wrote and posted this on the official forums and had around 140,000 views and 129 replies.  But here it is for those who missed it, and I still feel this way about it.X Rebirth - For Dummies ... LiterallyMy friends, developers, and our extremely tight nit community... boy where do I even start? I could start off with my prior X Series experience. I could start off with a rant. I could start off crying. I could start off being hopelessly optimistic. But the truth of the matter is, we are feeling all of those emotions. You took the X Series and made X Rebirth: For Dummies. Literally and figuratively. Only the dummies, still feel like dummies. You accomplished 2 things with the design changes: 1.) You attempted to dumb down the existing complexity, but instead you merely convoluted everything through a new cumbersome half baked console driven UI and interaction menu system. Things that you thought took "too much effort" to display or review before, take even longer now. 2.) You took a play right out of Apple's playbook, and flat REMOVED features because you knew best. What happened to all the key bindings? Too complicated, gone. Want to target the nearest hostile? Nope, you think gamepads are the future, no bindings for that. Want to quickly spot your proximity to others on the Gravidar? Nope, gone.. you need to fly aimlessly around stations scanning for anything relevant. Earth & Beyond I am totally surprised nobody has mentioned this one. Maybe this shows my age, but for those of you who don't know... there once existed (emphasis there) a game studio called Westwood. OH yes, many of you know it, and if you don't.. you should. They were hugely successful. They brought us the Dune Series, Command & Conquer, and then one day, they decided they would build a space MMO called Earth & Beyond. I subscribed, and I played it up until it flopped and failed miserably. I can't begin to tell you how similar it felt running around stations that were lifeless, only to interact with zombie NPCs who had nothing better to do but stand there. Things that could have been accomplished quicker from space and ship menus, HAD to be station oriented because "it was cool" and the developers believed in a fallacy that it's what gamers wanted. Yes, you hear players say this over and over, "Man someday it would be awesome if we could get out of our ships and walk around stations." Sounds good in theory, but has failed in practice, in every space game I have ever encountered, short of ONE game that was heavily story RPG oriented. Mass Effect. Do you know what happened to Westwood after their Earth & Beyond debacle? They closed their doors. The company liquidated. Yes, they aren't Egosoft. But Egosoft are not immune to these kinds of failings. And I can assure you, this has an eerie resemblance. Borderlands To make station visiting "worth" the time sink, Egosoft decided to put in "lootable" boxes or crates in the stations. It has a striking resemblance to wandering around a zone in Borderlands opening crate after crate to get loot, or more commonly, endless amounts of nickels and quarters. Freelancer Not to bash Microsoft, because Freelancer was actually a hugely successful game. The only problem here is, X has never been a Freelancer game. But for some odd reason, Egosoft decided to stick you in one ship and have you wander around the galaxy, bouncing from station to station doing missions and trade runs like this was "partially" a Freelancer game now. Where are the vast control for the 100's of TS/TP ships as Sector and Universe Traders going about their trade runs you meticulously configured? It's gone, except in the form of "Squads" where your "owned" ships follow you around the lagged Universe, hoping YOU might know where everybody is actually going. Oblivion For those who played Bethesda's Oblivion, you will remember the god awful NPC happiness system. You would spend stupid amounts of time flirting, threatening, or joking with NPC's for a little "kickback" on prices or information. Egosoft has tried this out with their "Small Talk" dialogue options on NPCs. Sounds interesting at first, but it becomes mindless drab and not only did players hate it, but Bethesda learned their lesson and removed it from their future games. Skyrim was a huge success, because not only did Bethesda go back to the drawing board, but they learned some valuable lessons and REMEMBERED them going forward. What exactly happened at Egosoft? The whole community already knows you learned valuable lessons, but it's like you came down with an epidemic of alzheimers when you worked for 7 years on Rebirth. X Rebirth: The True Problem We all know Egosoft has a stellar track record to listen to the community and patch games with a plethora of fixes and new content. This is undisputed by nearly everybody who has been here long enough. But you see, the problem with Rebirth is more severe than the typical game launch issues, bugs, performance problems, broken missions, etc. No, the problem with Rebirth is the inherent DESIGN. It's 7 year design. And yes, the modding community can do a LOT of things to improve games. Even change them to a certain degree. But I can assure you, as a full time software developer in both business and video games (and enthusiast modder for many games in my life) this one is very hard to fix, IF you are looking for classic X2/X3 game mechanics. Egosoft is faced with making drastic underlining design code changes to bring their community what it wants right now. I'm sorry, but that's just the reality of this situation right now. Graphics The graphics are actually very pretty. In space. I wont talk about the stations. But I do enjoy the overhaul to the station exteriors. The lighting and all the effects. While in space, it is definitely a sexy looking game. But that is all I can find, in me, that makes me want to play Rebirth. It's pretty when flying around in space. IN SPACE. Not wandering around cookie cutter stations like E&B. I like the sector/zone highways. And i'm still not sure what to think about the "Highway Leapfrog" mini-game that goes on when traveling through the highway system. In fact, I kind of hate looking straight up the tail pipe of other ships, crowding my already diminished view of space to make room for a beautiful cockpit which you can't even free-look. Again, not to be crass here... but as an experienced software engineer, hell even in space games as an Indie, I have to ask Egosoft, what exactly did you accomplish in 7 years? Best Regards, and good luck.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												You know when you create a new version of something it's usually to add to the good features of the previous ones and remove the bad bits?Well it looks like someone at Egosoft got a bit confused with that! from what i can tell they have added one good feature (ability to disable individual systems on large ships by careful aiming), however they have removed everything else that was good about X3! They have implemented some completely idiotic game mechanics, like the need to walk around spacestations to complete certain tasks (all of which look the same) or the stupid highway system, which not only is an annoying mini-game, it's also based around something that only works within an atmosphere with air resistance!you have no ability to look around in the cockpit (freelook) even though the cockpit seems to be fully 3d, you can only fly one ship, upgrading is♥♥♥♥♥♥ i wanted to keep this short so i'm not gonna keep listing the dumbass decisions they made!I've not even started on the bugs, yeah they have fixed a load of crashes, but what about the AI repeatedly flying straight into a satillite dish and bouncing around like fish in a tank.I don't understand how a company with such good titles like X2 and X3 can go so very wrong! they have both failed to satisfy fans and failed to make the game accessable to new players, Well done Egosoft!

number of helpful: 26 of 43 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												I bought into the hype pre-launch and thought the game would be fantastic. In the 7 hours I played the game hard crashed 6 times and I lost save data every time. To complete a tutorial mission I had to edit a game save file in notepad and put my mission state further ahead because of a bugged ship that got stuck. After I finally finished the tutorial I closed the game and never touched it again.The entire thing is optimized terribly and even in my high-end machine I could barely break 20FPS at the lowest possible settings. And I mean lowest. Don't be fooled by the screenshots on this store page. They don't reflect anything I ever saw with 12gb RAM, GTX 760 and a Core i7. It seems like when you walk around on foot the game is not only simulating, but rendering all of the activity outside of the station which causes it to run like complete trash even when you're standing still, doing nothing. Now they are rebranding as "X Rebirth 2.0" but don't be fooled, it's the same game with the same♥♥♥♥♥♥optimization. In the 7 months since launch they fixed a lot of the mission bugs and added the ability to not bother leaving your ship to go out on foot.  I think they also added some new cockpits and some different start conditions. But, maybe the worst part about the game is that even with all the bugs and optimization fixes, I don't think it was very good as a game... I only completed the tutorial so I don't have a great perspective but from what I played it was slow, clunky, and not fun. Cherry on top: The price of this game hasn't dropped a dime since release. They are still selling it for $50. This game is not worth $50. If I could get a refund I would. That 33/100 metacritic rating doesn't lie.

number of helpful: 18 of 28 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												*** U P D A T E *** 12th March 2015 - Got it again as a present. I tried it after 15 months from release and it's much much better.Graphic is cool and no fps issues for me in space. Stations are still horrible and boring. Mods help a bit (thanks, Modders). I still can't recommend it because of the lack of contents and monotony of the sidequests. Main quest is still bugged sometimes. The choice of having only one ship at all and few upgrades makes feel the game "smaller". It's not bad at all, cool graphic in space and some funny skirmishes, but i wouldn't feel that i lack something if it wasn't in my Steam library.27th nov, 2013 I got a refund on this game from Steam ... this can explain the status of the game, better than all the words of the world.26th nov, 2013 - Asked for a refund. That's just trash, letteraly burn 50€ can be more funny than this...Egosoft can't expect that "the community"(mods and so on) fixes their games. Absolutely bugged on release, even the TUTORIAL is broken(remember to save!!You'll have to reload many times hoping to find your personal way to avoid breaks).It's an xbox port(that never came out for xbox), and not a good one. Gameplay is boring. AI too. Ui is awful. Most of the spaceships that i encounter are simply "enviroment"..you can shot them and there is no reaction from them(only a voice that says you are losing faction points). Boarding an enemy ship is broken 50% of tries, at the moment. Trade is obscure by now, scavenging the space worths more. Main story is silly and secondary quests are repetitive. Raccomended only by/to fanboys. X3 TC - AP are better than this.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Turn, and run.  I played nearly all the predecessors from the series and, assuming this would be another iterative improvement with a new engine and better UI, got sucked into a pre-order.  This is not the X game you were looking for. It doesn't even seem to be an X game, just a console port that was never accepted for its console of choice, and so was sadly pushed into a PC launch wayyy before it was finished.  Ubiquitous bugs aside, the game just isn't done.  Maybe another year of development could have turned it into something special, but then it would have to compete with Elite and Star Citizen, something I sadly cannot see this game ever doing.  You can see what they were trying to do, but oh my did they miss the target, every time.  It just feels like a poorly implemented console game with none of the richness and depth that made the X series what it is (was).  Maybe in a year with a heap of community mods this will be worth 5 bucks on sale, but I hesitate to even hope that much.  You can get WIng Commander Privateer 2 on GOG for 5 bucks now.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												What can I say, I feel robbed. I pre-ordered this with such high hopes but what I got was an unfinished game at full retail price. This should have been in Early Access. Is there a stage of development that a game is in before Alpha? Whatever it is, that is where X Rebirth is at this point...unplayable! I don't think it will be done by summer of 2014, I have restarted so many times with each patch, and still get "stuck" somehow no matter which path I choose, campaign or free mode. And for the Developers to offer Beta testing after full release is a slap in the face. I'm so frustrated at this point, not too sure I will play it when it is playable, so I guess I made a donation to this title lol.Avoid this title at all costs.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												5/10If they made a good tutorial, it could be a cool game.If they used better graphics, it could be cool game.If they world didn't feel cold and impersonal, it could be a cool game.If they didn't make the management system clunker than a box of rocks, it could be a good game. It the game didn't freeze up and crash sometimes, it could be a cool game.If the game didn't feel overly complicated and confusing the first second you try to do something, it could be a cool game.If it were easy to navigate the world, it could be a cool game.Really, the only thing that was done right was the cockpit looks cool, the story seems interesting, and the world is very big.HOWEVER:They did just release version 2.0, and it looks to be very improved. Also after playing the game allot more, I've discovered it's actaully really cool if you can stick out the steep learning curve, and overly complicated systems. My only new criticism, is that they need to explain more things in game or make them simpler, and the story diffictulty needs to scale. 1.) It took me forever to figure out why I couldn't trade some cargo. Turns out, I didn't have a ship capable of tradding it. (It was canister type cargo, my ship could only hold bulk type cargo.)2.) I've gotten to a point in the story where I have to enguage in massive combat. I didn't know I needed to upgrade my ship, and now my sheilds are too weak, but I can't afford new sheidls, so back to attempting to trade.I still play this game, I still like it, but it has it's flaws.5/10

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												I understood prior to purchasing this game it was not going to be X3 TC/AP. I watched the trailers and thought it would be a very fun game to play with some new ideas and to possible take the game in a different direction. I do like playing space games, I have played EVE, Sins of a Solar Empire, Starpoint Gemini, Pax Imperia, Alpha Centauri, Galatic Civilizations, Star Wars MMO (Beta Tester), X3 TC/AP and I played some pay to play space game in the mid 90s but forgot the name and maybe a few others I have forgot to mention. Yes the game was bugged at launch, I could play the game at decent FPS but I experienced game breaking bugs so could not play. As of the latest patches 1 month into the game my FPS has tanked to the point of unplayable but a lot of the game breaking bugs were corrected.I gave the game 1 month and approximately 15 hours and will not be going back to the game. The design decisions that I thought would be great are for a lack of a better word horrible. I am either faced with game breaking bugs or horrible FPS.I am not recommending the game if you want a space game in anyway similar to a lot of space games out there. This one has taken the Space genre into a weird direction with basic functionality that is standard and decided to not put it in the game.To any thinking about purchasing this game during the Christmas season, please rethink the decision for at least another 11 months to give them a year.I will not ask or attempt a refund, I purchased the game and will live with the decision. In Novemeber of 2014 I will try the game again and will provide another review.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												While Egosoft is truly devoted to the genre and their past games have been great niche games (go check them out, buy the X Superbox), this time they took more risk than they could handle. Not only the engine has undergone dramatic changes, if not even being rewritten from scratch, the whole gameplay was redesigned and changed. This results in huge performance problems even half a year after release - and yes, still in version "2.0" - as well as tons of bugs and lack of polish. The game still feels like a beta version at best. The graphics are shiny (except for the NPCs, they're creepy old-people dolls with dead eyes), but on many systems you won't get even playable FPS. If you think your rig is top notch - this doesn't matter. Look at the forums.In terms of the gameplay, they have not yet reached the complexity of their older titles. Important features are currently missing, like the ability to create a closed ecosystem when you are building a complex of stations and want them to only buy from your own supply chain. The UI still is uncomfortable, but to be fair, the X games always had that problem.Personally, I had not much of possibility to play the game due to unplayable FPS. I am not sure if I like how they changed the universe to be much more dense and brought the action close to the stations. From what I have experienced, the universe feels too small for my taste. It's more like being in a giant space city, but the feeling of the vast space just doesn't appear. I think I would prefer a mix of the old X3 Reunion and Rebirth. Back to a sector based universe with lots of empty space to travel, but the stations as big and complex as in Rebirth. But I would leave out the NPC interactions. The idea of having to interact with NPCs to get tasks done might have good intentions, but it annoys me. Especially when they are as ugly and static as in X Rebirth. I prefer the good old ship computer and menus.So. Would I recommend it? Not in version 2.0. Maybe in version 3.0 or 4.0, what I want to say is: when they have fixed the game. Keep an eye on it, stay informed. Egosoft always has supported their games for an extraordinary long time. It surely is an interesting title, but it currently has way too many issues in performance, bugs and polish to recommend it. Go get the X Superbox and play the older titles, they are awesome space sandbox goodness.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												*Short Summary at the bottom*X Rebirth... there is so much to say about this game, nearly nothing nice to say though ( the fact that this game single handedly killed off the entire X community, should make it clearer just how much not nice is to say about this game ), sure, the game kinda looks nice, but that is also the best you can say about the game.the game is so full of bugs, that I had to use all 10 save files + quick saves to have any progress, because I kept breaking the game to the point where loading an earlier save was the only solution ( this happened extremely often ).I admit having my game save modified to get the required amount of money for the 1 Billion achievement, but only because of a magical money drain in the game that caused me to lose money constantly, seriously, 1 billion, gone in 2 days of not spending money ( never found out what did that ( the log over everything, had no info about any money being spent either ) ).The game is dumbed down and restricts you the entire way, even in the other game modes, you will never have anywhere near the freedom you had in the earlier games.Without any spoilers, the Champaign mode is broken on several levels, it ends in a way that makes you go: and what next.... wait... was that it..... I beat the story mode....... IT CAN'T END LIKE THIS!, this dosn't explain anything, none of this made sence..... there have to be more... right..... maybe there are some DLC comming that will complete the story, give some answers, make some sense of this.... at least a "complete" story... right?... NOPE!, no current announcements for DLC, not a single mention towards DLC, anywhere, at all...If you despite what I have said so far, still want to buy and play the game, be warned that you might not be able to, regardles of how much of a beast your PC is, you may run one of the worlds most advanced powerhouse PC's, and still not be able to run this game, due to bad programming. So buying it is a gamble in several ways, you may not even be able to launch it ( it ran in about a steady 30FPS for me from day 1, no clue why ), it may run, but at 2FPS, or it may run just fine at 30-60FPS, but you have no way of knowing before having bought the game.If you are a fan of the old X games and want to know what happened after the X3 games, you have my condolences, walk away, you never saw this, it ended with the X3 games, and that is all you honestly want to know.I think I have said all that I wanted to say, while staying as objective as I can, so for the short summary for those that didn't want to read all of this.*Summary*The game is a buggy abomination that is a waste of your time, money and potentially treasured memories of the earlier X games, and may not even be playable if you buy it.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Dreadful step backwards from X3, on which I logged many hours. Every aspect of the gameplay is dumbed down and noticebly worse, which makes this by far the most disappointing game I have ever purchased. The basic control scheme is poor, the UI is near impossible to use, the game chugs along even on high end systems, it crashes all the time, the character modelling is about ten years out of date, you're restricted to one ship, you can't even switch to an external view... the list is endless. To make matters worse - despite the UI being dumbed down it's massively more difficult and cumbersome to perform even the most basic trade tasks, which makes the game nigh on impossible to play if you can even get it started up at more than six fps in the first place. Avoid it.

												Yes, at the beginning the game was pretty terrible. I forgot it for more than 2 years. But given ES's history of fixing their games, I was pretty sure they will fix it. And they did. What I do not not understand is why to do such a horrible release in the first place?  And don't say to me is about money, because it isn't, or at least it should not be. Why? Because DeepSilver and ES new that they are releasing an incomplete product. That means they should be able to deduce that there will be no money in a long term as public ratings will not let sales to improve. So, what was the logic? I doubt that DeepSilver was out of money. I think DeepSilver was simply indifferent, maybe it was their way of saying "promises must be kept". But hell no. The one who says it, does not understands software industry and should not be in it as per se. You always, always plan for delays and set offs in such huge projects. Thats why DS does not even have any huge games except X series. They simply do not know to work with such projects.Quality means money and thats one thing they forgot. Now they are paying for missing it. There are other ways to fund such projects. Why not to use those? ES has a user base, has products, has a good history. Why not to use it?

number of helpful: 15 of 23 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												I've been a big fan of the series, logging hundreds of hours between X3 Reunion, X3 Terran Conflict, and Albion Prelude and am sorry to say that Rebirth is my biggest disappointment in recent memory. Three weeks after release and Egosoft has yet to provide a game which is either functional or optimized. Numerous bugs and poor graphical performance (even on high-end rigs) still plague the game. This may have been forgivable, but in the few hours I've been able to play, due to game breaking glitches, there isn't much to miss. The menu system is counter-intuitive and show none, I repeat NONE of the information I look to see on ships, stats, et cetera. The map system is an oddly unintelligible, two-dimensional take that is unhelpful. Moreover, the new highway system and removal of the autopilot feature from X3 makes navigation a committed and tedious process. In all of my save games, the trading is irrepairabily broken because trade ships wil not dock with stations to buy/sell goods, but this isn't a huge problem as it prevents me from continuing in the trite campaign missions (sarcasm). I can reconcile that with the tedium and obtuse nature of trade in this game. Unlike X3 where you could issue buy/sell orders to ships remotely without being near the station(s) where the orders were placed, X: Rebirth requires you to fly to each and every station to place each an every order in a system that is simply ludicrous. Overall, a HUGE step back in what was a fantastic series. Not only am I out $50 on this game, but I've lost all faith in future releases from the X series and Egosoft.

number of helpful: 16 of 25 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Bad news first;This was more of a letdown than Duke Nukem Forever.  I love the X series.  I've bought the games more than once.  This does not belong in the series.  The only controller that works right is the Xbox 360 controller, and the entire interface is made around being a console game.  The game only uses DirectX 9 (like Xbox 360), and the story line missions are buggy and you can get stuck and have to manually edit your gamesave in order to continue the game to fix things yourself.  This really feels like a failed console game that was ported to PC that was never supposed to be in the X universe.Industry standard controllers, like the Saitek X52, do not work.  The button mapping is buggy, as well.  It sees everything as an XBox 360 controller stick for some reason.  Also, it won't let you map more functions to a keyboard and mouse than you could to an XBox 360 controller.  This is a PC game that is constrained by a console controller's limitations.I'm still in the tutorial and it bugged out on me and stopped giving me any story missions or objectives about 10 minutes in.  Now I'm abandoned.The "universe" is tiny.  There's only one camera view for your ship and only one small ship to fly.  You will not be commanding a large capitol ship yourself into epic battles.There are maybe 10 different NPCs reused everywhere and only 3 different tiny interiors of space station ports.  Going inside of the space stations is obnoxiously painful, and the NPCs treat you rudely for no reason and repeat the same few phrases over and over.  It is also a pain to find the vendors you trade with and the interface to trade is awful.  It's just like a big F You when I am talking to every NPC to try to get the story to progress and trigger something, and they all end a conversation with something snarky like "Nice chat.  NOT!"  The economy is less advanced than current convenient stores.  It's seriously like each little port is a mostly empty farmer's market with a few NPCs that will trade with you, but you have to find them and sit through their insulting chat.There is a trading system you can do from your ship, but I cannot figure out for the life of me if I am buying or selling items and where they are going or where the money is going.  I don't know if I'm buying missles or selling them.  What is the difference between To Sales and To Offers?  I have no idea.  I think I accidentally sold all of my missles, which I thought were on my little ship, but maybe my large ship had them?  I couldn't figure it out at all.There is no radar for space battles.   No radar.  NO RADAR.  How do you dogfight with no radar to track enemies?  All you have is pointers around your view screen for directions.Oh yeah.  No targetting, either.The Good:The art design for the ships and exteriors of the space stations are amazing.  The art direction really is inspiringly beautiful in how they designed things.  You can get a sense for the purpose of various parts of stations and ships just by looking at them.  It is a joy to first explore them.  Even with only DirectX 9, they did an amazing job for how it looks when you fly around.  (the NPCs and interiors of stations are not that inspiring, though.  The NPCs are especially creepy with how their face pops onto your screen first, then body parts appear at different times and they materialize in front of you, due to pop in)The sound is nice.One thing the devs did is almost amazing enough to send them a thank you, though.  The save files are .xml files, which means they are human parsable ane plain text, so you can edit them pretty easily when you need to fix things... or give yourself tons of money, because the economy is so painfully implemented that it isn't worth the time to make money legitimately.  Why do I like this so much?  Because it is a single player game and people want to cheat or do fun things with a game to sandbox it when they want to.  Many people will install "trainers" that are loaded with malware in order to cheat, or install other cheat engine programs that will get you blocked by some online games just for being on your computer, or are also fillled with malware.It's time to bring cheats back to games.  ♥♥♥♥ acchievements and ♥♥♥♥ encrypted save files.  Thanks to the emphasis on acchievements in the game industry, debug modes and cheat codes have disappeared so that people don't cheat to get some virtual trophy.  The result is giant botnets of malware infested users sending spam, helping to DDoS, and make the internet a worse place, because they install some trainer and now their system is compromised.  Kudos to the devs for letting their users do what they want with their own single player games.What it would take for me to change my mind about this game;Revamp the interface to make sense for keyboard and mouse.  You can keep the console option for big screen mode people, but give us a choice.Fix joystick and key mapping support, especially for the X52, wink winkLet me map to more keys than an Xbox 360 controller can handle.Put in the traditional targetting and a radarRemove the interiors of space stations and just give me some giant landing bays that let me add a station to my trade network that I can access forever from my ship.  Look, right now, in real life, I can use this magical internet to buy or sell anything I want, and even more things that I don't want.  THE FUTURE WOULD HAVE SOMETHING BETTER.  STOP TURNING SPACE TRADING INTO FARMER'S MARKETS.  No one would do that with the technology available.  THIS MAKES NO SENSE.Fix the story mission bugsGive me fleet management tools that let me make decisions that don't ever involve flying to a ship to talk to someone in person.  I should never have to dock inside one of my ships unless I am delivering a physical person or object.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Don't let the bad reviews dating from launch fool you, X Rebirth as it is now in 3.6 is a very very good game. You still need to mod it to get the best out of it but everything is readily available in the steam workshop. Great game if you are into empire building. That feeling of taking on a small mission, not being able to cut it and just calling in a full capital fleet to wipe the map with the baddies, all the while watching the action unfold from the bridge of your flagship (Youll need to DL the mod for this) is pretty damn good. Complex economy is pretty fun too. Though I was clever and got one of my enemies to shoot at a neutral station. Well it worked and the station opened up on the capships following me, declaring war on my enemy by doing so, only this station was one of the few producing a very rare ware and with it's haulers now at war it could barely produce, spiking prices all over the galaxy -.- That being said, want to make a load of money and have fun with corporate espionnage? Go sabotage stations competing with you, lower your costs and pick up all your competition's clients while you're at it. Game has lots of depth if you want to play around with it.Severe shortage of guides and tutorials though, be patient and ask questions on steam discussions.

number of helpful: 16 of 25 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												An unfortunately incomplete game that doesn't live up to the expectations of the series.The game has relatively good graphics for a space game, but is highly unoptimised with frame rates coming out quite low.The gameplay has been somewhat limited compared to the previous games, with the player only able to pilot a single ship (though it is a flexible ship with plenty of capacity for modification). In an attempt to create more immersion within the game the player can now walk around inside the space stations, however this is very poorly done. The stations feel dead and empty. Their is very little personality, with the NPCs all being generic. There appears to still be the capacity to set up the same economic empires that were possible in the previous games.I think this game is not what it could have been, though I hope this is remedied in the future. Currently I would give it a miss and check out the earlier games in the series. Or check out the upcoming 'Star Citizen' (which isn't on Steam and is still in development).

												Having played one of the free weekends. I'm surprised that this game is voted at Mostly Negative. While I wasn't there to see the initial horribly broken release. Whatever post-launch version I was playing was enjoyable, immersive, and in a way outright addicting. Though, if you're expecting some Epic Story-Driven Saga like Mass Effect or something more combat-focused like Star Citizen, then this is not your cup of tea. This game is more akin to older space sim types that your basically a simple cog in the larger galactic economy machine, which makes it partially similar to Eve. So in essence it's more of you being a random person earning a living in space while slowly building your reputation like the other X games.The game does take some learning (took me like 3+ hours to finally figure out what's what), but after that it was pretty much sooth sailing

number of helpful: 17 of 27 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Note: I'm not counting bugs as apart of this review.Very upset to say, this game is not what I expected. Luckly I purchased this game at a much later date when it was being sold for 50% off. As much as I want to recommend a game that developers put a ton of time into, I just cannot do it with X rebirth.Here are the reasons why:1.) We'll start with the campaign; One thing I like about Syfi games is immersion. If you can make me feel like I'm in living breathing world with things to do at ever corner, you've done a good job. Now I must admit they almost had me but when I found out that NPC's in the game where not actually doing anything they're simply there for cosmetic purposes, that killed me.2.) Voice acting, simply put, if I wanted to go see or hear talentless actors, I'd watch Twilight. The voice acting is absolutly, (ABSOLUTLY) atrocious. Coupled with bad resolution NPC models which a player would easily see that they all look simlar to one another, like a universe with a obvious incest problem.    What I don't understand if you would go to the lengths to make the outer world beautiful, and unique. Why not apply that same work when you're inside the station walking around? Keep in mind AAA graphics is not the bread-and-butter of a game, but keeping graphics the consistant through out definitely helps.3.)  I've played the earlier installments of the 'X series' and enjoyed them very much, personally one of the things I enjoyed the most was being able to switch ships around for bigger and badder ones. Although piloting a ship is one-hundered times better in X Rebirth, you are limited to one ship. Many people will aurgue this, but point blank if you're going to compete with today's space sims this is a feature your game is going to need.The good:                1.) With all that said, the game does have it's good side. One, being piloting the ship and navagating through menus is awesome, takes some time to learn.                2.) The "outer world" (when you're flying in space, near station (ect...). Is beautiful! And very futuristic looking.               3.) The game does offer things to do being: Minging, Gas harvesting, Station building, Trading, and exploring.               4.) I'll give it to Egosoft, they know they fu(ked up. But are working to impove the games mechanics, and any game braking issues. Hopefully the game will have a birghter furture, we'll see.For sure this game is not worth the $49.99 it is currently being sold for, but it is worth the $25 or so bucks that I bought it for during the sale.

Posted: April 7, 2014
												I've given up. Ego is usually really great about fixing their mistakes and rewarding patience. Not this time. Each "fix" brings with it a slew of even more tech problems and bugs, let alone expanding gameplay to the same standards that were expected.Edit: I still try to give the game a chance. This edit is as of 3.2. There are still many game breaking bugs; Ships caught in trade loops, random crashes, off and on framerate drops. While things slowly are getting better, I still do not recommend the game in its current state. Bugs aside, gameplay is long and laborious... running back and forth through boring as heck trade lanes. They did take the lane minigame out, but even at that, the lanes are full of other small ships that get bombard you and slow you down. While I do like some of the first-person elements added to it such as ship crews etc... they are poorly implemented such as still limiting you to the Skunk ship, and having only a few NPC models. It gets old very quickly.

Posted: March 15, 2014
												I came to this game after having put 60+ hours plus into the X3 games and expansions. Loving X3 i was really excited about this landing.But i'm sorry to say this game is buggy and broken and not a patch on on the previous X games. Yeah its pretty to look at a glance but once you start spending time with it and looking in detail you see how broken it is.Capital ships phase straight through stations and now seem to fly faster than the smallest ships.After about 7 steps of the main storyline i came across a game breaking bug that means you can proceed any further.While still hand holding you through the basics the game asks you to buy a certain type of drone, after spending about an hour looking for someone who sells the certain drone, the game hasn't left you with enough cash to buy it and gives you no signs at all to go and make cash. You have to go and explore...Which wouldn't be too bad if the station explanations and exploration is impossible to get to grips with.This wasn't a one off, this happened several times, in the end i gave up.I tried this game on launch and 6 months after, after several patches... they haven't fixed it.If you want a deep space game with decent mechanics, stick to X3 and the expansions

number of helpful: 17 of 27 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												Ok, I was really, really mad when this game came out because I was so damn excited about it. I had high expectations, because I LOVE the X series. I own every X game that exists (and about 5 or so other space sim games). Let me just say WOW, now that the game is working and running amazingly smoothly, 1 crash in over 20+ hours of gameplay, that may not even have been atrributed to thier game engine. The frame rate is awsome on my GTX 770 maxed everything.THE GOOD--------------------GRAPHICS: The grahics are next-gen for a space combat game, they are amazing and fun to watch every, single time. SPACE COMBAT:space combat is fun and the AI is better than most space sim games out there. It can get repetitive after a while doing nothing but combat for hours on end but you can just go do something else, build some stations, conquer sectors commanding your capital ships and just watching the battle from a commanders perspective. You can start a trading empire, or become a pirate and depoy remote detonation bombs on ships... it goes on and on.ENVIRONMENT:As a Uninty game engine developer, I'm pretty amazing at what you have achieved with scale in this game. At first I couldnt tell if some of those large scale objects (Planets,Shatterd Moons) in the background were part of the skybox. I am very impressed with how you scaled the game and made it look so good. Though I suspect some kind of trickery at work with your Shaders! You should let me borrow some ;)GAME PLAY:You can board ships and take them over. nothing new here BUT, the pods come out of your ship and attract to the target like an action scene in a sci space film. So far it has been fun to watch every single time. Im addicted to capturing enemy space ships at this point just to watch the pods fly out. (they could add some drilling and molten metal types of animations and particle effects to make them appear to drill into the surface). THE BAD:-The sound effects can get a little old, if we can add more varition of sound effects and voice overs for the expansion, that would make this game more imersive and truly make it the greatest space sim ever made. Also, they need to write a script to limit how often a voice over is played from a single character controller, since you tend to click on them repeadedly when shopping for better crew members or ammo for your ship. You hear the same person repeating themselves 2-3-4 times... its annoying!-`They should add the voice over limitor function to the ship as well to keep it from reapting based up what the condition was that produced the previous voice over sound effect.-I had to look stuff up on google alot to find keys because there are SO MANY controls, there are controls for your controls! The control edit needs a form input search element to search through available controls quickly! This will be extremely usefull and save alot of time for beginners! Most people will be customizing thier controls. I am using keyboard and mouse and hated the default layout. I went from bad to pro once I changed all of the key controls and practiced for a while.-If you run in between two colliders it will bounce your around until you clip through into the interior of a station or a ship. It has happen to me many times and had to retart because your cant clip out from the interior. You need to control the unrendered side of your verticies and add a program to remove the physics colliders from the non-rendered side.-Your "bounce" physics on colliders needs to be toned down, so that clipping is less likely.- Also sometimes ships in your fleet clip through objects and get stuck, then I believe your fleet will bug out if that ship is within its group. Your fleet wont travel through gates if a group member is stuck. Mabey I'm wrong but,I had a ship clipped in a station and my fleet would not travel through a jump gate within any time frame. It seems the bugs I have encountered are more or less related to kinks that need to be worked on in your physics engine. You guys are awsome though for what you have made with such a small team.I'm sorry that I was so mad, I did not realize the scope and the work that is needed to make a game like this until I actually became a game developer myself and learned c#. You guys should of justdelayed the game another year and avoided that mess and you would have made ALOT more money. Does'nt your CEO get that? Seriosly, that crap launch you pulled hurt your sales!If you like space sim, BUY this game. It does have a learning curve, but it is well worth it to experince the fleet combat and amazing visuals and to realize that when this is improved slightly, it willbe amoung the top space sim games ever made if not the best single player space sim every made.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												What most people will be asking is that "Is X Rebirth worth buying since the 2.0 patch?"The short answer is no - with a big "BUT" at the end.The performance issues are still quite serious in that (even with a system that plays 99% of games on max) I can play it on "high" but even on the lowest settings there is stutter and the game will often flip you to your desktop for no apparent reason.HOWEVER, the game is playable in short bursts and shows the potential to be extemely good were these issues dealt with. As it stands I give it 60% and an "only if you are a fan". Potentially, it could become one of the best games ever made.I'm glad I have it..and i'm sure these problems will eventually be worked around - but I'm not entirely happy with it. And, for that reason, I can't fully recommend it at this time.*edit* As of 21/07 ..or 07/21 if you are American, the game continues to improve, continues to get closer to being a finished product, and continues to remain unfinished. A little note on the "missions" changes, the new ones add much needed interest and direction for those who don't want to be stuck inside the "campaign" but, since you can't run into the quest givers from the freeplay mode trying to play this as purely a sandbox game still doesn't work - there just aren't enough random events still to make freeplay a valid option. If you decide to "go it alone", trade around a while, be a mercenary, set up a station, it just feels like you are doing those things in a bubble. The universe doesn't notice you enough.

												I have been playing the X series since X2:The ThreatThis game is best enjoyed without taking into account the previous X titles, as a standalone game, it provides a fantastic and fun space-shooter/empire-building simulator.As an X game it does fall flat as you are only able to pilot one (althought upgradable) ship, rather than dozens of options that were availle in the earlier series.With the recent 4.0 update it allows for a quicker method of casual play, giveing you the opportunity for a 30 minute mission run, rather than spending a good hour or so simply hunting for an acceptable mission you can open up the BBS system and choose within minutes.If you like space games, give it a whirl, play campaign first as it is just a glorified tutorial and then dive into an alternate start.

												Good game, good plotline (sort of :/), good graphics (which my comp can process at around 30fps at lowest settings if i'm lucky.  Big engines are great! just one tiny problem though.   Actually two.1: ONLY ONE PLAYER OBTAINABLE AND PILOTABLE SHIPSeriously, and like we didn't know why the Skunk was a terrible ship in the first place.  This game is missing all the customization variety that was in the old X3 games like Terran Conflict and Albion Prelude.  2: NO PLANET LANDINGS OR WARZONESSeriously Egosoft?!  We wanted planet landings from X4, THIS IS X4, AND STILL NO PLANET COMBAT, LANDINGS, OR NOTHING!  Honestly, the closest you get to a planet base is a "Inherit your own planet mod from the community workshop, and even that was subpar at best.  Haven't seen any Yaki or Pirates (okay maybe 1 or 2 pirates), or Paranid,  All i've ever come across are stoned teladi, drunk terrans, depressed Argon, and a few suicidal xenon ships.  It's great that they're bringing back the Kha'ak, I loved those guys, but what's the point when you're still missing upwards of 80% of the old great content in the first place?5/10  MASSIVE ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT, GET IT TOGETHER EGOSOFT!!!! +2/10 cause can go into space stations and pretend to have a shootout with a bunch of battle droids.-1/10 cause already impossible xenon ai "is being strengthened".  As if the X Universe didn't already have enough to worry about :'(  Now we'll have a bunch of trigger-happy drones hovering around Albion, lovely.Side not:  Devs, some of us have been secretly wanting you to add in some Kha'ak and Xenon pilot interaction menus, so we can tell them to their faces that they suck cahoonas! (Old X Universe reference in case ya guys missed it :D)

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												Apparently this game was poorly recieved when it was first released, but I can't say anything about that as I picked it up when update 4.0 was released. As of the current version, this game is fantastic. Some weird dialogue is about the only complaint I have; otherwise this game is a phenomenal space empire builder. Combat is solid and satisfying, graphics are lovely, the simulated economy models are astoundingly complex, and the variety of different play styles you can go forth with make the game a little bit different for everyone. The detailed encyclopedia is also very accessible and helpful for learning about the game world.I'd definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a space game with a lot of depth.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Remember all the amazingly cool features in the previous X games that made them unique, and well worth the long startup time and learning curve?If you don't, you should probably go play those.  They're still pretty great, especially with mods.Well, Rebirth basically took all of good parts of the previous games and threw them out.  It's trash.  Combat is completely generic.  The trading system has been completely gutted.  The menus barely even work, and are bogged down with annoying animation to transition between the pages (and there are SO many pages).  The follower ships that you're supposed to hire and order around?  Wothless interface for orders, and they mostly just bug out and sit there.  The first person portions of the game, walking around on your ship and on stations are not even remotely interesting and only serve to distract and annoy from the already terrible gameplay.Remember how previous titles focused on setting up automated production/trade routes for profit?  Nope gone.Also, you only get one ship.  Because someone at the developer thought that could possibly be a good idea...I don't know how.I really enjoy the previous titles in this franchise.  They were challenging and unique games that occupied a special niche in gaming for me, and nothing else has offered a economic space sim that was even close to as interesting.  I cannot express how disappointed I am in this waste of a game.  I'm not sure that I'd be willing to risk my money on future titles from this developers.  Previous games make it clear that they have some talent.  This game makes it clear that they don't really give a crap.This game is complete and utter garbage, there are better flash games out there.  I wouldn't pay $10 for it, much less the (completely insulting) $50 that they seem to think they can ask.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Don't bother. Great visuals and attention to detail on exterior views is totatlly destroyed by horrendous bugs, and horrific design decisions and total lack of attention to mechanics, content, gameplay or voice acting.Even with the weekly patches coming out I've still not managed to complete the main plot as I keep running into show stopping bugs, daft AI behaviour and a total lack of information about what is happening where to whom leaving you scratching your head in the time-honoured question of "Is that a bug or a feature?". In this game is most likely to be the former, or simply not implemented or just plain missing.Once you've flow around and examined the gorgeous visuals in a universe that somehow manages to feel too small and too large at the same time the actual gameplay is repetitive, furstrating and basically boring.The best way to earn money isn't to fight, build or think, it's simply to turn on the primitive echo locator and collect containers. Six million credits in an hour isn't unusual, and considerably more lucrative than attempting to fight your way through the horrid trade interface.Conclusion: Don't bother. Buy X3: Terran Conflict or Albion Prelude instead.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Despite fixing a number of things with the 2.0 patch, there are still too many things that require fixing to go as yet. Ships frequently smash into things that they shouldn't and trading can be a bit hit or miss occasionally due to this issue. The biggest problems lies within the story however, which is supposed to act as a tutorial. However it's fairly evident that little more than a quarter of the way through, the devs got pretty fed up with trying to make the story function as a tutorial and stop giving any advice whatsoever about how to acheive the required actions to continue the story. Unles you're already familiar with X you will not beat the story without a guide, and even with one there will be many hours of head scratching. There is no warning upon entering a mission that you will need a lot more finance. To give a short example, I was asked to do a food supply run, with little instruction as to how. After 4 hours of reading forums and experimenting I finally figured it out and was ready to progress with the story. Unfortunately the game neglected to mention that I would also be expected to build a space station that would cost me well over 2 million. Considering the amount of weeks it would take to build up such money, I say dodge the story and try and enjoy free play for what it is if you really must buy it. A buggy, broken and questionable mess that at least looks pretty.Star Citizen and Elite: Dangerous leave this game in an awkward position, making it the lesser of the three despite being the only finished game, and your money would be much better spent on the superior competitors, one of which should release by the end of this year.

number of helpful: 20 of 33 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												As a huge fan of the X series, I hate giving this game a thumbs down. I really do. But it just doesn't feel like an X game. Gone is the series' trademark ability to pilot any ship you see. Sure, you can capture and give them orders, but it's not the same. Instead, you get the exciting ability to slowly explore stations that all look the same and collect worthless loot from unlocked containers that are apparently just lying around.  I admire Egosoft's loyalty to the game and I respect that they didn't just leave it to die, but they are just kicking a dead horse at this point. The game can be fun at times and it looks graphically amazing, but it just isn't an X game, and that's all that really matters in the end,

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Overall: I tried playing this game on release day, and it was very glitchy and buggy. However, now that the game has gone through several major updates and patches, it is a very good space sim. True, it isn't the same as X3: Reunion, Terran Conflict, and Albion Prelude was; but it now can stand its own ground. Give it a shot once it is on sale. And download all the popular Workshop mods.Pros: -Visuals are very spectacular -A ton of opportunities to make credits-Big selection of ship upgrades-Beautiful soundtrackCons:-Controls are not very friendly, takes time to get used to them-Managing fleets and individual ships is a mess in my opinion, can be fixed with mods-You are confined to one ship-Requires frequent game saves, a lot of game breaking glitches-Can't repair owned ships (I personally have no idea how to get them to repair, so I'd appreciate an explaination on how to do it).

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												As a space sim fan, I am very dissapointed in this game. I paid full price when it was first released and regret it to this day. Bugs and glitches galor, and Im trying to give it another chance now that the 2.0 patch is out. The learning curve is very high, so the people sticking with it are a bit more hard core, or gluttons for punishment. The game is pretty, but if you have played any of the previous X games, you will be dissapointed to learn that you are limited to one ship, an annoying copilot, bad voice acting, and some ugly NPC's when you have to encounter them. I dont know anybody who likes to pilot sim games with mouse and keyboard controls, but there is support for a 360 controller, which is ok at best. And if you have a decent flight stick, expect to spend a good amount of time remapping controls till you get it into a useful configuration.Sadly, there are no other current gen space sims on the market, though last I checked, you can get the X bundle of the previous games in this series for under $20. If that isnt good enough for you, its still a long wait for Elite: Dangerous and Star Citizen.

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I have played 148 hours of this game since its release. I seriously gave it every effort that could be expected. I have tried various mods to fix the otherwise terrible game design. I have edited save file after save file. The unfortunate result is that I am burned out by the constant restarting and the lost challenge inherent in editing save files. I feel ripped off by EgoSoft. They fell prey to the same business/design choices that so many other games have, like SWG and SWTOR for instance.... dumb down the game to appeal to the greatest number of people, and so designed the game for xbox 360, then at some point decided to port it to PC instead. The X series has always been a unique game with a loyal, if small, following. They betrayed us. Its 2013, why would you release a DX9 game in 2013... oh yeah, xbox. Dont buy this game for several months. Wait until the modding community, the real developers of the post-release game, to make it what it should have been.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												Big waste of money. Bought it thinking I would be once again presented with a masterpiece, coming from the humble beginnings of XBTF, and then through to the likes of the brilliance of X3TC and X3AP, immersed in the vast selection of pilot-able ships, vast galaxy, pirates etc etc etc.... All briliant in their own unique ways, so many features to list.But it soon dawned on me I had no SETA, no external view, ONLY ONE LAME SHIP TO FLY, and there was no huge galaxy to explore, also the Paranid, Boron, Yaki, were gone! WHAT!!! In their place you have what seem like very rushed and poor models of the races you could interact with, the space stations were the same, just the textures changed depending on where you fly, and everything seemed nausiaingly boring. if more effort was put it it would have worked, sadly not.What I actually received was a haplessly thrown together piece of gristle I wouldn't even let my dog chew on. This game is simply the true embodiment of old mother Hubbard's cupboard, it is totally bare, all the features you expect from the old games are gone. Prepare to be blinded by posh graphics over gameplay, not both as promiced... I will say that I wont be buying anything from Egosoft as fast as I did with this game.

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												TL:DR - Some game called X-Rebith sucked in 2013 and ruined my birthday. Suddenly, there's a different game in my list claiming to be X-Rebirth and it is really good.I knew my birthday in 2013 was going to be amazing. I knew this because X-Rebirth was going to come out the day after. I gingerly thanked everyone that wished me a Happy Birthday and kinda more or less glanced over any of the gifts, because the next day none of them would matter. I was going to be fully engulfed in X-Rebirth. 2013 was going to be the best birthday ever.Then it came out. I might have played with it for 12-20 hours. Trying to get past the bugs, the glitches, the missions that won't work and force a restart, the loss of SETA, and everything else that I felt as though I had lost from the previous versions of the game. My birthday... was destoryed. A year later I noticed that I had been given the first DLC since I was one of the inital purchases of this awful game, so I thought I'd give it another shot. Add in a few mods and I suddenly had a tolerable game. I didn't hate it, but I certainly didn't really like either. Things where progressing and I decided that I would continue to keep an eye on it.Then 4.0 Beta. A totally new game that keeps telling me that it is X-Rebirth, but this game is really really good. I've got quite a few hours in it now as you can see and this is only because of what they have done since the newest patches. Ignore the old reviews and read the ones for the DLC. This game is easily worth every single penny these days.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												As a whole there is a lot of depth in this game that cannot be denied. It is sad that developers decided to make so many gamebraking gameplay decisions that simply make the game so frustrating, slow progressing and difficult to access. There is almost no automation, so you can forget having a big corporation like in previous X games, the beggining of the game is just disapointment after disapointment when discovering that you cannot do that or that, and you have to do it manualy, slowly and be present in the zone where its going to happen. Without the option to accelerate time (which EGOSOFT said they will NOT add) i had to stare at my trade ship to dock at a station for 25 minutes, as thats how long it took to dock. In the mean time there was nothing else to do at all. So EGOSOFT says that time acceleration will not be needed in the game as you dont have to wait for your trade ships that much. Probably 25 minutes of docking is not considered as sufficient amount of time to wait before it starts to fall under "need to wait" category in EGOSOFT. Many gameplay features are simply not working alongside with the games concept. The interior is suprisingly passive and you basically cannot do anything in it, not even turn your head.To "discover" a new station in your zone, you need to be ridiciously close to it, we are talking about 500m for your computer to notice it. And than comes the weird duty of scanning the station, which means you need to come like 500m far from each module of that station, and not just anywhere on that module, on every module you have to find a specific spot that you need to get close to in order to scan it. So the whole scanning process of EVERY station will take about 10-30 minutes.What is that about? Isnt it in the stations interest to just tell me "Hey we are selling this for this much, want some?"I have to go thru so much hassle to get to know what do they make, sell and for how much that its beyond believe. After that, the whole frustration process of trading starts that again is so "un-independent" that making even the simpliest trades takes player so much time... Egosoft, there are many gameplay decisions you chose to implement that i can live with, but you have broken the whole concept of X games into small pieces that each is very frustrating and doesnt really go one with another.I want more interactive cockpit, i want to click on a small button above the radar screen to change its modes, modes like :zone map, sektor map, selected object info, basic trading info for the zone etc.I want to turn my head in cockpitI dont want to go inside of the stations and search for needed engineer hoping there is some everytime i need oneI want to be able to communicate with the stations from outside, i shoud not need to dock at all if i dont need repairsI want to use more than one gun at the same timeWell yes i will say it. I want the game to be a lot more like the previous X games were. You said you will make it more user friendly but to me it is exact opposite, even when you know how to do stuff, it is pain to do it

number of helpful: 22 of 37 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												I've been reading and watching how bad reviews Rebirth has been given...However I had made a decission to buy it when it would be cheap enough, and the weekend deals -66% was enough.I loved the previous titles, to the extent of X taking over my life pretty much.In anycase, the expectations were low thanks to the reception Rebirth has earned and I do really understand the reasons for it.The control scheme is pretty much ruined; when things were fast and simple (map, property menu etc) in earlier titles, in Rebirth it's done slow and cumbersome. Everything looks like it were aimed at consoles, but on the other end... not.UI is not only complex, but it lacks any sense of purpose. Earlier it was just complex but almost everything was where it was for a reason; and it worked after getting used to it. 7 hours into the game and I still have constant issues with the UI, never finding anything and things have been done VERY complex compared to what it used to be.Story feels nice and for that alone I will keep on playing, hoping that one day I get over the hugely confusing stupid UI Egosoft has created for Rebirth. I heard that a year ago the game was utterly unplayable and that doesn't surprise me at the least; it has been like this for a long time for X-series... Game is more or less unplayable for the first year and then it starts to get where it should be.I only hope X:Rebirth isn't where it should be, since there is so many issues still (at least for someone like me, who has spent literally thousands of hours in the earlier titles) especially with the UI and the way everything works.Fighting is very difficult with autoaim set to off, using Saitek X52 Pro makes life hell - easier to play with a gamepad and everything works way more logically with that.All in all, not a TOTAL failure. Not worth the full money even after a year of developement and bug fixing or the DLC. Still I get a nice feeling flying around trying to go on with the plot and the game draws me back in, calling me to play more.A lot of work is still needed, but if anyone can do it - Egosoft can.Against my better judgement I *will* recommend this game for everyone who are enthusiaistic about X series or "hardcore space sim's", but those who are not one of the two groups mentioned should really try it out first to see if they like it.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Egosoft, or rather the lead designer, apparently succumbed to their own arrogance and chose to ignore every bit of feedback from their loyal customers and chose instead to develop a mediocre arcade shooter.  I was alarmed when I read that there would be only one pilotable ship, but was assured that it would be wildly customizable.  They lied, there is virtually zero customization...  which primarily revolves around which of a half-dozen weapons to equip.They touted on-foot exploration as a groundbreaking feature where we could explore space stations and factories that actually had working machines producing physical goods using physical resources.  They lied...  there are ~4 layouts of space stations with a minimal amount of space to "adventure".  Hallways are blocked off via doors painted on walls and piles of janitorial refuse.  None of them appear to actually serve any real function, although one was obviously intended to be a jail.  I guess some genius figured that nobody would question why 1/4 of the space stations in the game used to be prisons.They got rid of the time acceleration feature, claiming that their usage of space highways would make the game faster.  Unfortunately it just means that your cargo ships now take hours of real time to get anywhere since they don't use the highways.  And you end up staring at the♥♥♥♥♥end of the 34th century's equivalent of a Honda Civic while traversing the wonders of space.This may be the most disappointed I have ever been by a game.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												I em enjoying this game. Much better than other space sims I've played. It is a different game than previous X games so if you're expecting the same as before you will be disapointed. That's probably why there are so many negative reviews, people's expectations are not met. But this game isn't trying to be just like previous X games. It's a whole new graphics engine and approach in general.Does it have some quirky moments? Yea sure. One look at the save file and you can know that there is a million different calculations going on in this game constantly... so I'm not surprised that "occasionally" things might get a little "stuck".You know what, deal with it! People aren't perfect and neither is Egosoft, give them a break. The game they first released certainly had many bugs but they have stayed with their game and addressed them. For the times it does get "stuck", it's usually just a matter of leaving the zone and coming back or reloading a previous save... done, that's all, no big deal.If you don't like space sims, or thinking, than you won't like this. There are mods to make things move a long much faster... play the game first and then read up on the mods so you understand what they really do and then get what is appropriate for your playstyle.The community for this game is awesome. People are always willling to help out and give guidance in the discussion boards. Like any game on Steam, I personally wait for  a sale, but this game is worth buying as long as you are willing to push through the learning curve... you tube, google search, and steam discussions are your friend.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												So much fun! Barely scratched the surface and I still have dozens of systems to discover.[UPDATE] 200 hours later I'm still addicted to this game! I have discovered every system and visited every sector, but I have barely begun to know them. I honestly don't understand the bad reviews, but here are a few thoughts:1.- This is game is super complicated, which is something I very much like, hence the 230 hours!2.- Because the game was buggy at the beginning people think that some things are bugs, but you just need to figure them out e.g. you order a capital ship to buy something from somewhere, but it just sits there. Most likely it's either a) you're sending it to a sector or station you haven't discovered yet or b) very commonly, you're sending it to a station that, even though it advertises its products on the market, it doesn't actually have a trading port! I know that's complicated but I love it!3.- People don't like it because they compare it to previous iterations. Nothing to add here except I find this game much richer, prettier and deeper. You can literally do anything you want: become a bounty hunter, a taxi driver, a warlord, an imperialist, a business man, etc. You can eve get off the ship and walk-around the stations or even the back of your ship. It's not very useful, but it certainly adds immersion.If you do get this game I strongly recommend getting the Cheat Mod from the Workshop area, as this allows you to take over, not only over stations, but also claim whole sectors!

number of helpful: 44 of 79 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Version 3.53 :Egosoft has finally made X Rebirth a proper X3 sequel!  Although X3 Terran Conflict (TC) and Albion Prelude (AP) are arguably better games for many reasons, X Rebirth is finally in a state that is worth playing.  It's not perfect – there are still many graphical issues, performance bottlenecks, and annoying restrictions that keep the game from being great, but it is worth 15 or 20 dollars if you find it on sale for that price.For fans of X3 and the series, it is worth coming back to and trying again.  I waited until 3.0 to get back into the game since its disappointing release.  It wasn't unexpected that release day would be problematic: There was plenty of evidence that this happened to prior games in the series and that Egosoft added many features post-release that should have been available on release day.  Still, despite how bad the game was when it came out, Egosoft has written the wrongs right.  I never had any doubt that they would get to 3.0.  But for those who are still bitter about the release: Their anger is justified, however, outdated.  X Rebirth has had a second rebirth.Why does this game now deserve your time?  It is probably the easiest X game in the series to get started with.  Unlike the other X games, the story/tutorial does explain most of what you need to know in the game(although the campaign gets frustrating at times).  Egosoft recently posted videos explaining advanced features that I would have never been able to figure out on my own.  The missions are also more friendly, giving you the ability to make money early without drudging through 50 hours of poverty trading energy cells.  The combat isn't the best part; and I find that exploration is lacking a bit as well.  So if those two features drew you to this game, get X3TC or AP instead.  This game highlights station building with an emphasis on building an empire as well as trading and building a fleet.  Station building is the only feature I can definitively say I like more than X3.  It is my personal favorite part of the X series, and it may be the reason I end up playing X Rebirth more than the 1000 hours I put into X3.If you are new to the X series, you may want to move on to X3 TC and AP if you're looking for more fun and more challenge after X Rebirth.  AP is also easier than TC, so that game may be a preferable next step.  I would recommend playing all these games with a joystick though.  I use a yoke myself, and I find that much more immersive.  You may also want to run the soundtrack for X Rebirth in the background -- it is absolutely awesome but half of the music doesn't seem to appear anywhere in the whole game.In the end, this game isn't worth 40 dollars.  It probably isn't even worth 30 unless you've already paid 300 bucks for a ship in Star Citizen.  I'd say buy it if it's under 25 if you're a space genre fan or empire builder.  This is just my opinion of course; I preordered the collector's edition.  I have no regrets though.  It was worth it for me.Note: The Teladi Outpost DLC is a small addition of content, probably worth 3 to 5 dollars.  It's nice to explore and build in a new region of space. My opinion and final thoughts: This huge game was made by a small developer, which inevitably means it's very rough around the edges. It's my opinion that most people who gave this game negative reviews think that it had a development team as large as Skyrim with a massive budget. I read many times about how X Rebirth (the game) was compared against Star Citizen (the idea), and somehow Star Citizen won almost every time. I find that line of thinking to be completely irrational. And I'm hard-pressed to find a game on steam that received lower ratings than X Rebirth (27% in 2014), even amongst games that were abandoned by their developers. X Rebirth seems to be the game that appeared at the wrong place and the wrong time.I nominated this game for the "Test of Time" award.

												I am so sad that I can't get a refund for this. The game was officially released but it wasn't even in Alpha condition. In addition to all the updates that have happened since release, it's still a load of garbage for the following reasons:- There is truly nothing to do but walk around cramped stations- Attempting to trade with stations is one of the most ridiculous things I've ever seen in my gaming career (you can't even tell if you're buying or selling)- Combat has no User Interface. You get a targetting reticle that stays on your screen and has no ability to lock on targets (and when you lead your shots, you still can't hit anything)- Trying to take over a capital ship? Forget it. Attempted that, couldn't even disable the ship's engines let alone comandeer it. It's bugged because all the ship's systems come right back to full and you never find out what happens to your marines.- Dialogue is garbage- Interface overall is cumbersome, you ACTUALLY TURN in your chair when you open a window by accident, completely blinding you even while in a fight. And the kicker:YOU"RE STUCK IN ONE SHIP FOREVER! That's right, unlike every other game made by Egosoft, you're stuck in your single space ship that is big enough to be a pain to fly, small enough to be ineffective in a fight.But wait! That's not all! Act now and you can get free crashes to your desktop after every save. And when you come back and try to load game? You guessed it! The save is deleted!
