content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												If you love Blade Runner and you love Space, you must get this. Seriously even if you never engage in the actual gameplay, the aesthetics and vibe of X:Rebirth is so strong with a good space version of Blade Runner. For flying around in space and exploring, checking out the intense detail of the stations and listening to the encyclopedia entries of every module of every station, this game delivers.Something that separates this from most space games? There is consumer traffic flying around constantly (not just other fighter ships, but civilians driving regular space cars and vans on space roads and highways. This adds a huge amount of atmosphere to the game that is missing from other space games. The ambient AI always moving around while you observe the beauty of this living breathing space environment.Second thing that separates it? Easy and good feeling mouse control. At night I play this on a freaking laptop trackpad okay? And the fact that I can do that is awesome. Most space games require something more demanding, some don't play well at all without a controller or joystick. There is some wonkyness to X Rebirth - the first person bits in particular and they could really improve some of the dialogue with NPCs, I don't hate it but it has the potential to be much better. However not many space games manage to have first person control at all, so I am very forgiving here. There is also something very cool about looking off the balcony of a station in first person and seeing how large and cool the stations around you look from ground view. It is a welcome change of pace to have your feet on the ground when you need a rest from constantly flying around.Egosoft has made an admirable attempt at restoring the general quality of this game to where it should be, and at version 4.0 it's in a very good spot. They have made some very meaningful updates and a lot of them make it easier to get into the game in general. Just be aware that you will only be flying one ship, unlike the X3 series. However the environments are so awesome that I was also able to forgive this.X Rebirth is a very ambitious game, and with that comes some rough edges. But after these patches it's not so rough anymore, and for what they achieved with the vibe and detail of environments / stations alone, you have gotten what you paid for. The Teladi Outpost and Home of Light are recommended to expand the universe further! Have fun space fans!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Newer: EDIT!:I have since completed the campaign and it was a brutal grind at times (Most of the X games had that at some point). And I must say there are some systems in the game that once they have been fine tuned and you understand them completely its... pretty damned impressive compared to the earlier games. The automated trade system is absolutely lovely, manual trade was the one thing that always turned me into nothing but a hitman in the other X-Games as the combat was really the only rewarding thing. The boarding system is much more interactive and challenging however it can be very difficult to get going initially as marines are sold only as recruits and even with a decent commander they can still get wiped out in seconds of reaching the inside of a craft. Combat against larger targets is much more interesting as they have soft points that can get blown off individually (Turrets, Jump Drive, Engines). The new missle system is short but not very sweet, as they are very cookie cutter (3 different types for fighters, 3 different types for scouts/interceptors, 3 different types for capital ships and stations) also there is NO missle defense system, once the thing is launched there is no getting rid of it unless it hits you or self detonates due to range. Drones have had a huge overhaul, there are hacking drones, automated interceptor/defense drones, missle drones, and manual control combat drones.Crew: Yeah these actually exist now, mechanics, marine captains, captains, defense officers, architechs, pilots and they can all be trained and have thier own skills.The game its self is unique in its own way from its predecesors and it expands on its idea as its own and I dont think it should be compared to the other X-games because it is so different from them as there is no comparion really. However those crappy highways need to go away and they need to bring back the Singularity Engine Time Accelerator (SETA)If Egosoft did the following:Took Terran Conflict/Albion Prelude and put the many systems that X Rebirth had into games like that then they would indeed have a title well worth their time, X3TC/AP with automated trading, indepth combat/boarding, Crews, Automated Station Administration, Adaptive Drones and took the complexity and diversity of the Terran Conflict/Albion Prelude and that would be something I would gawk at.However the game its self doesn't stand very well on its own and its so mediocre that I still would skip it.Older :Do not buy this game for its current price it is NOT worth 50 Dollars. I have been a veteran of the X series since X2 The Threat and I have no idea what Egosoft was going for with this one =/The game is mostly just flair and flash and the content is... repetetive, limiting, small and not to mention the menus are absoultely tedious to deal with and half the hud gets in the way of its self. There is only one ship that you yourself can operate which is just bonkers from the last installment of the X universe. There is a lot of new systems and scripts along with the game being mostly automated in comparison to the old system but getting the hang of these new systems was overwhelming and really not worth my time and I am familiar with these games, I couldnt imagine someone new to the realm of X starting up on this installment.Normally I like to play a months worth or so of a game before I decide to review it but I just cannot play this game because I cant even get past the broken campaign. If they fix one storyline halting bug, there is another (I have run into two and after I finally got past one there was another I was stuck at and after the game crashed it corrupted my save and had to start all over and now cant get past the first bug). The game feels rushed and incomplete and I honestly think egosoft just flat out landed on their face on this one. I hope they completely scrap this, stop working on it and move onward because the storyline wasn't honestly interesting me at all and I LOVED all of the other stories up to this one.Buy at your own risk is all I can say.Don't give up on the series though, if you haven't already play the titles before this one and wait patiently for the next installment. Hopefully they listen to the community and get it together on the next one."♥♥♥♥♥♥Tyrone get it together!"

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Honestly and Truly one of the worst, most disappointing game releases in my 20+ years of gaming. X Rebirth captured the imagination and excitement of fans of the X universe with its trailers promising a living world, explorable stations and so on...but the execution of the project killed the excitement of all but the most diehard of supporters within the first 15 minutes of gameplay upon release. Even now, many months later - the game is so riddled with issues that its a chore to play rather than a joy. All of the bugfixes in the world cannot change the fact that this game has terrible (AWFUL!) voice acting, a bland story line, transgendered old lady NPCs everywhere, and some serious dialogue issues. Why is everyone in this X Universe so damned polite? Even the pirates say lame things like "I am going to get you" and "Surrender Please". I think there was perhaps a language barrier issue (?) that translated to some very stale, overly polite and choppy dialogue...but that's something that has to be fixed in a game that really relies on dialogue to tell the player where to go, who to trade with etc. I cannot and will not recommend this game to anyone; outside of perhaps use in a game design classroom setting to show future developers what NOT to do. It doesnt matter how beautiful the space scenes are; a polished turd still stinks.

												I really gave this game a lot of leeway.  I'm a software engineer myself; I know how much it takes to make good software.  I loved X3: Terran Conflict.  There might not be a single game I've played for more hours, and I'll have to admit that even that was severely flawed.The UI in this game is horrendous.  The AI is missing.  It's terribly unbalanced.  There is very little actual content.  The performance is terrible (even on the lowest graphic settings).  And the bugs ... call Orkin.All they had to do was make X3 with a better UI, fleet management, and (if they really insisted) the ability to walk around inside of stations.  Instead, they made this mess.  I wanted to like it.  I gave it a good try (and $50), and I just can't take it.  I've been scouring the internet trying to find ways to make the game fun, playable.  There's just no hope.  Maybe by next year they'll have something good.  I'll check back then.

number of helpful: 15 of 24 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Let me first say that I am an X series fan. I am not a veteran of the series, since I just started playing X3 Albion Prelude less than a year ago (it being my first X game). I absolutely love the lore of the series and the core gameplay mechanics. This would have been a perfect addition to the series if it had just did the following simple things:1) Add a few more graphics effects to X3AP, like SSAO and the new anti-aliasing techniques such as FXAA and MLAA.2) Add good tutorials for the X3AP UI. (Don't make a silly radial UI; it makes the same quantity of data harder to read, makes complex functions harder to access by requiring the player to dig through menus, etc.)3) Improve AI decision-making4) Add in-game access to an extremely detailed encyclopedia about everything, especially the history of the Albion System and information about weapon systems and ships. This exists in X Rebirth, but much of the potential combat depth of X3AP is missing in X Rebirth.5) Build the rest of the game around it.Admittedly, it would have run worse and not looked at good as X Rebirth does now, but at least the gameplay would have been better.The biggest reason that this game is so buggy and broken is that Egosoft developed an entirely new game engine. That's right, this is NOT running on an older CryEngine. They spent a huge chunk of their development costs on creating an entirely new engine for the sake of graphics. This game will stand as a testament against the philosophy that graphics are the primary contributor to the quality of a game.Final Notes: In X3AP, you could captain or pilot every ship in the game - including capital ships - yourself. You could create fleets of numerous types of ships all supporting each other in various ways, according to your specifications. For instance, you could purchase a carrier and dock dozens of fighters to it. If the fighters needed to rearm with missiles, you could stock the carrier with missiles. You could outfit one destroyer to support your fighter wing with anti-fighter and anti-frigate capabilities, or the destroyer might attack other destroyers while protecting a missile frigate (probably piloted by the player) that barrages fighters and frigates with swarm missiles and capital ships with torpedoes.In X Rebirth, the tatical options have been limited for the sake of simplicity, rather than explained. Honestly, why couldn't they just make in-game tutorial videos for all the already-existing, complex functions? Change and improvement are often two different things. Do not buy this game, even if it's on sale for five dollars, unless it's drastically patched.

number of helpful: 17 of 28 people (61%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Lets get 1 thing out of the way before i begin, i know a lot of people are disappointed that you cant personally use more than 1 ship. yes it stinks but this game was never designed to be that kinda game, so rating it as such is abit unfair, if you didn't keep up with the press pre-development and didn't know this, then that's your own fault.So lets get started with my short review.Egosoft has a Long History of Releasing games that simply don't work on launch, they have MASSIVE potential but they don't work on launch... THAT SAID, they also have a long history of sticking with their products post launch to fix all of the launch bugs, add content, and add community feedback to the game in order to make it amazing.You will never see me fanboy for or back up any other developers, because they simply haven't earned it. Other devs always disappoint and never do for their games, what will Egosoft does for it's games.Egosoft is one of the rare devs that shouldn't get rated for their games on launch, to be fair YES it deserved the bad score then, but all of the newer players don't know what us older fans do, and that's that ego doesn't abandon its products. if we wait patiently, a year or 2 later we will have an amazing game to play. Don't believe me? Just look at the new reviews, they are positive!I highly recommend anyone who gave this game a negative review in the past, reinstall this game and take a 2nd look around at all the new stuff that has been added. Their are also a number of really good mods to try. Personally i have a lot of mods and have a very customized immersive and enjoyable experience each time i login. TLDR? Next time you buy a Egosoft game do so in good faith.Install it, don't play it, wait a year for them to patch the problems its guaranteed to have on launch, then come back and play. It will be everything you hoped for and more! They are a very small studio and it takes time to make a good game.Also after you have beat the game, dont be afraid to come back from time to time and try it again. Egosoft has a wonderful habit of adding new things to their games after post launch, and all through out its life for years after.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2013
												The game is in a pretty bad state right now, but Egosoft has a decent track record for massively improving their games after release. Don't get it now and check back in a couple of months.EDIT 11/4/2014:5 Months after release and the game is still a bug-ridden mess, just avoid this and get X3:AP instead.Edit 23/4/2014:Patch 1.30 hit and its improved joystick controls just barely make the game enjoyable but I did end up spending some time with it, so after ~20 hours of actually being able to somewhat experience the game I can finally write out some proper thoughts on the game.Clunky, very clunky. There's no easy way to go about anything.Want to setup a trade information network? While in X3 you'd send a ship to automatically deploy satellites in every sector, in Rebirth you have to dock with every single station, walk around until you stumble into a NPC that you can "small talk" with, play a silly minigame and sit trough cringe worthy dialog and then hope that NPC can actually update trade offers. Trading itself is also an issue. Unlike X3 you can only order trade ships around via a special trading interface that lists all trade offers and allows you to queue up trades. The idea is nice but the execution is very lacking, the UI, again, is very clunky: slow, badly designed and lacks the hotkeys that even X3 had. Even if you get past the UI you'll find your ships stuck more often than not, requiring yet more painstaking minutes in the UI to cycle them in and out of your squad and re-assigning all trade orders.Unlike X3's simple 1 cargo bay + maximum ware size system Rebirth has gone with, err, a total mess. Trading ships can carry a single cargo type (bulk,container,liquid,energy), plus a separate fuel tank, plus a separate drone bay. That, again, doesn't sound to bad in theory but now consider you can't just directly transfer wares between ships, unlike in X3. Ships can only buy jump fuel for themselves, if a ship finds itself in a sector without a station that sells energy sells (I wouldn't even know how that station is called) its stuck. In my X3 save I had a ship parked around the center of the galaxy that I could quickly order to refuel any ship that couldn't jump any further, nothing like that is possible in Rebirth. If a ship runs out of drones you need to take it to a shipyard, go out of your ship, search for the ship dealer, hope you found the right one (there's no easy way to tell what classes a ship dealer trades in) and restock it via drones via a special menu option(again, doesn't participate in the economy). Ships can't just go and buy drones for themselves (only for trading). The skunk is a story apart, there's a special "inventory" type for loot your collect from ships and scavenge from people's locker. These wares can only be sold to traders on stations and don't contribute to the economy or really add anything to the game. The skunk is also the only ship in the universe that can dock with stations and capital ships, fire missiles, strafe and is the only non-capital ship that can boost, carry people or launch half the selection of drones, it even gets its own special weapons that nobody else every seems to acquire.Upgrades to the skunk are also bought at special vendors that don't participate in the economy at all, and no AI will buy them.The player really is a story apart from the rest of the universe, nobody else behaves like you do, nobody else gets the abilities you have, a shameful departure from the X style of doing things.Ships and stations in Rebirth are no longer run by AI, instead they are crewed by people that you need to hire and transport around. Nice idea, bad execution. This basically adds a layer of complexity that isn't necessary and just isn't fun. I feel like I'm running a taxi service for an empire instead of managing it. X3 had all these ship upgrades that allowed you to over time delegate tasks to ships, Rebirth just plain doesn't. You'll always be the empire janitor/taxi instead of the manager you were in previous X games.Finding people to work your empire is again, very clunky. You can ask other ships directions to a specific person (again, trough a very clunky UI), but you still need to dock, walk around for a minute and hope the person you found actually wants to work for you.The economy and general game balance is just broken.I spend 90% of my time fighting a slow economy with trade ships stuck half of the time and earned ~1mil. Then I invested 500k in boarding, boarded a ship and sold it for 10mil. I used that to upgrade my ship completely and get a great boarding crew. Boarded another ship, sold that and now I'm sitting on 30mil, bored, slightly♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and writing this review.Combat is generally boring, there's only 5 weapons for the skunk, 3 capital ship weapons (surface elements) and 4 missiles. Plus you'll end up fighting the same type of drone 90% of the time. (Still more interesting than trade, sadly). Boarding has been made much more accessible, but the rewards are game-breaking high.A good bit: The atmosphereThe music and graphics are still quite the thing and are sadly the most enjoyable part of Rebirth as of right now. I'd have more fun calmly exploring the universe, listening to the amazing soundtrack and taking in the sights and not worry about the disaster of UI, ship control or being a taxi service.I'm no great writer but I really love the X series hope this review has helped other fans of the series make their mind up about this game.TL;DR:Clunky, lonely, player is not part of the universe.Trade: You'll always be the empire janitor/taxi instead of the manager you were in previous X games.Fight: 5 skunk weapons, 3 capital ship weapons, 4 missiles, same enemy 90% of the timeBuild: Only in certain spots, limited in number, no self sustaining chains, little control.Think: see trade

												Nice try egosoft, the only thing you forgot to do before releasing the game is to fix the hundreds of bugs there are in the game. its been a while since the game was released and it is still full of bugs. During 4 hours of actual gameplay, you have to think that you have to add 2 hours of waiting because of the multiple bugs there are in the game!! You target spawn inside a station so you cant kill it, your capital ships wont go to a refueling station, you cant cancel trades and all the things that will make you enjoy waiting for hours. And by hidden I mean core features that you dont know how to access! Even some of them are missing, for example, you cant cancel a trade! But why would you cancel a trade? Because of a bug that make your capital ship stand there, watch cartoons during 9000 years and when you ask him again, he look at you, and go back to his cartoons.So if you want to buy this game, wait a year, that way youll be sure (or not!) there are no more bugs! (Seriously, its a nice game, but its impossible to play it)

												X Rebirth belongs with other storied titles such as Big Rigs Over the Road Racing and Ride to Hell: Road to Retribution. The scale of its failures are best described as "Duke Nukem esque" if you're a fan of space games and "I can't believe that cost 49.99" if you're not. There is nothing redeeming about this game except the exterior visuals of ships and stations, and they are nowhere near $50 good.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Ok so 2.0 is out and there are have been a few improvements made to gamepley, controls and graphics stability since the last review. The game no longer crashes every 5 minutes and the graphics seem much smoother noteably when moving through densly populated areas, the controls are much the same but don't seem as jerky as before. I would still wait for Star Citizen of you're looking for a really involved space sim experience buecause this isn't it, it may do to fill in time if the price drops below £10. I worked hard to love this game but came up short and then just gave up. It still isn't the high quality involving game that it was supposed to be and I fall just short of demanding a refund. The stations throughout the game are based each on once of 3 layouts! That's it once you've seen all three you've seen all of them and you may as well get the mod that allows you to avoid going into the stations like X3 series stations. The voice acting is naff, the storyline is rubbish and the dog fights if approached correctly are a doddle so where's the challange? Where's the fun? Dissapointing to say the least.4.5/10Update:The new update 2.5 is a greay improvement and really shows what a comapany can do when they realise that they have released a sub par product to win customers back, the game is much smoother and edits to the travel system have made this game a little less boring. It's a step in the right direction and with the release of 3.0 due in dec/jan this game shows a real promise of being well worth a sale purchase to waste a few hours on.

number of helpful: 29 of 51 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												Overall this game in its current state is worth every cent. There are problems stemming from insufficient quality control and play testing but you can still get many hours of joy out of this game despite the problems.However, if you are a X2 or X3 fan, then be warned that this is not X4 rather its a continuation of the game style in the original X game, 'Beyond the Frontier'. Notably you can only fly a single ship although it is a very capable ship.Pro: Good space combat: Not Excellent like 'Freespace' but you get to target surface components of capital ships while dodging turret fire and thinking tactically about avoiding the turrets field of fire, flying faster than its tracking speed and avoiding head on conflicts with some deadly turrets that are near impossible to dodge. Economy: Empire building is generally enjoyable in this game, just be smart about location. Space station building is much more complex in this X game compared to previous X game, now you have to worry about hiring the right people to work on your station and building extensions. Story: I found the story to be enjoyable, you get to explore (within the campaign) and help the underdogs survive and grow. Space Terrain: Space is no longer a big empty void, plenty of asteroids, derelicts, space clouds and highways to give you a tactical advantage (if you know how) Good musicCon: Steep learning curve, lack of cue's, sadistic mission design occasionally: Sometimes you find that the game drops you in the deep-end or leaves you hanging from a cliff and you have to start googling to figure out how to proceed. For example, the campaign requires you to build a space station but it turns out that you cannot buy some of the prerequisite items. After some googling you find out that you have to become a pirate and steal said item but then you find out that you have to do a borderline sadistic amount of grinding to get enough of said item to proceed.Another example is that the campaign gives you a powerful war ship but doesnt tell you how to repair or move it, even after some googling you may still have trouble moving it.Another example is how larger ships move, the game gives you a capital ship but doesnt teach you about the jump fuel and capital ship booster dynamics, leaving you with some unnecessary confusion.Another example is the way station building works, you have to buy a construction ship which builds the station. You might think that the construction ship can then build another station once its done, but no, the construction ship becomes a permanent part of the station that can only upgrade said station, the game doesnt explain this mechanic. Cumbersome interface: They made some improvements with the updates but it is still unpleasant to use. Questionable script quality: Sometimes you find that things dont work as expected, often there is a good but obscure reason for it (are your ships lacking some drones? drone bay destroyed? drifted too far from station? etc) other times you find that it appears to be a bug, cancel the previous order and remake same order then it works. Some incomplete aspects: For example first person mode is quite limited and should be further expanded. Exploration also very limited, although the game does not claim to have a strong exploration element, it would still be an enjoyable addition, currently it is limited to finding some containers in space which are rarely useful and never interesting. Fighters cannot dock on capital ships, not even on carriers, only combat drones can dock. This makes me think that carriers are incomplete. Your stations can get damaged by trading: The exhaust fumes from a capital ship can damage ships and stations. In practice capital ships trading with stations accidently hurt your stations in this way. Then repairing your own stations is troublesome because you need to physically move the repair wares onto your station attached construction ships, they cannot put buy orders for these items on the market. Enemy stations cannot be completely destroyed, they will eventually rebuild. Most characters lack hair geometry. Also there are a lot of grannies in the game but that may not bother everyone :)

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												I'm rewriting my review after a year of this game being out.  I'm also going to consider it from a stand alone point of view.  This is only an X game from a story line point of view, it does not hold anything else in common with the preceding X games.As a whole, the game is free from major bugs, expecially the plot breaking ones.  The biggest problems I have with the game, is that for a game set in space, the areas are both cramped and to expansive at the same time.  The massive stations, while full of detail, can really become a hinderance while fighting near them as there is no reprecussions for the ai if they accidentally shoot them, but as the player, if you shoot the station or some of the civillians running around, you get reported to the police, have a standing drop, and if this isnt' your first time, get to have some of the police joining the fight against you.  These stations aren't so far apart that it takes long to get to them, but finding your way around them to a specific docking port can take a while if you don't have something to lead you to where it is.  This has been helped alot now though with the ability to gain access to all of the people on the station from near one of the dock ports.  You can also trade and recruit without landing on the station, with a slight delivery fee.  The stations themselves, while each type being very detailed and different, are rather limited in numbers.  Station interiors and NPCs also fall victim to this.  There are only about as many interiors as there are types of docks.  While each one is changed slightly, it's kinda like just rearranging a house without changing the base layout, there's only so much you can do.  The NPCs are all very generic, detailed, but ugly people generally.  This type of situation is the standard for the game.  Excellent detail on the individual parts, but so few parts, they repeated to many times.  Your ship, the Pride of Albion(aka Albion  Skunk as the designers decided to name your ship without giving you a chance to rename it to something worthy of a leader's ship)  Falls vicitim to this detailed mototony again.  Your primary weapons, a variety of lasers, are all able to be equipped to the ship simultiously, though you may only use one at a time.  As your experience, and cash, goes up, you are able to purchase upgraded versions of these, but they are nothing more than more powerful versions of the basics.  The missile selection is a little more diverse, mainly attributed to  the latest patches, with a good selection to suit most suations.  The engines and shields are also limited in selection with an average version, then one version at each extreme.  3 "types" of engines/shields, and increasing levels of them.    Your "copilot" is probably one of the worst parts of the ship, she is repetitive, annoying and the choice of outfit just doesn't fit into the game.  While that's not usually an issue, it really does bug me for some reason, considering the amount of time she ends up on your screen. I'm all for hot space women with very little left to the imagination, but this one doesn't fit into that in any way, and the "boob window" as it is called, just annoys me.Basic ship to ship combat is very standard, run of the mill.  Captial ships are large lumbering and pretty much push overs.  While they do support good shielding and hull hp, they only take time and very little effort to take down.  They have plenty of blind spots to hide in and recharge your shields while being pretty much invulerable.  One good example of this is the drone bays.  Wide open bays you can park your ship in, with no real way for the enemy to attack you.  Once you have recharged, you can pop back out and start taking out the turrets again.  They are very slow, and while they can jump from area to area, they are hard to manage on a large scale.   Trading with them tends to be tedious.  I do like the transportation system, aka highways.  they give you a nice view of systems,  balanced transit times, and are fairly well laid out, though it can take a while to memorize the network.  The improved maps in the latest patches have made finding your way around them easier, but I still think there is room for improvement on this aspect.  The missions and storyline are the one thing that really hasn't changed from the older X games or many other space games.  There are a couple set basic types of missions, and they are varied in difficulty by time, number of enemies, and such.  The biggest issue with the missions is that you have to wander around the massive stations looking for the icon to pop up,  there is no central place to find them, and you can sometimes take longer finding a mission than it takes to complete it.   I do like the story line and it fits well into the X universe and it's history.  The acting leave something to be desired of but on a whole, I do like this aspect.The final part of this game that I'm going to cover is the sandbox.  Whether you start from the end of the story line or a custom start, this in my opinion, is where the game is most lacking.  I have found it hard to set goals that keep me playing the game.  Your ship is fairly limited in upgrades, so combat can quickly become monotanous, though boarding and capturing ships has become increasingly difficult with the latest patches.  Building stations is also a long and tedious process with very little return on investment, as well as the same thing with trading.  The main problem I have with all of this is that once you limit out your ship, the only reason you need any money is to restock your missiles, or build more stations and capitals.  Yes you can use it to fund large combat squadrons, and go around wiping out whole stations and zones, but since you can't seem to takeover/rebuild the stations, you are eventually shooting yourself in the foot trade wise.  This game just does not have the variations in the right areas to be able to set large, diverse goals that can keep you playing the game for extended periods of time.  In review, as a whole, this game has a large attention to detail in what it has in it, but there is just not enough general content.   The story is a bit of a grind at times, but worth completing I believe.  All in all though it is a pretty average game these days,  Excellent detail, severe lack of content.  On a positive note though, unlike a lot of the good indy space games that are out, this game has an attention to layout that prevents the confusion that many of this genre suffer from.  There are a lot of other games, that while they are much more diverse and open ended, suffer from a pieced together user interface that is cumbersome and hard to understand. This game is sleek well designed and easy on the eyes.One more section to this review. If you have played any of the prior X games, do not go into this game with any expecations of it being like the rest.  You have been restricted to one ship, one race, even though there are 2 other races floating around, and a very limited selection of support ships.  From this aspect, they took the massive amount of content that the other games had, and removed it to provide high detail on a limited amount of content.  If they were to create DLCs that are X Rebirths for each race, and added them to the current standing game, not on their own indivitually, this game could eventually get much closer to the feel and playability of the original games, but I really don't see that happening.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Downright unplayable. If this was released as "early access" it would be understandable, but they have essentially launched a game in beta (or even alpha) state and are hastily patching it. They spent a lot of time and effort on features that nobody wanted, walking around in stations, having a companion, talking to NPCs, etc. It feels like they played Mass Effect and tried to put what they saw into an X game, but failed miserably.But remember that X3 was barely playable when it came out. Egosoft does have a history of launching broken games, but with great post-release support. There is already a good modding community that are working on fixing this broken game. I would suggest passing on this until at least a year has passed, and possibly when they come up with an expansion (X Rebirth: The Rebirth).

Posted: June 1, 2014
												Game is extremly buggy and with every new patch it breaks the old save game which makes the game unplayable. I dont even know if it will be worth a revist when they fix/finnish the game, by then elite dangerous will probally be out.  I have not tried the latest patch but i really dont have the patience to restart the game everytime theres a patch. Avoid this one, theres far better games out there.Edit : retried the game 2 years later....I have an i5 4670k and a 780 gtx, which is far better than the recomened specs. Frame rates vary but i seen the odd drop down to 20 fps. In busy places i get 40-45 fps on low settings, higher settings am averaging just over 30. Walking about in stations is bad, i often get 25 - 20 fps depending where i am. . It is better than when it first launched but fps is still bad and after two years of development they still havnt completly fixed the fps problem. I dont know what the fps will be using the minimum or recommened specs. Textures are still bad, audio is out of sync in places, no effort to add hair to characters. The game its self is ok, there is alot to like about it, if you can look past the issues it has but personally i find it hard to.

												I had high hopes for this game. Sadly it has failed on so many levels its almost unforgivable. The UI design feels like it was an afterthought and the cockpit view is fixed with no freeview, To quote a recent review "a 90's flight sim has better cockpit controles" -destructoid.comI have given this game several chances but have been plagued by bugs. The latest trying to hire a defence officer, after alt tabing out to work out what i was doing wrong i desovared that the officer was already working for the station. That info nugget was hidden in a dev blog. How can you leave such an important piece of information from the game! after working that out i tryed to jump back into the game only to have it crash.That's really the last straw. Don't waste your time or money on this game, it looks pretty but thats where the fun ends.

Posted: January 31, 2014
												One of the worst games I have ever played. This is not a simulator, nor is it an action game. The voice acting is horrendous. I could have easily done the voice acting better myself. The way you go about looking around stations to find missions is just terrible and tedious. It's so much hassle just trying to find a mission that it becomes a mission itself trying to find a mission.That stupid co-pilot can f-off and so can the absolutely absurd camera view. Forced first person/cockpit seriously doesn't work. Space looks lovely, but good luck trying to enjoy it with the worst fixed cockpit camera in the world.Complete and utter waste of £40.00, I'd like a refund back from this terrible excuse for a game. This should be pre-alpha and it's far too overpriced. 7 years of wasted time. Should have done X4! And for all of the crap this game entails, I give it the almighty score of: MINUS-100 out of 10. P.S. Buy at your own risk.

												I purchased this when it originally came out and it was an embarassment to the x series. The campaign was broken (still kind of is), there were numerous mini games you were forced into to get simple things done, lots of bugs and features that were missing for no reason other than "it's not x3, it's x rebirth". I recommend this game if you're into space trading/empire building games. It's a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												<<  EDIT: Have now passed the 300 hour mark, and.. STILL LOVING THIS GAME!  >>I am LOVING this game.  Looks like I've about a hundred hours in, and I've barely begin to scratch the surface - but I've been having a heckuva lot of fun playing.  This is a deep, rich, immersive game.  I start it up and the hours happily fly by.I'm gonna keep this short because given the choice I'd prefer to be actually playing the game.  I've only ever bothered to write one Steam review before, but I wanted to toss in my two cents on this game.  I don't know if you'll like it (evidently a good proportion of folks are still determined not to like it) - but I do know this game has given me what I've been searching for a long time.I've been trying a bunch of space / sci-fi games - many of them great games - but to greater or lesser degrees I always felt something missing.  I finally figured out what it was.  It was what I loved most about good sci-fi: the sense of Wonder.  Well I've found it here in this game.This is a richly imagined space game, with a bit of a high fantasy edge - places feel different and alive and beautiful.  I've apparently spent a hundred hours just flying around, exploring, admiring.  I've done some missions, I've done some fighting, I've made some credits, I've made some friends and some enemies - but mostly I've just been smiling a whole lot.I've only seen the tip of the iceberg.  I haven't yet assembled a fleet, or even bought my first Capital ship; I haven't yet built an empire, any stations, or even my first trader; I haven't yet captured my first ship, or even fully pimped out my own.  I have yet to dip into the Teladi DLC, and have already pre-purchased the upcoming HoL DLC.  I see many many many more happy hours ahead.  I think I've finally found my Space Skyrim.It must be disheartening for the Devs to see so much obstinate negativity; they had a vision and they've been working hard to keep polishing it (I'm on the 4.0 beta).  For my own part a big thank you to them, and their next X game will be an instant buy for me.Anyhoo.  If the first hundred or so hours are anything to go by, this game is right among my few all time faves - don't know if you'd like it, but then I don't know if you like ice cream either.  Back to SPAAACE!

Posted: June 27, 2016
												TL:DR For the price of €17 "X Rebirth Complete " is really a great game if you are into sandbox, space, and sim.  Dont mind the overal "Mostly Negative" reviews because they are mostly for when the game was in 1.0-ish. Now the devs have made it into 4.0 and the bugs is not to befound and perforamance is good (see speccs below)2016-06-27:  With 6 hours into the main story there seems to be tons to do and the space feels endless with many paths to pick. The atmosphere is tick and just slowly fly past a forest/farm on a large space ship is a great audiovisuall experience :). The ship control feels right with the mouse/keyboard as well as the handcontroller and the game runs great on a "old" 680 with the resolution 1920x1200. I would recommend a SSD for this game because of the small load times will not be felt such as when an old HDD is used.   2016-07-28:20 hours in and the game is becoming better and better. Amazing momement to send the troops to another ship and actually see the swarm of small ships land on the other ship while the rest of the crew is nuking it with laser...2016-08-11: Im at work thinking about how to make the big buck with a new trading strategy that Ive slept on. The game is getting more fun, complex and better looking for each hour... 2016 GOTY for me.2016-12-19: New graphic card (690) and the SLI support is not good at all. But Ive finally having spare time to roam around. Making my first space station.Also the the game will get another update with...VR and IR-tracking support! The devs way to care for their games should be the golden standard for game devs :).

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												After all the hype and build-up, and being a long time X-enthusiast (owning EVERY X game prior), the much awaited X Rebirth turned out to be a complete and utter dismal dissappointment. While most game developers would aim to build on existing positives, X Rebirth's devs have taken everything GOOD about the original games, and thrown them completely out of the window in order to squeeze in some "pretty new graphics", which in all honesty, aren't that impressive to begin with and seem more of a throwback to mid 2000's graphics engines. The removal of third person views, multiple ship control, gate travel (a new "taxi tube" system has been developed to shuttle your ship from system to system, which is absolutely TERRIBLE) and many "new features" are actually fancy detractions from what made the original X series so great. The addition of being able to walk around in stations sounded great at first, but is extremely limited in it's function and serves no great logical purpose to the game that couldn't be solved easier with menus and communications channels, except to make the game boringly and frustratingly mundane each time you are forced to wander around stations upon docking. Trade is just about non-functional, often causing game-breaking errors and lockups, and combat although beautiful to watch is just as broken. I am sorry to say that I was duped into pre-ordering this game with the promise of great things... It's a shame it was all a sham, and that no attempt to fix the issues has been made (even though that would basically mean re-releasing the entire game). number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												It seems like this game had a very rough launch and I'm happy to say that it does not deserve its reputation as a bad game.Having picked up X Rebirth during patch 3.5 it seems that many of the huge problems have been fixed; there are also some very good mods available, just search by highest rated. One large issue that I have with X Rebirth is the inability to pilot different ships. However after playing X Rebirth for a decent amount of time the ship that you fly (The Albion Skunk) has really grown on me. Piloting the skunk around the universe as you build up your forces has a Han Solo feel to it.Overall the I recommend the game to anybody looking for a great sandbox space sim that features tons of emerging mechanics that makes each players experience vastly different. If you are on fence the about buying X Rebirth, wait until it goes on sale and pick it up for cheap.Pros:+ Sound track - top quality stuff, definitely worth the money for the sound track+ Graphics - the older X games really felt lacking in this department and X Rebirth delivers+ Gameplay - piloting feels fun, and large scale fleet actions with capital ships feels omg epic+ Crew - you need to hire staff to run your empire, capital ships need engineers and captains. it adds a bit to the immersion+ Easy to learn - compared to the other X games the learning curve is less steep+ Replayability - with different start options and so much to do (start as a trader, combat pilot, or pursue the main story), the game evolves in so many different waysCons:- Weapons - choice feels very limited, and no real customization in this department- Pace - as with all X games, the game may be too slow for many people. it takes serious time to enjoy the game, especially if you are new to the series- Bugs - there are very annoying bugs, however none that I have encountered have been game breaking- Cannot fly multiple ships - this makes many people sad

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												After all the hype and build-up, and being a long time X-enthusiast (owning EVERY X game prior), the much awaited X Rebirth turned out to be a complete and utter dismal dissappointment. While most game developers would aim to build on existing positives, X Rebirth's devs have taken everything GOOD about the original games, and thrown them completely out of the window in order to squeeze in some "pretty new graphics", which in all honesty, aren't that impressive to begin with and seem more of a throwback to mid 2000's graphics engines. The removal of third person views, multiple ship control, gate travel (a new "taxi tube" system has been developed to shuttle your ship from system to system, which is absolutely TERRIBLE) and many "new features" are actually fancy detractions from what made the original X series so great. The addition of being able to walk around in stations sounded great at first, but is extremely limited in it's function and serves no great logical purpose to the game that couldn't be solved easier with menus and communications channels, except to make the game boringly and frustratingly mundane each time you are forced to wander around stations upon docking. Trade is just about non-functional, often causing game-breaking errors and lockups, and combat although beautiful to watch is just as broken. I am sorry to say that I was duped into pre-ordering this game with the promise of great things... It's a shame it was all a sham, and that no attempt to fix the issues has been made (even though that would basically mean re-releasing the entire game). Save yourself some money (and sanity); DO NOT buy this pile of steaming cowpat!

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												i think its a good game, ignoring the review rating as most of those reviews are before egosoft patched the hell out of that game. i played the game after they fixed the majority of the bugs and glitches and it is a good game for those who are interested in space sims and/or econemy simulators. i think in some ways it improved from the previous games namely1) ships arent restricted to six turret groups + one front battery anymore2) lesser loadingscreens (going from one part of the universe isnt as painfull as in the previous games which was loading screen - fly to next gate - loadingscreen and you couldnt do anything in the loading screens)3)the universe feels bigger(in the previous games the station were very close due to gameplay reasons, now we have highways, which connect the stations4)capital ships are integrated better into trading5)buiding ships and station takes time now, you cant just order ten battleships in a few minutes6)equiping capital ships with weapons is a bit less of a pain in the backsidealthough it has some disadvantages when compared to the previus games1) you are bound to a single, although upgradable, fighter/bomber class ship (might be because you dont have turret groups anymore so it isnt as easy to tell turrets what to shoot for a player so ego put you into fighter you are bound to, but thats just my theory)2)every weapon type only has one "bay". for example you have laser A which only fires one laser at a time and Type B which also fires only one laser at a time.

												My intial play through of the game started with Campaign, I locked into the immersion of the Universe as soon as the game loaded but for me that is all the immersion I was going to get. Though my PC outranks the Recommended Specs I have been forced to play on super low graphics settings and stil lget around 8 - 12 fps and I thought that it could not get any worse than that!I felt that the ability to play from within my ships cockpit was great though I was upset with only the 1 ship option and the very hard interface almost like it was developed for me to be using an Xbox game pad hooked up to it. I saw an icon for a Nightclub so I decided to to take a break and check out the ability to leave my ship... I wished I had not, upon leaving the ship I was met by a man with boobs... actually it turned out this was a woman when I showed the screeny to all my friends but none the less it amused me so... I carried on walking and found a Robot that sort of looked like a cross between a Dyson Vacuum Cleaner and WALLE but my eye was caught on something better, Advertisments for the strippers... a lot of raw skin so I hurried my way to the main bar where I was met by not NPC's not even CCC's just badly modelled mannequins with nothing more thna insults to throw at me when spoken to.I met a man on the station selling illegal high grade missiles so I spent all my starting cash on them and returned to my ship where I saved my game... now I only play this when I want to mess about shooting at random objects. (Actually I learnt if I get the cops after me then go into the docking bay of the big capital ships then the police shoot at the capital ship hoping to hit me lol)Overal I'm going to give this game a 3/10, It's not all bad but I can deff recommend you stay well clear of this title until either the sales or they patch it(in fact needs a whole new release let alone a patch) if your looking for something like this then checkout Star Citizen or head back in the series and check out X: Albion Prelude(the introductory game to Rebirth and the end of Terran Conflict)

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												4.0 + DLC ReviewTL;DR: This is not X4 and it's not meant to be X4. It's a good space-combat-and-fun-flying-around-in-space-sim which has an ill-designed but workable economic system. Dont expect to play for thousands of hours but you can still get more playtime than most other AAA titles.I played a fair bit of X3 TC and AP back in the day. I loved those games so much that I pre-ordered the metal collector's edition for XR. However, the game was a mess at launch and I never really played it until now. With patch 4.0 and the two expansions, the game seems pretty solid.It's not a successor to X3, it's a different game. If you wanted X4, you won't like this. But if you are new to the X series or can approach X:R as a different franchise, free of the trappings of it's predecessors, then you might just like it.The good:- The graphics quality and performance is amazing. Though it's not as pretty as Star Citizen (check the Gamescon 2016 demo), or E:D in the Vive, it's still gorgeous and atmospheric. And I am surprised at how smooth the game is even with ultra settings at 1440p and zipping across with amazing speed along the highways. This on my 2 year old 780 Ti. The stations are huge and detailed (from the outside). You can walk around inside the stations if you want to, but that part is ugly.- Combat is decent- I honestly enjoy it as much as in X3.- The world seems alive. There are literally hundreds and hundreds of ships chugging along the routes and they actually look like space cars and sapce lorries on a busy space highway. Billboards light up the routes, stations look believable, you can even pimp up the cockpit somewhat.- No crashes so far, no serious bugs noticed.The bad:- You can pilot just one ship- which sucks (though you can hire NPCs to run other ships for you). Also, weapons and equipment types are very very limited. This is my biggest problem with the game so far. It just seems very light on this front.- The Economy - it's kinda broken. To be fair, I have never played any game where the economic aspect seemed to be perfectly simulated. However, it's salvagable to an extent - at least in some zones.Also, do check out the Steam workshop for mods. Many of them provide great quality of life improvements. There are even some big ones that fix the shortcomings that I have mentioned here, but then can only go so far.

number of helpful: 15 of 25 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												First I would like to talk about launch, as in my view people kind of gave up on this game right out the gate. This game was unfortunately scarred by a bad launch, rightfully so as the game has its few bugs, flaws, and quirks, as ALL brand new games do. Though most people only spent an hour or so before they ran into some minor game stopping bugs and threw in the towel without even a second glance. For those of us who stuck around and could spare 15 min without rage quiting, looked to the incredible fan base who had our backs with bug work arounds and guides to help get through the troubled launch. After launch and a few days of blasting past bugs and finding work arounds we started getting patches, which have fixed a major amount of bugs making that first hour easier to play through and the game itself easier to complete.Now I want to talk about the game itself. This is a great game, my favorite of the bunch so far.  As expected of the X series this game requires time to progress and unfold into a larger and better game. The depth of this game is immense, and even with 130 hours I still feel as though I have many more hours to go to even begin to master this game. Weither it be trying to run a mining operation or becoming a professional bounty hunter this game always provides a unique challenge. The story line is very well put together and seems almost like a huge extended tutorial, making you learn and rethink constantly. Though tutorial is putting it kindly, as this game will not hold hands with you the whole way, instead this game gives you the push to leave that spaceport and find a path on your own. All in all, I can reccommend this game to anyone who enjoys space/sim/trader/exploration games. If you give it the time and the effort this game will keep you coming back hour after hour for more fun and more adventures.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game is a terrible addition to the series.  It has taken the exploratory element as well as the advancement element of the X-Series and mutilated it horrifficly.  Also a terribly buggy release.Came back to check if it got any better.Technically it did.There was no crashing, I could trade, and I only had one bug on the main quest line....That said the core gameplay was lacking in comparison of the old game.Still staring blankly at highways instead of a load screen when transitioning.No fast SETA acceleration (fast forwards) so when waiting for something to happen it takes FOREVER.You still have to fly circles around a station to figure out what prices are until you buy a module to not have to play a sucky mode.Even once you get the module the prices are still ridiculously terrible until you talk to people, fly around the station some more and hack the station.Don't get attached to your stuff you get early on if you're playing campaign mode.Still stuck in one ship, and upgrades are fairly linear and bland.They make you buy cockpits that arent obtrusive.Couldnt figure out how to tell my ships to just dock at a station to protect them.You NEED an afterburner to get anywhere without dying of old age first, but when you use it you're sacrificing your shields so getting to a distant fight is either brain melting or you arrive at half shields...Nope, still cant reccomend it, if it were a star system I would probably score it in the 1-2 range.

number of helpful: 17 of 29 people (59%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Being a huge fan of the X series I was shocked by the state X:Rebirth was released in:The performance was terrible, the game crashed constantly, you couldn't even play through the main story because one of the first quests just bugged out and kept you stuck. The game was a frustrating mess.My experience with Egosoft however was, that they usually continue maintaining their games over a long period of time and so I kept following the development of things as they rolled out one patch after the other.Now, with version 3.20 I can finally say, that the game is now in a proper playable state.They fixed most of the performance issues, the story quests work as intended, station building and fleet management works fine and the AI is starting to improve as well.Finally they added more ship models, don't force you to walk around stations anymore to trade your inventory and upped the threat that pirates pose. So, if you were thinking about getting this game but weren't sure if you really should because of the bad stuff you heard from frustrated early buyers, I think now is the time to pick it up without having any regrets.I expect Egosoft to improve the game for a long time now, so there should be something new going on every once in a while that will keep me coming back to it and thus never removing it from my hard drive for ages.

												Ambitious game, great concept. X games are usually awesome. But stay AWAY from this one. Riddled with gamebreaking bugs, horrible optimization (low fps on high end pcs), incredibly bad animations and character models, WORSE voice acting. Trading system is said to be very intuitive, and its not supposed to be broken according to EGOSOFT. If its working as intended its the WORST trade window in a game ever. Ambience is awesome, combat is okay (exeption is the fps drops), but gets boring fast. The concept of boarding cruisers is great, but there is no way to gague the progression system of marines, and you end up wasting ur time, and your boardingparty just dies either way. Feels like this game was supposed to be developed for xbox 360, but didnt cut it. So instead of having a useless unfinished product, they made a horrible port to the PC, and just slapped full price on it, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on their customers. I can safely say, that this game is the worst game ive played in a long time. NOT as advertised. STAY AWAY3/10

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I loved X3, TC and AP and yes they were flawed and infuriating at times, but they were at least decent and unique games that were just a little rough around the edges. I gave egosoft too much credit with this game, I assumed they would take this opportunity to learn from their mistakes and do it right this time. They took seven years to do it for crying out loud. But no. This is a terrible game, filled with terrible WTF design decisions. I have no faith this will ever be a worthwile game. Everything good about the previous games isn't here at all, and the so called 'improvements' they've made just leave me scratching my head. I mean, at some point surely one of the developers looked up and said, 'actually this is pretty s**T, I think we need to rethink what we've done'. But they didn't. Sorry EGOSoft, but I don't have any faith in you anymore as a developer. You clearly don't have the self awareness to know when you're on a winner and when you're building a steaming pile. Maybe if you somehow survive as a company and decide to make X4 I might give you another chance. But I will be very hesitant to give you my money again. You did not deserve it this time.

												I do not recommend this game if you are an X fan or not. If you are an X fan then youl will be disappoined in the fact that you only get to have one pilotable ship and some drones. number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												I gave up playing the campaign because of the many bugs that made it impossible to complete, like a food supply capital ship simply disappearing from your squad to name one of many  such problems.Whilst waiting for patches to hopefully fix the campaign I went on to play the free roam version the graphics are very pretty in space but the frame rate is terrible even on a high end PC. In the stations you are taken back to graphics of say around the 2006 era, and without some mods you will meet some of the ugliest characters I think I've ever seen who all say the same thing over and over no matter what part of the galaxy you're in again the lag here can be a real pain. The map system is terrible and I found it very difficult to actually use it to get anywhere with especially since the X3 maps were good.My other disappointment is the lack of an external camera and no way to look from side to side, had I known this up front I most likely would not have bought this game at all.On the up side there have been quite a few patches that have solved some of the many issues with promise of more to come. As Steam seem to be quite stubborn on granting refunds my advice would be to look else ware for a space sim at least until this game gets a lot more patches.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												It is with much reluctance I have to say No. I so wanted to like this game and mine and the community expectations pre-release were so high. Bugs will be (and are) being fixxed, but the basic design and loss of so many key gameplay and control features from previous incarnations has left this a generally empty and unfulfilling experience.For those of you wanting a definitive space bulding and exploration experience, roll back and look at Egosofts earlier relase X3 Terran Conflict. (NOT Albion Prelude, this DLC adds game events that will  furstrate the overall game if you don't have a good grounding in the basic gameplay.)For those of you who are familiar with X, then if you really want to roll back to an experiece equivalent to X-BTF designed for the forthcomming Steam Console, well, you probably got stung by the pre-order already.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												I stopped playing this game due to excessive bugs when it was first released. Now update 2.00 has cleaned up many of the bugs and the game is actually playable now. The hauler you control can actually move now to complete the trade mission. The framerate is a solid 50fps except for brief moments when combat begins. I am loving the ability to purchase different cockpits. I am using combat mk3 and since it is transparent i get the full screen to play with. This game is getting better but I feel the trading to be uncompelling and going full combat is the easier way with just looting missles for cash. Capital ships actually shoot now so it is harder.I do not reccomend this game, even if it is on sale since it's predeccesor x3:tc / x3 ap are both cheaper and WAY better games. If you are looking for an alternative game just look for star citizen or the new elite.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												There are some kerbal dolls (see kerbal space program) hidden on some of the stations. That was cool. The game it's self is not at all like X3. I miss being able to exit my ship and fix it with a repair beam (although I would have liked this to not be considered a hostile action in X3 when doing it to other ships and stations--something I think is bug). Interacting with aliens makes no sense. There is this weird frequency bar mini-game that's never explained , and, depending on when you click depeds on if your dialouge action is positive or negative (even when you think you've figured it out, the success results still seem entirely random)--more negative, and your rating goes down with them or that faction, more positive and you can get better prices.  Yeah sure, it's cool to be able to get out of your ship and explore stations, but that ends up being the majority of the game. You never have to fly around to make a fortune--just sneak around stations and raiding stuff. You're also suck with one ship type, and that's it. If they took X3, and added the ability to explore stations and explore your own ship, then yeah, it would have been a good game... not this. I could never really get into it.Hold out for the next release of X, and lets hope they get it right this time.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												I picked up the collectors addition recently and have been giving it a go. It is very different for x3 which I've spent a large number of hours playing. Playing on ubuntu on an under spec machine but it still plays decent with not one crash in 10 hours or so. So far I'd give it a 6/10 for gameplay. Very steep learning curve but that's one of the things I'm enjoying is learning how to get things done. Universe feels generic, ie finding a lost colony that's been isolated for hundreds of years, but they have the same clothes, same dang space station interior and space highways. The space station premise is poorly executed and feels like a waste of time but it looks like some functions can be managed over radio at least. I don't like the limitation of one ship, that was part of the cool factor of x3, but it's not a deal breaker.I am going to keep playing, partially out of stubbornness to look past the faults and partially out of enjoying what does play well.

Posted: December 26, 2015
												From the initial terrible release of X-Rebirth with lots of really nasty bugs, after a lots of patching by Egosoft  today I would highly recommend this game to all space sim / trade empire players. X-Rebirth provides a unique approach to building trade empire, different than previous X3 games TC & AP, allowing building predefined industrial complexes in a step by step approach, station exploration and many other new features. In-space graphics is  stunning, sound & music are great quality. The graphics inside stations and especially NPC graphics is still poor and needs improvement.  Afte exciting news that 4.0 patch with lots of necessary improvements and new DLC Home of Light with expansion of existing galaxies will be released in February 2016, well  simply I cant wait for it..

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												First thing I should say is that I did enjoy this game and giving it a not recommended review is entirely based on the games unstable behaviour on my PC.Here's my rig specs :- CPU: Intel Core i7 4770K Watercooled and Overclocked to 4.7GHz- Motherboard: Gigabyte Z87X-OC- RAM: Team Group Vulcan Orange 8GB (2x4GB) 2400MHz C10- Graphics: 2 x AMD Radeon R9 290X 4096MB Graphics Cards in Crossfire & Watercooled- Cooling: Full Custom Watercooling Loop, Mayhems Orange Pastel Fluid- Primary Drive: Samsung 840 Evo Series 1TB SSD- Secondary Drive: Seagate Barracuda 2TB SATA-III Hard Drive- Optical Drive: LG Blu Ray RRW- Audio: 7.1 Channel HD Audio with SPDIF I/O- Operating System: Microsoft Windows 8.1 64-Bit- Power Supply: Super Flower Leadex 80+ Gold Rated 1000W Silent Power SupplyIt's more than enough to run this game at 60fps yet after the recent big 2.0 update I found that my fps dropped massively compared to before the update despite this update claiming many fixes. Even turning down the graphics options to low would not fix this for me.To top it off, after the update I started to get blue screen crashes which would make my PC buzz loudly and cause me to have to hard boot it.In light of this I've now decided to uninstall the game despite only getting 55 hours of play from it, which for this game is pretty low as I intended to play it as much as I could over the next year, or until Elite Dangerous was in my possession.I think I'll now have to bite the bullet and pay that premium price for ED to get my space epic fix.The best part of the game are the graphics, they are stunning in places and the shear awe factor is enough to make you want to ignore its faults. Sadly, wanting to ignore the faults and being able to are two entierly different things.The voice acting, is horrid, NPC's are dull, lifeless and poorly annimated and singularly bring this game down to a mediocre title rather than being an epic, and if these were given more love in the developement stages it could have reached those heights.For me the bugs were just too much and I'm no longer prepared to stick with this game and I will switch to the Elite game as soon as I'm able to afford it.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												The features of this game may sound promising, but that's how the developers tricked us all into buying the game. The game, in it's current state, doesn't even come close to what the developers promised or to previous games of this series. Do not buy this game (yet), it is a fundamentally broken, dumbed-down, bad console port, which will surely take a year or more to get fixed. Please read on:Trade:Trade to me is the most important aspect of such a game. In the previous games, trade was awesome. Not in X:Rebirth, however. There is a trade computer software which you can install to your ship, which shows current trade offers. However, these offers are only stored in your computer when you fly through the actual zone the offering stations are located in. Once you fulfilled a trade offer, it disappears from your software and eventually your trade offer screen will be empty. That means you can't trade unless you fly through all the zones on a regular basis, which is horribly time consuming. Also, your trade ships have no way to trade autonomously, you always have to command them to take a trade. Additionally, you can only plan three trips for a ship. Furthermore, the economy is simply broken. While some systems are doing pretty well, your actions don't really influence the economy of a system. So if you think you can lead a system to wealth and prosperity, you are wrong. There is a mod which tries to fix this whole mess and so far it's ok, but there is no way I can tell if my actions make a difference. The statistics of your stations (production, sales etc.) are non-existent and the only thing that tells you something is going on are annoying messages of the station manager, telling you that he/she made a little fortune and will be transferring it to your account. I currently have two stations built (yeah, I'll get to that too) and these messages are already annoying me to death. And yes, there's even more. From broken trade ships (simply doing nothing at all, getting stuck everywhere or trading with hostile factions, which will ofcourse get them destroyed (and you don't even get a message)) to station managers throwing their budget you gave them out of the window to buy secondary ressources instead of primary ressources, everything is in it. Fight:EPIC FLEET ENCOUNTERS, they said. Sounds awesome, but it's not. You can have as many ships in your fleet as you like, all the enemies will be shooting at you. The coolest part: Your fleet will not do a thing. The combat AI of your fleet is broken, they will neither help you nor fly out of the battle if they somehow manage to get in trouble. Dogfights are boring. Fly straight up to the enemy vessel, shoot it a bit and turn when they pass you. Most annoying are drones. They attack you from everywhere and you have no idea in what direction to turn, because the HUD is so horrible. There is no "Target next enemy" button whatsoever and finding the red, thin-lined squares on a vibrant background is really eye-straining and sometimes nearly impossible when you are in a zone with a sun and/or orange nebula in the background. "Choose to fight for someone". No big deal. You wan't to be police? Buy a license, but it doesn't really matter. Other police vessels will still come at you if you do any shooting. "Take the action right into massive structures". Yeah, attack a station. By the time you are done, your grand children's children will probably be watching you. The puny weapon arsenal at your disposal is just ridiculous. Speaking of which, there are only five weapon types. And one of these is the mining laser, which is completely useless because you can't pick up ores with your ship. Boarding got improved compared to the previous games, but it still is bad. First, destroy the ship's jumpdrive. It's pointless, because it won't jump to safety anyways. Then, destroy the engines. Now your boarding crew will launch and fly towards the ship. Once they reach the hull, it's up to you to create "distractions". Destroying turrets, shield generators and sadly the drone launch pad. Unless you destroy these things, the boarding crew will take forever to get the job done. The bad thing is: if you destroy the drone launch pad, all the drones on the ship will be destroyed, which also includes cargo and construction drones. So there you are, you captured a ship without drones, destroyed engines and no jump drive. It's basically a floating wreck. Next up, dock on the ship and tell the captain and the engineer you previously hired to work on the ship (yes, you have to board the ship to tell your crew to work there..). The engineer will only fix your ship to 75% hull, you will have to take it to a shipyard if you want to get 100%. Now you still need drones, so either you fly to a shipyard and order the ship to buy drones (you have to fly to the zone and speak with the shipyard guy on the station), which takes a considerable amount of time since you destroyed the engines and the jump drive, or you open a save game editor and manually add them to your captured ship. Build:Empire building sounds great. Again, it's not. Station building is so buggy, that I spend more time editing the save games than playing the actual game. Without a certain mod, your station will be built in an ungly, deformed way, with parts of the station all over the zone. The devs thought it would be nice to have little pointless ships flying around your station to make it look like a city. Ironically, these things make it impossible to have a nice station. They obscure the place where the module is to be built in, so the AI moves the module a bit, resulting in stations looking more like a Picasso painting. During the plot you are given a task to build a station to vitalize a certain factions economy. That station however, doesn't produce anything. Well it does produce something, but it's not a good which is present in the economy. Furthermore, to produce this useless good which noone will buy, you need ressources from other systems. Your station trader however is restricted to the system your station is in. Think:Yeah, will have more than enough time to think about everything. Escort plot missions which take 30 minutes, hacking missions which take forever and travelling the universe without SETA or jump drive.I could continue, but I reached max chars.

												Xrebirth is a good game it has alot of potential for advancement into something far greater than it currently is at this stage. For example a storyline with a mass effect 3 or better instead of just a space game add a people individual action to it. Also I have played this awhile. I have sort of grown to it. IF the bugs of station ships not working , traders not trading , It sure would be nice if there was a total overide command to wake the game or diagnose the conflict of what is wrong with the players game which said fix this or delete that or whatever without getting the error messages on startup saying cannot load game account stuff like galaxy communication not on because it was part of the problem and have to start all over in the game, or any other error message as a matter of fact on the menu selection.ships not transferring wares between them and station bto builders not building got fixed along with the other bugs in the game got fixed when steam updates or modders update or egosoft updates . If everyone had some common ground to play the game the way they want to play it , that would be one heck of a game This game could really evolve into something far more that what it is. But everyone needs to work together with the creators of the game and steam and the modders. When a modder updates their mod and/or adds a newer version of the mod it kills the game for other players or at least the ones who do not know how to fix whats wrong, like me. I have come to the point of creating a decent empire only to have some bug mess up the whole game. But like I said it is a great game or it can evolve to a greater game it all depends on you guys and what you want. Please just fix all the bugs and compadability.
