												this game is so glichy its like a pre-alpha. avoid it like the pleague until the build the REAL game.as of 1.17 the game will still randomly crash (probably due to the horrid gpu managment of the game) capital ships are still bugged and fixing this game still requires editing your saves.on the plus side (yes the core of the game still has a plus side) the core of this game is that of an x universe.  and it is much easier to get into as the starter ship is a god and can fit just about everything but a jump drive.  this is fixed by aquiring a capital ship and hitching a ride to your destination.  all of the textures have had an overhaul (granted the game still looks like it came out of 2k)  new modules on the capital ships adding allot more functionality and objective specific targeting (while still keeping health bars for the npc to outright destroy)  the stations are now massive and intricate making them really fun to fly through, and its an x universe game you can go anyware (unless your docked in witch case your usualy trapped in a force field bubble of some kind with a very stereotipical layout)on the downside.  (gliches aside) this is the most limiting x game ever.  u have only one ship to use granted it is equivlent to just about any ship there is but part of the reason you want to buy an x title is to fly any ship anyware. doesnt happen.  how they managed to add content while reducing it is beyond my but they did.  granted i havent been able to get past the build station mission in story mode yet (mostly because of the glichs randomly ending my game prematurely oh thank for the autosave feature)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2013
												I have finished the plot and have 65 game hours on the clock. I sit looking at the screen thinking “now what?” Put the bugs and performance issues to one side for now (I am reasonably confident they will be dealt with), this game appears to have nothing in store but tedium now the plot guidance has disappeared.I need to make money in order to progress. The prospect of either long range scanning, or constantly flying around huge stations to try and get missions or establish what is for sale/wanted fills me with despair. Especially as I have yet been able to establish how I get my freighters to refuel. Is the only way to do this be by ordering them to buy something then telling them to buy fuel first when they tell me they have no fuel? (that has yet to work BTW). I have the trading software and even though I have traversed from the end of the plot to Far Out, I bring up the trading menu and there seems to be little that I can buy, what little that is available I cannot sell as I am an enemy to most of the stations that require the wares (PMC). What am I progressing to? Is my purpose solely to get the economy going? Can you order a cap ship to attack something?That station I built, due to bugs and not being able to find freighters that held the required materials for building the various sections, was mostly completed by hacking the save. It has yet to produce a single item for sale. Modular station design seems to be a good idea, only being able to select and build one module at a time seems bizarre. Especially when I cannot seem to be able to contact the architect remotely (I can’t even comm the captain and ask them to go and get the architect). Backwards and forwards again and again, why would I do that for more than the required station? Please tell me that it is different for a construction ship that isn’t part of the plot.I have mixed feelings regarding the use of shield energy to boost speed, if I knew how many enemy ships were close, trying to kill me and what type of ship they were it would be a good idea (I can make a judgement call and run if need be).  But as I can only see red triangles at the edge of the screen I do not have enough information to know when to run.“Shut up Betty” was funny the first time. The highway mini game was was fun the first few times. Hacking while your co-pilot seems happy to let the ship get blown to pieces is ridiculous. Hacking in general is ridiculous once you throw the mini game into the equation along with some hacking points being many km’s apart. I am not going to comment on the small talk mini game. A mod has put paid to “shut up Betty”, I refuse to play the highway mini game anymore and I had no choice with hacking.Clusters are too small, the distance between them is too large and I am loathe to jump out of a highway on the off chance that there may be something interesting. Writing this wall of text has allowed me to determine what is wrong, in my mind, with the game. All of the fun, mystery and potential sense of achievement has been removed. I don’t want to micro manage on a face to face basis. The saddest part is that now I have finished the plot I don’t know if I want to fire the game up again.Maybe the complete lack of any useful game information (how to, what is, why does etc.) is keeping me from the best gaming experience of my life. I may never find out.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Such a disapointment... To its credit X: Rebirth is probably the easiest X game to get into of all the series. Unfortunately it's also the easiest to walk away from... The core of the game has its problems, but the devil's in the details: bad and utterly confusing menu system, terrible AI, completely useless map system... The list goes on and on. You know, I should have realized something was amiss when the game actually tried to convince me that the name "Albion Skunk" was chosen by some wise guy as a joke who reprogrammed the ship's computer, or something like that. At the moment I thought it was funny, but that was only because I thought someone would actually think of re-re-programming the ship into some other, cool-sounding name. But no. The "Albion Skunk" it remains... and yes, it stinks :(

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												While heavily hyped X Rebirth has done nothing short of falling flat on its face upon release. The bugs are too numerous to count in all fields ranging from UI, to ship control to AI interactions and story line missions. The game is a wide divergence from the previous X releases, with little more than names and references to events to tie this game to its predecessors it is no wonder so many are disappointed with X Rebirth. I would happily return this game and not waste any more of my life on it. Since I can't return it however, I'll settle for the latter and move on to something that shows an ounce of quality control.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												More than 3 years after its launch, X Rebirth is still a mess when it comes to performance, dropping to 30 fps and below, on rigs that can run Witcher 3 nearly maxed at 45. The game received a lot of polish over time but the old saying rings true - ultimately, you cannot polish a turd.The simple fact of the matter is that it's neither the involved simulation and economy puzzle that the previous X games were, nor is it a fun, exciting, exploration game like Freelancer. It's stuck somewhere in the middle, failing to score high in either sub-genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2013
												This is comming from a X player from the last 10 years of playing the X gamesi'd like to point out this is the WORSE X Game i have Ever played in my Life.Being stuck in one ship is a terrible design choice, one I think the developers will regret in the long term.Simplfying the trade. Those of use who loved the supply chain logistics of previous X games will be very upset this is almost completely nerfed here. One station does it all.Simpler? Yes More enjoyable? Nope not for me anyway.What is the "elevator pitch" for people to upgrade to this game? How is it an upgrade. I can see what it removes from X3 Albion Prelude, and sometimes removing things is a good design choice (though I don't think many nerfs in this game are good) but what Rebirth actually add?At the moment it's playing OK for me. Just.Being stuck in one ship is a terrible design choice, one I think the developers will regret in the long term.Simplfying the trade. Those of use who loved the supply chain logistics of previous X games will be very upset this is almost completely nerfed here. One station does it all.Simpler? Yes More enjoyable? Nope not for me anyway.Combat has been dumbed down. Choices removed.Things like the stock exchange that was present in AP has gone, the none campaign missions also seem gone.The graphics while ok are not better than AP either (this is a direct X 9.0c game after all, so is running the same technology as the original X3 more or less)I'm not saying this is a bad game, just can't see the point of it existing who did Egosoft make it for? How is it more advanced or better than the last X3 update? I've only put 8 and a half hours in so far, but I might as well write this now, as I can't see me playing any more. It just seems to lack the depth and rewarding complexity of the last games. I'm looking for "new" or "innovative" and can find nothing... at all. Am I missing something?In short even when fixed, I'm not sure why I would play this in preference to Albion Prelude which is a larger, more mature, deeper and more rewarding game that looks the same (if not better) plays more smoothly...If anyone could answer that question I'd love to hear from them .WHY NOT TO BUY THIS GAME!1. Being stuck in one ship, Yep only one Ship not 86+ like the old X games2. Graphics are dated, looks worse the X3:R from 20053. There is no immersion, You got it no immersion AT ALL4. Voice acting is utterly terrible, Get Ready for B Grade voice acting as thats all you hear5. Supply chain logistics of previous X games, GONE 100% GONE!6. Combat has been dumbed down, Choices removed IT'S SO BORING!7. Things like the stock exchange that was present in the last X games, GONE 100% GONE!8. Menus, You must go though the NPC's to do anything and hear there same line OVER AND OVER AND OVER9. Comanding your  Ships, Again you must go though your NPC's to do anything and that Takes Forever and ever and does not help that you have no idea what your doing at all.10. Docking, Good lucky Trying to dock looking for a tiny icon that you can only see when your in front of it.In short even when fixed, I'm not sure why I would play this in preference to X3 Albion Prelude which is a larger, more mature, deeper and more rewarding game that looks the same (if not better) plays more smoothly and is not broken like this pile of crap is...If anyone could answer that question I'd love to hear from themBuyer Beweare

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												I've Where to start.  Firslty, it is very clear that this game was not finished at release.  I've been waiting until around a few days ago to give it a try.  Egosoft has still not come through with the patches they promised.  The trading is completly bugged and if one thing is done wrong it flat out does not work.  The navigation system is not only confusing and buggy but is near impossible to find the information you need/want to know.  Combat can be fun at times.  It feels a little slow to pace and from time to time you simply explode for no reason.  The game has a good look to it but the cockpit feels completly worthless and has almost no value as far as mechanic.  And lastly, not only do you have to leave the cockpit to talk to your crew but the ship only has one room on it.  Somehow with one room (that has nothing functional in it) can fit you, your co-pilot, an engineer, eight marines, and a marine captain on it.  It has a few very cool festures like how to scan for long range.  the station landing feels very dry and unpolished as well as the fact that your ship can be attacked while you are docked and can plainly see it on the landing pad.  The game feels like it was the test system the quickly slapped some polish on and said "That's good enough, right?"  All in all, I wouldn't recomend this game to anyone until Egosoft fixes most, if not all of the problems with it.  Personally, I feel that I have been scammed by Egosoft and they should be ashamed of themselves for even releasing this game.

												Wow - what an incredibly terrible game.  So far the game looks NOTHING like the video would have you believe. The in game characters walking around are about as graphically advanced as a Playstation One game.  They are stiff, underdrawn and move (and talk) like robots.  The story so far is pretty thin.   The interface of walking around and clicking on random objects feels forced and uncomfortable.   Its been a very long time since I was THIS disappointed in a Steam purchase.  The game feels rushed, underdone and buggy.  There is zero excuse for a product this shoddy.   One a one to five scale I'd rate it a ZERO.  Simply awful.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Bring a Bug Spray!This is a fantastic game, in a very beautifully crafted world (if you can ignore the decade old sub-par character animations and voice acting) as a futuristic space sim, it's gorgeous!The music sets the tone very well, and I love spending time flying around, looking at the other ships and stations doing their work.HOWEVER, as of right now, the game is plagued with bugs. Lots and lots of bugs, glitches, and some are game breaking enough that you can't progress through the story. The menu system is also a bit confusing in the beginning but once you get used to it, it's quite deep. Still a lot of work needs to be done to refine it however. Mods can solve many of that problem though.Egosoft, however is known to have choppy launches, but patch things up later on (apparently) so if you decide on it, do wait a couple weeks to months. The modding community is quite active so far with many little tweaks to make the game a lot more enjoyable, despite the bugs.Do I recommend? Yes... maybe... but not yet! Wait until they get everything sorted out. It should be amazing by then.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Sound: 1 Music is ok but short, sound acting is awful and the general sound effects are very repetative.Graphics: 8 First thing when I started on this game was how good it looked, it was all down hill from there.Gameplay:1 Even when this game works through all the bugs, it still feels like a shell to most space sim games, the trading is souless and boring.Story: 1 I Must admit 1 for this aspect sounds harsh, but when you tie in the voice acting, the souless script and fact nothing works in the campain you understand why I give it 1.Replayablity: 0 As I was so sick of playing after only a handful of hours, I doubt I could ever go back into this world.Overall : 2X-2 and X-3 was both hard to play, some might say it was like working in a job, I wouldn't go that far. But when you done something worthwhile you really could feel happy about it. In X-Rebirth everything still seems a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to do but you just feel numb after you done it. I think its due to the one ship setup, you feel disconnected from everything around you. Add to the fact that nothing works and you really have a title that no one with prior knowledge would even think about buying for £5 let alone £40, so please guys don't make same mistake many of us did and stay away from this one you are not missing out trust me.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												As a longtime player of the X series, this game bears no resemblance to those fantastic engrossing predecessors.  Gone are the  deep levels of control over your great financial empire and gone are the deep levels of control of your own ship!Being limited to a single ship isn't worth the tiny benefit of walking around a 3-room vessel in which you can only interact in one room.Being able to land and get out of your ship isn't worth the pain of looking at the zombie-esque tortured faces of your business contacts on the space stations, and t isn't worth listening to their awful dialog.The Minigames of : Spacelane Travel, Dialogue/Sweet-talking, Galaxy spacelane travel & Spacestation scanning for trade discounts are all painful.There is no fleet management system and that's good because i'm not sure what I'd do with a fleet in this poorly designed game.Trade is cumbersome, communications is cumbersome, navigation is cumbersome, flight over distance without autopilot is cumbersome.The map system in this game is the worst map system I have ever seen in any game.  Really.  I believe it was designed by a person who does not know how to read actual maps.  The ability to manipulate the map is gone, you can't zoom out or in, you can't scroll anywhere and there is no facility to allow orientation to any map objects.I have always thought of the X games as a PC game.  I don't know their console history, and perhaps there is some, but this game with it's very limited key choices and lack of commands as well as it's obvious wheel-oriented menu options was obviously intended to be controlled by a game controller.  I do not and never will have a game controller attached to my PC.I get the feeling that this was never designed by the people who made the X games.  The departures are so stark, the changes are so dramatic and the design elements are so cumbersome and yet so limited that I think this game is something else entirely.  I feel like they just put the X game on a piece of trash so they could get my $60.This game is very beautiful in space.  There I wrote something nice.Don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												I play a lot of terrible games. Very few make me angry though. X-Rebirth isn't a terrible game, but it is an infuriating one because there's so much promise in the ideas behind it but the execution feels clunky. This may be a failure of funding or a result of having to rush a release, but what could have been a lot smoother simply results in a game which constantly feels like you're jabbing yourself in the arm to see if you can still feel pain. I gave up playing shortly after I was encouraged to explore a space station on foot and then got stuck between a vent and a wall after being told I'd be rewarded for exploring vents. In a way, the game was right, it pushed me to never play it again and I've been rewarded with a lot of time I've spent doing other, more exciting things. Like watching paint dry.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												I really, really want to like this game... but its just such a let down.The thing is, the old X games were never really meant to be exciting, thrill seeking, action packed combat sims. They were trading and company management Sims and the thing that kept me playing was the pride in watching the empire i'd built from scratch flourish. This new one however, looks like its trying hard to be someing to just isnt! when i first started playing it, I was reminded just a little of Mass Effect (In a sense of that there was a lot of character communication and story driven) and I honestly think thats what ego was going for... but it it missed the mark by a long shot, the character models are lifeless and cloned repetedly on every station (In fact if you look closely at the female models they share the exact same Male Head, Im not kidding take a look!!) and the story alone is nowhere near enough to keep the game rolling (Maybe it might have been if it didnt constantly crash and force you to restart, which happened to me three times in 7 hrs of playing) and so we're left with the trading aspect of the game... THERE ISNT ANY!! this is no joke Ego, how can you take away the one thing that drew us in to the old X games and then stamp a 40 quid price tag on it!! indeed to give them some credit the space does look amazing, but if its just graphics your after, my advice is go and rent and watch Avatar!! But by far the worst and most unforgivable thing wrong with this game is that it litterally leaves you with nothing to do but follow its dull broken campain, so when it spectactually crashes, And oh believe me IT WILL!! all you can do is start it all again!!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												24 patches and still an unpolished turd.I've been one of the people that preordered the game, fully expecting bugs to happen, same as with all the previous X series games. I've been with the series since X-BtF. I've made it through the glitchy first versions of X2 and X3:Reunion alike. I had fun.Rebirth is different. The engine itself shows potential, but everything tacked onto it is a mess. Even completely disregarding the bugs in the economy and storyline, the game is still bad. The UI design is horrid and needs a complete overhaul. Most of the features that made the previous games great are missing entirely or dumbed down to the point of uselessness. Many of the new features that were tacked on are badly thought out or lackluster.Yisha is the most obnoxious sidekick I ever encountered in games period. The fact that on the first days after release mods were popping up to shut her the hell up speaks volumes. Same for Ren's terribly repetitive lines every time you talk to an NPC. The entire trading/station scanning concept is a horrendous cluster♥♥♥♥. The hacking/smalltalk minigame is ridiculous.Despite promises to the contrary, modders still don't have all the tools they need to polish this turd. The playership is hardcoded to the Skunk. The UI is all in compiled lua that is more or less impossible to modify without the sources, which the Modders still don't have. The engine itself shows great potential, but Egosoft still isn't really letting the community at it.All that that leaves one with is a semi-decent space shooter. And there are other games that do this a lot better, for a much lower pricetag.Scripting support aaside, it has all the marks of a rushed and terribly botched console port, despite being developed exclusively for the PC. Patches are slowly fixing this: We now get targeting hotkeys for the keyboard, for one. Ha.There are two rays of light, though: While most of the modding community already gave up on this game, some are still working away at it, and many of the smaller annoyances have been fixed thanks to the community. Egosoft has a stellar record when it comes to supporting their games even years after release, even adding new content long after releasing a patch that completely removed DRM, both for TC and AP.I'd say with another year or so and a solid UI revamp, this game could truly shine. Let's just hope Egosoft doesn't go bankrupt by then, and that they don't wait with opening up their Lua sources for too long.For now, though: Very definitely not recommended. Grab it at the next WInter Sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												This game is such a travesty to the X franchise i had to write my first review (probably only).If you are new to the X franchise you may actually find the game interesting for awhile before you find out just how shallow it really is. After the campaign there is NOTHING to do. And the campaign itselt is a bugridden nightmare of how not to create an interesting plot.Lets go through its shortcomings:1. The trade part of the game is, show stopping bugs aside, shallow. You, the player, are the only one who uses money for an example. Alot of the items being produced are for building ships. Which the shipyards will do regardless of if the NPC or the player orders any. It will simply churn ships out. If there was no need for it, the AI will take the ship out of sight and delete it from the game (literally). So there is no real "supply and demand" in function. If anything, its a plan economy which the soviet union demonstrated never worked. Yet they implement just that in X Rebirth - and oddly enough it doesnt work. How about that! Rating: 1/102. Fight... Well if you like fancy graphics and dont really care that your ship is superior in every way and can just "boost" (afterburn) its way out of any fight that starts to become challenging this game may be for you. Unless you play with a joystick - because they made an xbox controller the featured item for this game. (Yes this was supposed to have been an xbox release 3-4 years ago or so but obviously such a poor game that it was never allowed by MS to be released). You have no way of "tab targetting" as they apparantly think chasing icons on the edge of your field of vision is awesome - that apparantly is set to 60 degrees as well. If you are in a system with a red sun its almost impossible to keep track of said icons. You get the idea. And dont get me started on the whole drone thing. Terrible idea with a terrible implementation. Your so called "co-pilot" which was apparantly going to be piloting your ship while youre busy controlling a drone - doesnt. So you get your♥♥♥♥♥blown off. Brilliant. Rating: 2/103. Building stations was one of the interesting things in the past, as you could set up your own trade empire and compete over sectors if thats what you wanted. They have actually thought out of the box in a nice way this time, allowing you to make huge complexes. Great idea. But then they couldnt have you build your stations just anywhere. No there will be 2 maybe 3 slots where you can place it. So much for freedom. There is also the part about "why" you would want to build anything as you are the only one who needs money to fund stuff - and making money is extremely (too) easy. Rating: 3/104. Thinking about this game makes my heart hurt. I preordered this game because the X series had been a great experience for me in the past. It no longer is. The campaign is long and unrewarding. The economy is fake so there is no incentive to try and corner any part of the market or try to take a competing (enemy) corporation out. They have no money, they need no money, so they can never be "beaten". So what is there left to do? Nothing. Space combat boring and uninspiring. After a few boarding/captures of capital ships that gets boring too. The placefiller/timesink minigames makes you want to scream. About 1/3 of your time will be WASTED in the highways, in the past you could zoom past boring parts of the game with SETA which allowed you to increase time by factors up to 10 so you didnt have to sit and watch paint dry, sorry i mean wait patiently for your ship to arrive at the next destination so you can jump out of the highways. Rating: 2/10Other parts of the game i will cover here:Graphics: I will not lie, the new engine makes space look truly awesome. Stations, NPCs and the skunk itself is a whole other story. And you cant look around the cockpit nor look at your ship from the outside. So minus a few points there. It has a few issues (no doubt because it was programmed for the xbox360) where really high end machines run worse than medium/low end machine. But pretty thats for sure. put 1-2 points on when it gets bugfixed. Rating: 6/10Music: Great as always, that is one of the parts of the game i always enjoyed. The beautiful score. Sound effects and the voice acting? Not so much, but i feel its adequate for this game. Rating: 7/10Gameplay: It would probably be easier to say whats actually working for this game which is... nothing. Literally. I have sunk about 16 hours into this game and i havent felt like starting it up again for weeks. And i used to love the X series and have sunk hundreds of hours into them. This one was simply a money grab. That they burned any creditability they had with the X community, well thats just too bad. In Bernd Lehahn (owner of Egosoft) own words this was a "Huge success" on release. Yes indeed, saleswise it was. For 1 week. Then sales plummeted. Rating: 1/10Overall: A very very bad excuse for an X franchise game. There is nothing to keep you playing like in previous installments. Its an empty, shallow excuse for a moneygrab. The only positive thing they can take from this is the new graphics engine - that even though its already aged - looks great (in space). The rest? A disaster. This game will quickly be forgotten - except for the bad memories it will bring back to the surface years into the future.Rating: 2/10 - DO NOT BUY not even when its patched and put out on offer at 80% off. Buy X3:AP instead.

The objective location isn't helpful when you don't know what to do there.And there's many more but those are the ones that come to my mind when I explain why I've put down the game for the time being. I do hope that in time they patch... fix? the game to make it a fully enjoyable experience.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I am 11 hours into the game, an unfortunately there are many glaring flaws in this game. I believe most of the technical issues will eventually be resolved, but there are some serious design issues which really drag this game down.I have long been a fan of the X series and I have been looking forward to this game for months, so my experience might be colored somewhat by my disappointment. I have been plagued with poor performance, constant game crashes which sometimes require a reboot to get out of, and numerous glitches in the trading system and missions that make advancement impossible.Again, the technical issues will be resolved via patching. What may not be resolved are the design choices that depart from previous X games. To list:1. You can no longer hop from ship to ship. You can own multiple ships and you can issue them limited orders, but your starting ship will be your ending ship and it will be the only one you pilot.2. The trading network has been neutered. You can only issue trade commands for your freighters to sell or purchase goods in their system only. You can't set up the elaborate chains that were possible in X:TC.3. Voice acting: You are chained to another character that has some of the worst voice acting I've heard since Final Fantasy X.4. Menus, sub menus, sub-sub-menus: You can't just buy a gun or missile while floating in space. You need to dock your ship, walk to the individual merchant, open a conversation, request to see their goods, request to see their missiles, then request to buy them, then tell them how many you want. Seriously, restocking missiles is a 5-minute ordeal after every fight.I think I see where they wanted to go with this game. They wanted to make it more appealing to the masses that were previously turned off by the massive learning curve the series holds. Unfortunately, instead of streamlining the game mechanics they just hid them behind a poorly-designed and time-consuming interface which is somehow more painful to deal with than the spreadsheets of the older games.I want to like this game so much, but there are just too many jagged edges to get much actual enjoyment.

If you want evidence then look at the menu navigation, videos made by the developers (all are playing using the xbox controller), xbox specific metadata/code, full xbox controller support but disfunctional joystick support, limited key binding options, DX9 only, "hacked" 32 bit executable to use more then the 4gb memory limit.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												I'm sorry to say, but this game was clearly not play tested before it was released.  I'm a big fan of X3, and was so looking forward to this addition to series.  I just wished I would have waited until it was on a steam discount deal before I purchased it.  Game performance is verry slow, even on the lowest settings.  I'm able to run games such as Skyrum, Bioshock, Warthunder, all on extream graphics settings with no problems, and adiquit frame rates.  But X Rebirth is very choppy at the lowest settings.  Not sure what kind of graphics engine they are using, but it's horible!  And the bugs are to numerous to count, hell there is a bug that just teleports you out into the middle of no where?!Now, with that being said, I will give the programmers credit, they have been comming out with patches on a regular bassis (almost weekly) in an attempt to do damage control, they have made some minor improvements to FPS problems, so there is hope for X Rebirth yet.  So I would recommend that you not purchase this title at this time, give it about a year, wait for it to be on a Steam daily deal, get it at a reduced price, by then hopefully they will have most if not all of the bugs fixed.So for now, I'm not going to recommend this game, hopefully I can change my recommendation at a later date.  (keeping my fingers crossed)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												So far this game has gone full retard.  Visually it's very cool but don't be fooled it's full of game breaking glitches.  First of all if you do buy this game be sure to save often as it will randomly have game breaking errors.  In the first 5 hours it happened to me 3 times, the first time I lost over an hour of gameplay.  Following the campaign The mining company is now hostile with me and open fire everytime they are near my ship.  Neutral space stations everywhere will do absolutely nothing when these ships fire on mine but if I return fire the immidiately respond against me.  So what is the character the only person subject to the law in the entire universe?  In addition to that I'm on a mission where I apparently have to use a Trojan ROV except I don't have one and i've been to 4 different drone dealers none of which sell them.  I've looked at the mission screen multiple times and it gives me no information at all.  So now I'm going to youtube to look for answers as to what the **** I'm supposed to do on this mission to advance the plot.  Furthermore I was in another area where I had to boost past some enemy ships to get through a gate, but the characters were talking.  I boosted through before they were finished and the game made me go back through the gate only to come back again before it would update the navigation point lmfao.  One last thing.  When you start the story mode you get a cargo ship with weapons and shields that the story has you purchase crew members for and even place in your squad so it follows you around.  There is even a mission where you have to use your cargo vessel to ship something for you.  The point I'm at now that ship has just vanished!  I know exactly where it was and how much health it had.  I also had a captain, an engineer, and a security officer on it all of which cost money.  It was never in a battle it has just vanished.  It's not in my property owned screen anymore it's just gone for no reason.If you want a big headache then this is the game for you.  Bugs and glitches as well as improperly done triggers have repeatedly pulled me out of the immersion and made me very much aware that I'm playing a video game.

This game is incomplete, buggy, feels designed for a console, cheesy, has terrible dialogue, and I wish I had not spent so much time trying to make it work so I would have been eligible for a refund. DO NOT BUY, at least, not for a long time (until the modding community can fix the garbage - which I expect will never happen).

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I wanted to like this game very badly. That said, it's a terrible game. Egosoft screwed up the launch horribly, and while it's commendable that they've fixed a lot of the game-breaking bugs in the last two months, the game is still a terrible game. It's fundamentally unfun. Virtually every game mechanic can be summed up as "tedious" at best.Escort missions take 20 minutes of sitting around waiting for something to happen, followed by 5 seconds of combat, followed by 10 more minutes of waiting for the ship being escorted to dock. Travel between sectors takes forever, even when piggybacking on a jump drive capable ship. Of course, if you do piggyback on something, it's guaranteed to die when it inevitably passes through an impossible-to-avoid PMC controlled zone. If instead you just send it through alone, no problem, emerges unscathed, through the miracle of out-of-sector combat!Trading takes forever, and station-building relies on trading at its core, so that's twice as tedious. Half the materials you need will be obtainable mostly through hijacking freighters. Guess what? Hijacking anything is also tedious with yet another timesink there. And what is the reward for all these timesinks? Cool things to upgrade your ship with? Nope. Awesome new ships you can buy? Haha, no. Maybe some new capability for your stations or something? Get real. Usually it's just "Yay, I got to advance the plot to where it showcases the next horrible game mechanic!" Best part: The ending. I won't spoil it for you. But basically, all of a sudden, the plot just... ends. If the game was amazing, that could maybe have been forgiven as the expansion pack hook, leaving you wanting more. But in this game, it was more a sigh of relief. This stupid thing is finally over.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												I wanted this game to be the next step of the X series. It has been the case that with every new one, it offered the same as the last one, but with better and more features. So it was from the first one, all the way to X:AP. From what we were told it would be, we expected the end of "tubing" our stations to make it a complex, the end of gateways were out ship were colliding with others comming out, and of course better graphics.Instead we received a game that only has the same races and a few mentions to the previous universe. Everything else is working differently, making this not the next X game, but anothing game set in space. Graphics in space are beautiful, but everything else is awkward, ugly, repetitive and annoying. Trade mechanics started broken, but even if they are fixed take an age to complete, and without advanced autopilot commands, are hard to provide enjoyment.A graphics user interface built around the needs of the least common denominator (which in this game is the Xbox controller) means that the keyboard and joystick are severely limited by design and it took only forum remarks to get the developers to promise to add a few keyboard commands, while going off and apologizing that those will not be included in the Xbox controller. While the gamepad incorporation should be an option for those that want to use one, it should always be handled as the most important commands and controlls peripheral and not a way to work everything in the game, as that leads (as it had) to a very simple interface for a very complex game. This means that previous complex menus in X games are now gone and to do anything you have to go over much more steps than before! Yes, the previous menus seemed complex, but that was only because the game itself was complex. The menus were very well designed to offer control and everyone that ever loved the game had a very good understanding of how the menus worked, because they loved all the complexity the game had to offer. Having a steep learning curve was never an issue for his game, it had to have it, because it had so much to offer once you were on the other side.New additions to the game to deal with previous problem areas are equally not well thought out. The simplest one should have been the traveling between sectors. The problem in the past was that every one had to go through a gate to go to the next sector, and that introduced problems like big ships entering through that gate would intrfeer with the small ships comming out (or the reverse) causing AI pathfinding problems and crashes between ships. The solution was a highway system, that is fast, one way, and involved a mini game based on being caught in the wake of another to speed up in the lane. Aside from this being irrelevant, one could just not use it, but as there is no autopilot to tell it to take you to that system or that station, you hace to fly manually and wait while you get there and make notice to get out in the right area or the trip will just continue until the end of the lane.First of all, why no autopilot? There always was an autopilot, X:R doesn't have one.Secondly, there is one element that makes sence, one way travel, but that would be all the solution needed for the problem. Introducing one way gates would solve the single problem that existed with the gate system.Thirdly, where before we entered and exited the gates in one or two seconds, we now have to wait to fly between sectors and unless you want to play the minigame, the travelling can become long and extremely boring.This means that lanes offer the solution to the previous games, while introducing new problems we never had before. Good design ths is not.There are further design choices like this made throughout the game. Big stations are great and beautiful, but to read them all you have to fly extremely close to all modules of a station and on the correct side of the module as that is the only one offering the magical  ( i ) icon, which I assume would point to the only antenna on the module that allows communication to your ship's scanners so that you can get the information. So gone are the days of scanning a station from 25km away (or longer if one had triplex scanners) and learning all there was to know, now we are reduced to a few meters of scannign range for one module that has to be facing us correctly. There is no reason to do something like this in any space game I have ever played - or hope to play.Maps in the game are big unwieldy things, as if they were designed to be seen by someone still playing of a PAL monitor. In this day wher an HDReady resolution is considered low for a PC monitor, the maps are so big that waste screen realestate and become nonfunctional. Bind this together with a control system that is again not the right one, and figuring out the maps becomes a hussle.The same low density that exists for the game maps continues to your assets listings, quickly filling up with only a few of them when the X games were typical of the player having many hundreds to track and monitor, providing another step back from previous games, also not being helped by the control system.Space station walking is also pointless and akin to an FPS of the previous decade in terms of how moving around it feels, and of five years ago on how it looks. This is not a commend on the aesthetics of the models, but on the technical accomplishement of the engine for interiors. The fact that every single person you meet is just so ugly and so similar would make for a good lore item of how cloning brought the species to this state, but this is not offered anywhere and the strip clubs on stations do not seem to agree with a cloning reproduction society. Space station walking is just irrelevant and every one is the same as the other, as there are only three or four models reported as available (although to mee it felt more ilke two different ones).Trade is also completely new. Not only can you buy and sell items to people in stations when you walk in there, but now you can give commands to big trade ships to buy and sell between stations. The problem is that this is too slow, too little. In previous games, the trader ships could fit any product or raw material in the universe. Not so in this one, as they are specialized. Maybe there are others available later or someplace else that I have not seen, but then using the trade ships is extremely slow as you have to wait for them to dock (10 minutes or so), load (anything from 1 to 3 minutes), fly off (another 10 to 20 minutes depending on position in the sector), travel to the next sector (which is another 5 to 20 minutes), dock (10 minutes), unload their goods (another 1 to 3 minutes). All this must be done in real time.As if to drive the nail home, gone is S.E.T.A. which might have salvaged something from this. Time acceleration was always something that developer Egosoft have made a remark on as not being the end-all tool players were using it for. it does not surprise me that it came time to drop S.E.T.A now, nor that further comments have been made that it will NOT be comming in a future date. Real Time is the name of the game, but this is a single player game and not a multiplayer platform where time needs to be kept accurate for the sake of the community. This is a design decision that says Egosoft wants us to experience their game in real time, as if being afraid that using S.E.T.A. would make gamers bored after having finished their game so soon. Only that a true X game cannot end, as the end is only defined by the player, not the available options given by the developer.I fully acknowledge that this may have been intended as a new type of game, in which case it is not something I like and cannot recommend to anyone. If this is supposed to be the next X then I still do not like it as it is completely different to anything that ever made the X game what they were. Space is beautiful though!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												I wish I could say good things about this game, I really do. I purchased this at launch after visiting forums and discussing things with others and had high hopes, but due to some in game bugs and poor game controller support nothing really worked. The fact that my computer broke gave me a break to allow some updates to come out and let me reset my expectations. Now some updates have come out and I gave it some time coming back to it with a fixed computer. Only just, has the most recent patch allowed me to keymap a joystick correctly, somehow however, I have lost the ability to play in first person portions. Mouse and keyboard integration while using a third party controller has made making it past the tutorial stages an absolute nightmare. Before I could walk around but not fly the ship, now I can fly the ship but not walk around. Forget beta testing, this game still feels like it's in alpha... I want my money back at this point. I'll hold out that maybe one day this might be good, but this is just ridiculous.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Aside from the appalling bugs and crashes, there is little to credit this game: bad writing, atrocious acting and odd mannequin-style npcs in a world of very muddy console-like graphics.  I played using a controller, as that appears to be the principle user input of dev-choice, but even so experienced glitched button controls and lag.Recent patches have rendered previous saves unusable and game crashes often corrupt saves - there is only so many times you can re-start a game only to find progress remains blocked by bugs.How this game continues to be sold at £40 is an outrage.  Frankly, it should be withdrawn.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												It's not very enjoyable in its current state with many show stopper or game breaking bugs. Hopefully they will begin working these things out. I'm not sure how many of them, almost all of them really, got past their testing. This is more like a mid beta release than a real release, it reflects bad on them. To mention some of the bugs: You can easily que your ship to load into negative cargo, where it then no longer moves at all....There's quite a few ways that you can, without knowing, give your ships orders and then the ships will stop execution of orders and sit doing nothing forever.The UI is rather sluggish and at some points, actually turns sideways, that's great.Transport trading often takes 10-20 minutes of waiting for it to dock and transfer stuff.... where did SETA go?Many times the quest details are... non-existent, so if you leave the game for a couple days and then come back to it I hope you really remember exactly what you were suppose to be doing. The objective location isn't helpful when you don't know what to do there.And there's many more but those are the ones that come to my mind when I explain why I've put down the game for the time being. I do hope that in time they patch... fix? the game to make it a fully enjoyable experience.

												UPDATE: Hmm maybe i judged too soon? Since release, developers have been working around the clock to remove bugs and improve gameplay, controller issues and whatnot. Maybe it's time for a re-review? Yeah, I must admit when I launched the 1.21 version of X-Rebirth I was impressed by the TOTAL LACK of PROGRESS the dev team has made in making this atrocity playable. Ok there is tons of work to do to make this happen, but for the short amount of time I managed to play before CTDing, I didn't see any difference aside from the version number.  I'm pretty sure my framerate is even LOWER than what it was at launch. So NO, I didn't judge too soon. I rarely do. If this game were a dog, u'd shoot it in the face out of sheer compassion. Worst game in at least a decade. No srsly if u like this bug-infested pile of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, u need to get your head examined because you'll defenitely have one or more SERIOUS mental issues.If u like this "game" you'll also probably enjoy:- getting your teeth sawn out with a rusty hacksaw while being tied to a chair - seeing your familly getting r4p3d and killed by a bunch of smelly foreigners- slicing open newborn babies, decorating a tree with their entrails and putting their heads in a jar on a shelf next to the tree

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												For very casual gamers looking for a light space arcade to mess around with, you may enjoy XR. Highly recommend you wait until it's $10 though.For hard-core space (and especially X-series) junkies, beware. Everything that made previous X-series good is missing from XR, and it's not replaced by anything good either.All things that were supposed to enhance immserion and simplify the players interaction within the game instead wind up being hideous, tedious, annoying. Design deisions seem to squarely target children, and even that is done so horrendously bad a lot of children would probably think this game isn't very good.When compared to all prevous games in the X-series, X-Rebirth may wind up being one of the most epic failures on record, for any game series.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												I am a first-time player of the X series, and fully acknowledge that several fans of the series consider this game to not be one of the X series, but an attempt to make the game more accessible.At this time, I have not played X3 or any of the previous titles (though I have been highly recommended to do so).X Rebirth starts out just how you'd want, beautiful graphics, good physics, sandbox environment, some resemblance of a storyline. However, as several have noted the bugs in this release made the game ridiculous to play initially. I have heard that several of the bugs have been patched but I haven't given the game another chance since the first weekend I dedicated roughly 20-30 hours.After a few hours of getting acquainted, I found that I very quickly ran out of things to do. The game was sort of driving me along a storyline (which included several broken sections) but there was no clear direction on what the "end-game" content was meant to be. Sure, you can build stations, other ships, but you're limited to only one ship to fly? I bought this game thinking it was the "game to make EVE Online look horrible", but I later found out that is Star Citizen.Shame Steam doesn't offer refunds, this was a complete was of my money - and it clearly should've been marked as an early release of the game. A Metascore of 33 (the lowest of my library by far) speaks for itself as well. Save your money.

												This game is absolutely horrible!  First of all it was released as a finished product which was in its Alfa stage at best.  It's nothing like any other game in the X-series, all of those games were outstanding.  This game doesn't deserve that namesake.  The one bright side is the constant patching the developer does....at least once a month or so.  I will note that it's a very expensive game for which I'd like a refund on.  I spent $60.00 on it and purchased it the day it came out.  Months later it still isn't playable.  This is the worst experience I've ever had with a game period.  I would strongly advise against purchasing this game...ever since it was advertised very deceptively.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Terrible terrible terrible! What was promised to be the next level, next gen, advancement of the X series seems like 10 steps backwards! The game does not function well. All of the X games were buggy but this is unplayable! In stead of a smoothly polished new edition of the X franchise, we have recieved a game that has introduced flawed and worthless mechanics and overhauled the GUI / HUD with a pathetic menu system that is no where near as useful as the previous version. Flying your ships is completely different too. I loved every game and was very excited to buy this one, but I am so dissapointed and can't bring myself to continue to play as its just awful.At the very least you should be able to revert the system back to the method of the previous X games, with the old menu and old view and controls. Now you have a crappy looking cockpit and useless docking system and even more pointless 'off-ship exploration' (which looks like starwars KOTOR style). Everything has been made 10x worse with the new 'improvements'. minus maybe the background scenes. This is a massive facepalm for the company and they should have stuck with the old method, everybody loved it and it worked! Please please please save your money and don't buy this... OR buy the older X games such as X 3, or Albion Prelude.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												This is a highly unstable largely unfinished game that should be marked Early Access due to just how unplayable it is.It has potential to be a really cool almost EVE-Online Single Player-ish game, but right now you just have a game that runs at 15FPS on an nVidia 770 GTX. It crashes. It's slow. The AI is dumb and gets stuck in things.I wish I didn't buy this yet. It is NOT a complete video game and definitely not worth $50. Maybe in a year or two from now the Devs can finish the game then it might be worth trying again.Edit: After a year of updates the game runs smoothly at 60fps now. I'm not sure if they fixed the AI driving into walls or not, I'm also not sure if they revamped "chase" missions through the highways either, that used to be very glitchy as movement caused you to move erradically in the "lanes".I'm just not sure if this game is worth it at this point, I already spent $50 and have gotten nothing for my pains. It plays, but is it worth playing? My recommendation for now stays No as the developer left a dirty taste in my mouth by releasing a game like this as a full release. (If it was Early Access or beta I could have possibly given it some leniency.)

The ability to board stations and ships is a step in the right direction but the complete disregard for the quality of dialogue and voice acting is a big disappointment. The X series was never about clever dialogue but if you're going to make interaction with NPC's a more personal experience I feel a bit more care in this area was warranted.While the poor dialogue system is ever likely to be fixed, if the bugs and performance issues, which are the real problem here, can be tackled there is the potential for an amazing game. But it just isn't at that stage yet.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Stay away. Star far, far, away. You have been warned.Where to begin... actually, I have a good idea.Quite simply put, this game is unfinished. Beyond the plethora of bugs and performance issues, there aer many, many features that are simply not well implemented or unfinished. THERE IS NO RADAR ON A SPACE SIM GAME. That's something AWFULLY basic to leave out of a space sim.Trading is another excellent example of this. In order to trade in this game, you have to order your freighters to go around picking up or selling wares which takes ten or twenty minutes depending on the location or god forbid, you run into a bug where your freighter simply sits there and do nothing. However, for some unknown reason, Egosoft decided that a cancel trade order button is not necessary. Really? At this point, I don't even know if this is intentional design or just another checkmark on the growing list of unfinished features.Beyond key missing features, the state of the game itself feels unfinished as well. The truly awful looking character models look like they are placeholders until something better takes their place, and space scenery, while gorgeous, wavers upon closer examination as you fly up next to ships and stations and see generic, bland, I would say almost placeholder-like low-res textures.Adding in walk-in stations per requested below. There are only 3-4 presets in every system, which wouldn't be so bad in and of itself if the game did not force you to walk in stations for every other interaction. Picking up missions, dropping off missions, hiring marines, hiring pilots and officers. Couple that with the atrocious looking NPCs and you can see why almost no one likes this aspect of the game. The fact that the most popular mod is to REMOVE the need to walk in stations says volumes in and of itself. That being said, it can be a great platform for future mods, but in its current state, implementation, and restrictions? It is really bad.I have put hundred of hours in X3. While Egosoft had always said Rebirth is going to be a departure from the series, the pre-release promotion they did for the game is borderline fraud. Case in point, most of the features on its Steam page is missing or not working. The system requirement is a joke. I have a 4ghz i7, 16GB ram, and 7970 Crossfire and I consistently get 10fps in the game.tl;dr DON'T SUPPORT UNFINISHED GAME RELEASES

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												I keep installing it, playing it, uninstalling it... I want to play it, I want to like it, but I just can't.Bought the game on release day and thought it was terrible. Slow, buggy, annoying characters, poor design... I kept trying it again, after each patch, and found the game to be still lacking... Still buggy, still fundmentally flawed. So I unistalled it (again) and waited to see what the next patch would bring.First off it started off with rumours of "something big in May". Then I started seeing some stuff about the beta of 2.0 and some videos of gameplay. The videos made the game look fantastic (but then they always did) and when 2.0 was finally release, I reinstalled and tried it again... Nope.. Still a mess.My first attempt was a restart of the campaign. Seemed to play alright, but i really can't stand that annoying cow that gets dumped on you in the first few seconds of the game... Seriously, whoever thought she would be a good character? She's the Jar Jar Binks of the X Universe.So settling on  the more open approach of free play I loaded it up and started doing passenger transfer missions. Everything was going fine, a decent frame rate of around 40-50 FPS, highways were "OK" (could still do with some work especially when flying with autopilot which seems to want to crash into every ship in the highway at every chance it gets) and I started making money. Even had a couple of small dogfights and came out ok... Then it happened! After undocking from a station the game suddenly started running like a slideshow at 3FPS and no apparent reason why. It was fine when I first entered the system, fine when I flew to the station and fine for the 3+ hours that I'd spent playing the game previously. But all of a sudden it became unplayable. Even the pause menu took a good few seconds to display when I pressed escape. So I quit with a few passing remarks about Egosoft qualty control and "cowboy programmers" and uninstalled.Wanting to try some of the other starts I reinstalled it a couple of days later and tried trader. Not being familiar with which stations give which wares in this new X Universe I was just wandering aimlessly from system to system to system, going back to ferrying passengers around and trying to work out where I need to buy various things. It doesn't seem as clear cut as X3 where you knew that Power Circle was the place to get power cells and sell them to the neighbouring stations and you could start making money from there and branching out into other things once you'd made some cash. After an hour or so I gave up.So I finally tried Mercenary. Followed the waypoints to that guy who offers the partol, escort or passneger mission, then starting looking for other mission to complete. Was playing fine until.... 3FPS, but this time after only an hour and a half of play.Honestly, I give up on it.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												Not recommended... This is not the "X" game you are looking for...Firstly, let me stress that I am a massive fan of the previous "X" Games. When I saw "Rebirth" was due to be released I immediately found myself looking forward to getting lost in another massive, bustling galaxy with lots to see, do and buy. I always found the massive range of player useable ships meant I could always find something new to work toward purchasing and upgrading. Now, when I heard about Rebirth, and the ability to dock and walk around stations to trade, modernised graphics and a great new storyline campaign, I was ecstatic. I thought to myself "this is exactly the game I have been waiting for!". Unfortunately, when the game was first relased it received such appalling reviews that I did't even try it. I guessed (correctly I suppose) that if I waited a while then game-breaking bugs would be fixed, and the price would fall. So, with the release of the latest update, "Rebirth 2.0" which claims to have recitified the majority of faults and overhauled the gameplay based on player feedback (combined with the Steam promotion which was running at the time) I thought Rebirth might be worth a look. I was wrong...Visuals: Yes, it is pretty. Well... at least in space. Graphically this is a nice step up from the latest generation of X games, and is more or less what I had been expecting. However if you dock at a station, don't expect anything resembling realistic characters. Character models on the whole are grotesque, with extremely outdated visuals and horrible, frozen expressions. Stations themselves once you reach the interior, are simply cookie cutter copies of each other with very little variation at all. See one station, you've seen them all. At one stage of the storyline, an NPC aboard your ship exclaims "Wow, I've never seen a station like that before" (or words to that effect.) But as I clambered out of my ship, oh look it's the same docking bay/corridors/rooms as the previous 10. They're empty, lifeless, bland and generally uninteresting addtions to the game that in my opinion would have been better off ignored.Gameplay: Well... Bland. That seems to be the most commonly recurring word I think of when trying to accurately describe the majority of the game in fact. At first, flying around in your ship is reasonable fun as you take in the view and fly through the highways. But it gets old, fast. Firstly, the small to medium sized vessel you begin the game with is the only thing you will be flying. The "Albion Skunk" is yours for the duration. Sure, you can fit it with new weapons and engines as you'd expect, but you cannot purchase or fly other ships, even though you may own them and hire crew to fly them for you. And as flexible as this ship is, I can't help but long for the days of being able to pilot just about any ship I could find. I didn't get any sense of achievement or reward being stuck with the same, rather bland (there's that word again) ship throughout. Secondly, the campaign itself. I admit, I completely abandoned this after around 4 hours. I kept thinking something wonderful would be just around the corner, however I spent the entire time flying through numerous sectors in which there was nothing to see, to numerous stations in which there was nothing to do. Once there, I would talk to one of the numerous copy/paste NPCs who would then send me to do the same at another station. There is no longer any form of time dilation to speed up travel, you're stuck staring at space. On the whole, I think the biggest issue with this iteration is simply that there is nothing to DO... You spend your time floating meaninglessly through space filled with meaningless empty characters with no purpose. The large majority (and I'm really not exaggerating here) of NPC's will simply fly in circles without any concern for the world around them. I really, really wanted to like this game. And I tried, I really did. Unfortunately, it just wasn't to be. I am sorely disappointed, even after going in with low expectations following other poor reviews. Take my advice, and spend your money elsewhere.

												I bought the first release = TERRIBLE, as in unplayable.I upgraded to 2.0 = TERRIBLE Still, just not as terrible.I just tried 4.0 and was considering the latest DLC's = Fixed highway travel, but I just don't have the will power to learn this over engineered game just to have a little relaxation fun as a trader, fighter, explorer or miner. I absolutely can't get over the fact that I am stuck in the same ship, so it's not worth the emense amount of time it takes to learn the hidden UI features, flight controls, game mechanics, etc...etc.. just to manage other ships that I don't get to fly and feel like a grind or chore playing.Sorry, but games shouldn't be like learning a new job skill just to have a little fun. Overall the game interface is still lacking as it compares to general software user interfaces and reduces the game to a technical mess and just not fun to play.Absolutely over engineered with no real benefit for the casual player for all the hard work. This game is for the serious space sim dude with lots of time on his hands, who gets off on being technical for technicals sake.For the record, I am the type of gamer who really likes the EVE online level of ship control and having menus in obvious places to manage the game. Where you can start doing meaningful stuff within a 10 minute tutorial session and build from there. Not hours of hard study, writing down menu commands on post it notes, etc. Being able to fly different ships is an absolute must, if it's a ship flying game, so this game is still a deal breaker. Why fix such a broken game concept? It's a NO vote from this casual. Uninstall, again.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24
												A complete departure that looks and plays worse than the older games. Fans will hate it, new players will think it's awful.The game has completely changed (hence the name), and for the worst. It used to be a technical marvel with solid gameplay, now it's another generic, stereotypical low budget obscure game.Everything about it is worse than even X2, which was released in 2003. Gameplay is clunky; interiors, characters, all look like they came from 2001; even the backdrops of planets and stars look less amazing; the voice acting is actually worse; the music isn't as good as it used to, and one mini-game has a stereotypical techno-ish soundtrack that loops every 3 seconds, and not even properly, so it skips.X3 had 100, 150 sectors. This game basically has 4 different backdrops. FOUR. Four very large maps, but pointlessly large, they could've stuffed it all into a smaller space.Getting from place to place is no longer by jump gates, but you fly through 'highways'. No longer do you immediately get where you want to go, but you must 'drive' down these highways for 10, 20 seconds, longer. Combat is no longer smooth and dramatic and certainly no sexy battles going on here. Even the pilots aren't bothered, literally saying stuff like "yup I felt that" rather than screaming as they face death.Trading requires more douching around. You can now walk in stations, but they all look the same. You can talk to people... well no, you can't talk to people. You can click on them and get them to show their wares or hire them or whatever, and on occasion you can engage in 'small talk' if they blurt something out loud about one of 4 subjects. Same quotes, same answers, just to get a little discount or info you could live without. The sitting-in-a-ship-reading-news-and-hearing-announcements from previous games were far more immersive.The poor production values and slow (even for the X series!) gameplay ruin the story mode, I was not invested in any way.Old games like X2 and Freelancer, budget games like Darkstar One, even recent games like No Man's Sky or that one space level from Call of Battlefield do it so much better.

I recommend the game on GoG, not on Steam.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												This game is in the works.  Needs a better actress for Yisha (Your very ANNOYING copilot).  Going on stations, boring.  The other people in FP visitations are dry, and lack vitality.  Capital ships NEED bridges, not landing pads.  Gameplay is pretty cool when you can actially command from the cap ship.  The skunk (your ship) is explorable, but bland and also does not feel like it has personality, let alone function or life outside the actual controls in the front.  The concept of this game is AWESOME.  The downfall right now is lack of function of station visitations, general lifeless feel from NPCs, and the acting.  The narration from the ship computer (and station announcement lady) are also read as though they didnt bother to have any quality control overview.  The economy is still a mess, there is a general lack of any goal other than to build a capship, or whatnot and maybe a space station.  As far as exploration, you wont be finding any actual adventure other than beautiful scenery outside of the main story plot.  All the women look butch.  And act butch.  This game was built for people who like strategy games and mercantile activities, but fighting, trading and exploring is just plain AWEFUL.  If I were to make any recommendations to the development of this release, it would be to go back and get better actors.  Better animations for NPCs, add capship bridges, and more functions to the ships and bridges, and mini adventure content, and redo the textures on stations and keep getting the economy repaired.  the devs do a great job, but only as of now have catered to merchants.  What they offer explorers, fighters, and thinkers is so narrow, and it takes away from the game dramatically.  I asm not sure that the developers really care to address these VERY important character flaws of their baby, because I believe they think they will please us players somehow eventually.  People are still very unhappy about this game, and yes it had a bad launch, but they will not gain momentum with gamers unless they BALANCE their efforts.  So far, traders get %90.  And since freelook, no immersive features added,  I give this game a thumbs up, but I EXPECT the devs not only repair bugs and add a few features but create a more immersive atmosphere, by getting these NPCs and missions some more flavor.  More "functions"  more "interactions on ships and stations"

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Okay first off, this is not a bad game, in fact it has the makings of a great game, the reason its been panned is because of the rough release where the develeopers were told they had to release the game early or be shut down, so everyone bought it and it was, predictably, filled with game breaking bugs and all the rest.If you played the older titles in this series you'll be in for a shock, it has elements of the older ones but it is a completely new game, you need to realise the X series is infamous for its steep learning curbs but, its a game that you play for the long haul, what all X games have is that feeling of starting off as a nobody in a lore rich universe filled with varrying factions, and slowly building up an empire wether it be a pirate, police, or commercial one. There are lots of reasons why people hate this game, whether it being the quirks of the npc's, how easy it is to die, the learning curb, or just people who bought the initial release. I can tell you, Egosoft have done a great job at supporting this game and they are still, to this day building it into the game they originally envisioned along with the fantastic support of the steam workshop.Best thing you can do is to just look up some gameplay on youtube, decide if it interests you, then decide if you want to refund it. Just realise, the game company have put their souls into this game, where the publishers wanted an ASAP release.

The problem stems from the fact the game simply will not let you lower it to those min settings.Even on low graphics every surface of the game is covered in lighting effects out the♥♥♥♥♥that would make a triple A title fume in jealousy and somehow space itself just seems like one giant lens flare. This game has no real story and poor to mediocre at best Voice Acting so it relies on it's gameplay and looks to win you over: seems they banked everything into looks if you want them or not. Cant speak to gameplay, as I said all 3 hours I played this game was a frustrating series of graphical issues making me rage quit before even fully finishing the tutorial.
